Cool-down: 

Worked out in lane 6 at the U. It was a lot of fun to be in there and feed off the energy of everyone running and the music blasting. I felt good. By the end of this I was tired, but it was the good tired that you get after a solid session. With some more good workouts over the next 2 weeks I think I can run a PR in the 3K.

Lilydale with Run N Fun. We ran pretty slow the whole way which felt good after last night's workout. The roads and sidewalks are pretty slick and slushy. My left hamstring and hip are a bit sore but not worrisome.

Treadmill at noon. The TV was tuned to First Take instead of Sports Center and First Take is impossible to watch without being able to hear it, so this kind of dragged on. Legs felt tired. With a mile and a half left Unforgiven II came on the gym iPod and that got me kind of pumped up.

When I got home from work I was starving so I ate a bagel with peanut butter and about half of a bag of goldfish. I didn't really feel like running and had almost decided to take the evening off and watch a movie instead before telling myself to man up and head out. The first two miles I was wondering what I was doing, but the last hour I ended up having a good run. Sidewalks had quite a few icy spots.

25 min tempo
5 min jog
4 x 30 seconds fast (1 min jog)

Went to the dome for a tempo. Warmed up with Nick, Leaf, and Phil, then ran the workout solo. Felt strong and relaxed, and if the 5 laps to 2 miles measurement is accurate I was running 5:12-5:15 pace the whole time after my first lap (which was at 5:05 pace). The strides at the end didn't feel very good. I am expecting that I will be sore tomorrow from the surface. This was fun to do once but I wouldn't want to do it every week.
Treadmill at lunch with no TV and no music. I was thinking about racing though so the time passed quickly enough.

Ran on the treadmill again because it was snowing out and I'm soft. Looks like I'm going to have to move things around the next couple of days thanks to weather and scheduling. Shouldn't be too big of a deal. Felt pretty good tonight. I'm pleasantly surprised that the dome didn't trash my legs.

Spun the hampster wheel again this morning. I set up my portable DVD player in front of the treadmill and watched the Butler v Gonzaga game from a few weeks ago. Legs felt really good. I need to do some catching up on sleep though; past 2 nights have been way too short.

27 min run
800m SSJCs
2 x 200m in 29.1 and 30.2 (50m walk, 150 jog between)
800m+ cooldown

Since I was in Northfield I decided to take advantage of Tostrud for a second run and get a little shot of speedwork in. Ran like a mile with Grant while he was finishing up his run. My goal for the 200s was to run 30s. The first one was a little bit too fast but I suppose it's nice to know that I can still run a 29 low. My second one was basically at Galen Rupp's goal 3K pace for later tonight. Crazy.

Long run to the Franklin Bridge and back. I felt tired at the start and the way out felt like it took 2 hours just by itself. The way back went by much more quickly. The path was a bit snowy so the footing wasn't great. Nice training week.

I was feeling a little run down so I just took it easy this evening. It's not real surprising since I did quite a bit last week. Legs felt much better at the end of the run than they did at the beginning.
Shakeout for tonight's workout. Got a pretty tough one on tap.

***INTERVAL***
Warm-up: 
Set...Reps...Distance/Time...Goal...Actual...Rep rest...Set rest
1.........5.....1000 Meters....____....2:56, 2:55, 2:55, 2:56, 2:52....2:00....____
2.........1.....400 Meters....____....65....____....____
Cool-down: 

Worked out at the U with Nick and Jordan Zwick. The original plan was 4 x 1000 + 2 x 400 and I thought it was going to be really tough. I paced the first one (shooting for just under 3:00) and felt strong and smooth, and pretty much knew from that point that I'd have a good day. On the next two we were supposed to surge the 3rd 200. We did, but the surges weren't anything special...34s or so. After the 3rd K I decided I'd do 5 since I was still feeling really good. On the last one I was 2:22 at 800 and then closed in a 30 (that was planned). Nick then asked if I wanted to jump in a 400...I still felt alright, so why not? 65 felt (dare I say) easy. This is my best track workout since college and stacks up well with some of the better ones I've ever done. It was great to run it with other people; I've got to do that more often. Big confidence boost for the race next week.

I started this run really late for a variety of reasons. Did the same run I did last Wednesday to St Thomas and back. Once I move next month this will only be about a 5 mile run. Felt ok but I was a bit tired from a combination of the workout yesterday and a long day today. The sidewalks and path were also in pretty bad shape from the recent snow.
Lunch run. It was a bit warmer in the fitness center than it has been.
Ran in the slop on river road. I'm contemplating driving down to Olaf to get tomorrow's workout in, as it's not possible outside right now and I don't want to skip it.

Worked out at St Olaf.  This was a nice moderate effort that allowed me to get a little bit of work in and feel out the pace for next week.  I didn't feel as good as I did on Tuesday, but I expected that I wouldn't.  Still got through without too much effort.  This weekend I'll be able to get some rest.  I couldn't have run 68s for 3K tonight but hopefully next Friday it can happen.  Tavern dinner afterward with Aleta.
15 miles isn't really a long run anymore.  Felt alright but towards the end I was getting hungry since I didn't eat a lot today.  Finished up just in time to watch the mile at the Husky Classic.
Ran on the treadmill thanks to the snow/freezing rain.  Got to watch most of the second half of the Lakers game.  Felt good.

Easy shakeout.  I'm dropping my miles this week to try to have a good race on Friday.  One easy week won't screw me up as far as peaking later this spring and the confidence that would come with a good race would be well worth any tradeoff.

Tuneup workout at the U.  Started off in lane 6 but my pacing was sloppy so after the first 800 I slid down to lane 1.  The mile started off in 2:37, then I came back in 2:29.  Felt smooth.  The first 800 was just weird.  Don't know what happened.  The second one and the 400s were better.  I went after it on the 200...I had one gear left but that was as fast as I've moved in quite some time.  Overall I didn't feel fantastic but that's fine.  Save that for Friday.

All the sidewalks and paths outside are sheets of ice so I ran on the treadmill.  Felt alright.  Some older women came in with a bunch of bottles of wine and went in the sauna.  Pretty sure that's against the rules, but whatever.
Late morning treadmill run.  I think ESPN talked about LeBron James for at least 20 of the 28 minutes that I was running.  Legs felt good, although I did not sleep well last night.
Ran in a combination of rain/snow.  There were some large puddles on the path from melting.  Not a very fun run, but at least I felt good.
Pre race run and strides.  Not really a confidence booster because I felt terrible.
Easy shakeout at like 11:30 on the treadmill.  The demons are pretty loud right now, I've got about eight hours to work this out.
Waited all day to run.  I got through it alright but my legs (and body in general) are pretty tired.  Down day tomorrow, which will be nice.
Planned down day to recover from the weekend.  It was windy and cold, and I was tired.  3 more weeks until daylight savings time.

I was going to go to Run N Fun but I ended up deciding that I didn't want to run outside in 20 mph winds and -10 windchill, so I spun the hampster wheel instead.  It ended up working out ok since I got to watch Michigan State v Indiana.  Still not feeling super chipper.  I also lifted some weights.

7 mile sub threshold run

Nice longer tempo on river road.  The goal on dry pavement would have been 5:30s...since a decent portion of this was on ice I may have been slightly slower but I don't think it was by too much.  My legs felt better on this than they have on any other run since Saturday.  Finished with 6 x '100m' and 2 x '200m'.

Treadmill at lunch.  Felt better than I thought I would.  Kept the pace slow.

Something in my left hip was causing me to walk with a bit of a hitch when I left work.  I also felt it at the start of the warmup on Saturday and a couple of other times since then.  I decided to take the evening off rather than force in a run with an altered stride.  Means my weekly total will be lower, but right now I care a lot less about that number than I used to.
Hip is no longer an issue, but I'm tired.

9:30 PM run on Friday evening after working all day.  Yup, that's how cool my life is right now.  Legs felt crappy, as they have pretty much all week.  The second half of the run I was thinking about racing a 10K, so that at least made it a little more exciting.

Good long run this afternoon.  Lots of slush and puddles, which was annoying, but I'm feeling a lot stronger on runs over 15 miles than I did last year.  16th and 17th miles were under 6:00.  Legs will be back soon...I think.
Felt like doing an easy shakeout
The server was down at work this morning so I took my lunch break a little early.

12 x Ford Hill

Started the warmup at 9 PM.  Long day.  The sidewalks were pretty slushy and icy on the warmup and I was thinking (hoping?) that I might not be able to do the workout, but the hill was mostly clear.  There was a big puddle at the bottom, so the repeats were a little shorter than what I usually do.  I felt good running this.  The jog down at times even seemed slightly too long.

Not proud of this.  I went to the Gophers game against Indiana (which was AWESOME) and couldn't summon the motivation to run afterward.  My average hours of sleep in the past week is under 6, and I have just been feeling tired and lazy for awhile.  I've kind of fallen off the wagon with training since Snowshoe.  Need to get back on.

Ran at lunch.  I did this outside for the first time in several weeks.  The middle two miles essentially consisted of 'running' probably 9:00 pace on ice.  The forecast for the next week looks decent, so maybe it will melt soon.  Legs felt good, but not sleeping much is wearing me out.  I hope I don't get sick.
Ran to downtown and back.  Felt fine. 6 strides.

21 min tempo (roughly 4 miles)
5 min rest
3 x 2:00 @ 5K effort (1:30 int)
3 min rest
6 x 0:30 Fast (1:00 int)

This went better than I thought it might.  Felt solid at all 3 paces.  There are quite a few frozen puddles on the path, mostly at road crossings, which was annoying.  On the second 30 second interval I scared the crap out of some guy walking his dog and listening to his iPod.  I kind of wish I could run the Jacksonville 15K next weekend.

Ran roughly 9 hours after finishing last night's workout, and I did not sleep very well again last night.  All things considered the run wasn't too bad.  I didn't feel good running up hills, but on the flats I was fine.  I'm excited to watch MIACs tonight.

Capped the long run at 16 this week because I'm tired and there is no sense in doing a 2 hour plus run that puts me in the hole.  I got through the run with no problems and kind of wished I had done another mile at the end.  Overdressed...it didn't bother me on the run but when I was done my stuff looked like I had just taken a shower in it.

For whatever reason I've found it extremely difficult to get out the door the past couple Sundays, and that trend continued today.  Once I did get out there this was just another run...didn't feel particularly good or bad.  I'm getting sick of stomping thru puddles.  The 6 to 10 inches of snow that is on the way will not make things any better.

Past 4 weeks: 80, 70.5, 81, 83.  Not great volume, but I'm fit, I'm totally healthy, I'm excited for the spring, and the training I've done the past two months is something I can build off of rather than a cycle that has me peaking now.  As long as I can make it through Friday's actuarial exam without getting sick I'll be able to put in a couple of good weeks of training in March and then have some fun in April.
I'm sort of wondering whether running 5 miles in the mornings actually does anything for my fitness, or if I just do it a couple of times a week because I always have.

Worked out at the U.  There was no sense of camaraderie tonight since the only other people there were the Team USA Minnesota crew and they were done with their workouts before I started mine.  The last three minutes of the 3200 were kind of tough.  I'm glad I was able to get it under 10 though.  The 400s weren't bad.  Overall a good effort.  I was hoping that this would be my last workout on the indoor track for the year, but looking at the forecast I'd say it's likely that I'll be back next week.
Wheel spinning.  Legs actually felt pretty good.
Usual lunch run on the treadmill.
Late night run on river road.  They had it pretty much all cleaned up after yesterday's snow.  Saw a couple of stoners.
Took it easy.  Exam tomorrow.
Indoor shakeout while reviewing my notes.

9 x Ford Hill

Didn't feel great on this, but hills rarely feel good anyway.  Now that my exam is over my goal is to get myself back to feeling normal by Wednesday's workout.  It was nice to run in shorts and to get the whole run done before the sun went down.  Can't wait to make both of those things a habit over the course of the next few weeks.
Ran a little bit faster than normal.  6 strides at the end.

Hardest I've ever bonked in my life.  My body pretty much completely ran out of gas with 5 miles left.  I decided to come back via St Paul Ave since it would be a mile shorter, but the sidewalks on that street were sheets of ice and I probably spent more time walking than running.  Not a fun time.
Didn't accomplish my goal of getting the entire run in before dark, but it was nice to at least be able to start when it was light out.  Felt much better than yesterday.

From Run N Fun with a solid crew.  It was light out for basically the entire run, which was awesome.  We went down to the river and then came back up Summit (this wasn't a full 10, but my first run today was more than 4 and yesterday's run was more than 10, so it all balances out).  About 2/3 of the way through I started getting hungry and a little light headed, but then I got a second wind.  Did six strides at the end...legs felt really good on those.

My boss let me leave work at 4 to go work out and then come back to the office later, which worked out really nice.  Once again there wasn't much going on in the fieldhouse...some Augsburg sprinters were practicing and Plasencia was hitting ground balls to Chris Rombough and another guy.  I didn't feel very good on the warmup, or at any point during the workout, but was able to get through 5 intervals without feeling too much worse.  I almost always slowed down the second 200 and then would get back on.  A sixth interval would have been nice but I didn't want to force it.  The 150s were kind of fun.
I didn't necessarily want to take an easy day today, but my body needed it.
~4 hours of sleep last night.  Dishwasher flooded my kitchen at 1 AM.
Ran after the Badger game ended.  Felt pretty tired.

24 min tempo
5 min jog rest
5 x Ford Hill

This was a good workout.  The tempo felt really solid.  Hills gave me some practice at pushing while tired.  My legs felt pretty wrecked afterward.
Decided to run on the treadmill during the Wisconsin game rather than waiting until after both the game and the selection show.  Watching the game made the run pass quickly.

Monday night long run.  It snowed last night and this morning, but the majority of the route was cleared.  The first couple miles were into a 20 mph headwind, which wasn't fun, but then the last few miles were with it at my back.  Felt fine physically, just was getting kind of bored by the end.  I don't think I'll run long on a weeknight again anytime soon.  I'm glad I got some long runs in during March this year.

Lilydale from Run N Fun, mostly with Nick.  Didn't feel that good...probably a combination of the long run yesterday and the fact that at lunch I drank a beer and no water.  Cold and windy...if we had this weather on December 19 or January 19 I would be totally fine with it, but because it's March 19 it makes me crabby.

Mediocre Ks workout at the U.  I felt like I started this workout with only a half full gas tank.  I didn't have any problems with breathing but my legs felt a little weak.  Still hit decent times...not as fast as I did 1000s six weeks ago, but that day was as good of a workout as I've ever had and I can't expect that every time.  Decided to just do a 600 instead of a full 6th one in order to not completely empty the tank, and I also wanted to make sure I broke 70 second pace at least once.  As long as I take care of myself the next couple of days I've got the fitness for a good race on Sunday.

Ran at lunch and watched the NCAA Tournament.  I felt kind of beat up getting out of bed this morning but by the time I ran I felt better.  Looking forward to having this evening off since that rarely happens.

Ran in the morning.  First run from the new apartment, even though I've been living there for a week.  14 degrees outside...  Despite still being really tired when my alarm went off once I got about two miles in this way a pretty enjoyable run.  I negative split by two minutes and the way back is a net uphill, so I must have been crawling out of the gates.
Little shakeout and a couple of strides after work.  Ran to St Thomas and back.  Felt good.
Easy pre-race run on river road.  Legs felt good.  Stomach was very unsettled, which made the run not very much fun.  Excited for tomorrow; the race is loaded.
Race day shakeout
Results say I got 13th, but I definitely beat John Heitzman.  Something got screwed up.

Easy recovery run to downtown and back.  Last time running from my West 7th St apartment.  Felt alright, quads weren't sore walking around today whereas last year they were wrecked the day after Human Race.  The weather's warming up little by little.
Ran outside at lunch.  Lots of puddles.  Felt good, although I was dead tired waking up this morning.  Easy workout on tap for later.

4 miles soft tempo (5:30-5:40 pace, started on the slower side)
5 min jog rest
6 x Ford Hill

I wanted to get something besides easy running in today but wasn't ready for a hard workout yet after Sunday.  This was a nice moderate effort.  The 'tempo' felt really easy, which I suppose it should seeing as it's slower than the pace I hope to run for a marathon this fall.  Legs are getting stronger from the hills I've been doing.  I might not have had quite enough to eat during the day.

After a long, chaotic day I ran late at night.  Went out and back over the Franklin bridge and down West River.  I still have to really figure out running from my new place.  Legs felt good.  There are some shady looking characters that hang out by the river at night.

There's no way I'd be able to leave work to go to the U to workout today, so I went to Plan B and did this along the river during lunch.  The odd intervals were with the wind and the even ones were into it.  I maintained pace/slightly sped up throughout, so that's nice.  Felt like I was running at about 8K effort.  The last two I was able to practice digging in when tired.  For a workout that was squeezed into the middle of the workday I'll take it.  I'll probably do a little shakeout tonight since I didn't have time for much of a cooldown.
It's finally feeling like spring.  Lots of puddles out there.
Left work at 10 PM.  Almost scrapped the second run but ended up doing 6.
Long run down the river road and up Summit.  Felt good until the last mile and a half.  Legs don't feel that great now so hopefully I can recover quickly for a workout on Monday.  Beautiful weather.

Ran along the river with Aleta biking next to me.  It was colder than I thought it would be based on looking outside.  Legs felt really good, especially considering how tired they were after yesterday's long run.
Morning run on Summit.  Didn't really like the route, too many stoplights for a 5 mile morning run.  It was also too cold for April 1...windchill of 9 degrees.  At least I felt pretty good.

Easy run and strides.  Felt good.  I was wearing a Run N Fun top and when I passed two people I heard one of them say, 'Oh we don't have to worry about being passed by him.  He runs for Run N Fun so he's fast.'  Haha.

Last indoor workout for the year.  The snow is mostly gone but I didn't want to have to try to hit times in an important workout in 30 degree, windy weather.  Ran in lane 6 at the U.  It took a couple of intervals to find the pace (first one I was out in 73, the second one I overcompensated and got out in 68), but by #3 I was on it.  I felt strong, and unlike last year and 2 years ago this pace didn't feel super fast.  I definitely had to work on the last couple, but if I wanted to I could have done an 8th (and probably would have if this wasn't a race week).  Big confidence boost...I think 14:4X in the 5K is realistic with good weather.

Bumped into Metzdorff about 5 minutes in, so I ended up doing most of the run with him.  Legs felt good...I could have run a couple more miles tonight but I am making an effort to rest well before my races this year.  I'm pretty pumped for Sunday.
Didn't sleep terrific last night, but the run was fine.  Morning runs are actually fairly enjoyable now that it's warmer outside.

16 min tempo
3 min rest
3 min @ ~8K effort
3 min rest
4 x 30 seconds fast (1 min jog)

Light tuneup workout this evening.  Didn't feel transcendent (which I suppose is good), but felt decent enough.  I may have started a little too fast on the tempo.  Finished up with about 60 hours until I start my warmup on Sunday.  Rest well now.

Ran during lunch.  My right achilles has been sore at the start of runs for the past two days.  After a couple miles I am not noticing anything, but it still makes me a little nervous.  Other than that this felt decent.  I was really hungry at the end.

Pre-race run in Chicago with Ben Jacobs, Ben Kampf, Greeno, and Nick.  We ran along the lakeshore.  Achilles was bothering me for the first 15-20 minutes, then it went away.  It was super windy.  Did a few strides at the end.  Legs felt neither great nor bad.  I also walked somewhere between 4 and 5 miles at night.

Took the day off.  I want to kill this achilles issue before it becomes a real problem.  Signed up for the 5K at St Thomas on Friday...the next two days will determine whether or not I actually run it.

Lilydale with Run N Fun.  I was the youngest person there by about 4 years.  Pace was nice and relaxed.  My achilles isn't really any better after the day off, but it felt better after rolling it out and doing some heel drops post-run.  I'll just take this day by day I guess.
Ran at lunch.  Felt good except for that darn achilles.  Here comes the snow...

First time not running on my birthday since 7th grade.  Last night I made it five minutes before turning around and walking home because my achilles was a good bit worse than it has been.  This is probably the first time in a few years that I wished I still lived in Appleton, as there I'd have immediate access to e-stim and PT.  Here I'm just going to have to wait it out.  I didn't have too much important training scheduled for this week, but if I can't get back on schedule by early next week going to Hillsdale will have to be re-evaluated.  I suppose the one bright spot spot of this is that the weather absolutely sucks right now, so at least I don't have to force myself to run in it.

54 min elliptical

10 min warmup
10:00, 2 x 5:00, 2 x 3:00 Hard (2:00 Easy Between)
10 min cooldown

Had to get something in to try to keep my sharpness, but there's only so much you can do on an elliptical.  I got really hot while doing this, mainly my feet.  At least I got to watch The Masters.  I'm decently optimistic that I'll be able to run tomorrow.

Easy run.  If I did this during a normal 90-100 mile week I wouldn't have any concerns, but because of the past week I'm overanalyzing things.  Achilles feels much better.  No real pain on this run, it just felt a little 'abnormal' if I really thought about it.  Waking up this morning and reading/watching the coverage about Kobe's achilles rupturing last night and it being a possible career ender scares the heck out of me, although I realize my injury is not remotely close to his.  Hopefully things will continue to move forward.  The weather felt like February.  34 degrees with snow on the sides of the path.
Ran in wind and sleet.  Wasn't all that much fun, but I'm happy to be out there.  Achilles behaved pretty well.
Ran at lunch.  It wasn't going very well so I hopped off the treadmill a mile early.  No more treadmill running for now.

I took ibuprofen about an hour before this run and was then able to get through it essentially pain free.  I also attempted a few strides, and those weren't a problem either.  Thoughts and prayers to all those in Boston...can't believe what happened.

30 min tempo
4 x 1 min hard (1 min rest)

Well, the good news from this is that it doesn't seem like barely running last week affected my fitness much.  I felt strong and was running sub 5:20 pace (getting down towards 5:10) after the first few minutes.  The 'less good' news is that this wasn't pain free.  It was great to see the sun again; made the run much more enjoyable.  Hillsdale is still up in the air right now...the next 3-4 days will determine whether I make the trip or not.
Ran from work.  This actually wasn't that bad.

Big O reunion run in Minneapolis with Adrian, Prez, Letich, and Burseth.  Achilles hurt.  This is getting old.  Part of me is thinking I should just take a week off.  Fun run and dinner afterward though.

Essentially got forced into a day off by Mother Nature.  With a bad achilles I can't run outside on the unplowed paths (yes, it snowed several inches on April 18th), and running on the treadmill aggravates it since you're always going slightly uphill.  I guess some extra rest is ok.

I crushed this workout.  Every rep was sub 4:50 pace.  Last August I did basically this same workout on a track, and today was significantly faster in training shoes and on river road where there are some hills.  I really wish I could utilize this fitness in a race.

Achilles is blown up after yesterday's workout.  It's really swollen.  The first three miles of this run I was actually thinking, 'Hey, I actually feel pretty good', but by the time I was five miles in I was hurting pretty bad.  Had to take several walk breaks on the way back.  Racing next weekend is definitely out of the question...I've got to just take some time off and get this healed up.  There are 9 weeks until the US Half Champs, so at least I have some time.  Some will probably say that working out last night was dumb.  Maybe it was, but my defense is that if I was going to race next week I needed to test it, and I saved myself time, money, and probably at least some frustration and disappointment by having this happen this weekend rather than driving out to Michigan next weekend to DNF or run 32 minutes on a gimpy leg.
Watched the Lakers game and the Bucks game.  The only time either of my teams had a lead was when the Lakers were ahead 2-0.  That pretty much sums up the day.
The field for the Gina 10K is strong (as always) and it looks like the weather will be just about perfect for it (again, as always).  Maybe next year I'll make it out there.
I've got a nice cold now to go with the achilles tendonitis.  It's not my week.  I'm trying to stay positive, but mostly failing.
My achilles isn't swollen anymore and it doesn't hurt at all walking around (although it never really did, so that's not much of a sign of anything).  Perhaps I will try running tomorrow.

Short test run.  Achilles felt normal, but my dad said that on my first run back I wouldn't feel anything so I guess that doesn't really mean much.  Breathing felt pretty rough thanks to my cold.  The weather was really nice.

Ran along the river at lunch.  Absolutely beautiful day...would have been nice to go for a regular length run.  Kind of bummed since I had been looking forward to setting a 10K PR today for awhile but that isn't happening.  I'm not totally sure yet what I'll do this weekend.
Feels kind of pathetic to log 3 mile runs.  Gotta be smart though, if I screw this up and have to take another week + off the US Half Champs will be in doubt.
Baby steps.  Tried to focus on just enjoying being outside on such a nice day.  Achilles feels like it's getting better, but post-run it would creak whenever I bent my ankle.
Same run as yesterday.  Right after the run I did a workout on the elliptical.  5 min warmup, 20 min 'tempo' + 2 x 3 min hard (2 min ints), 5 min cooldown.
Elliptical.  Details logged above.
30 minutes bike
I bumped into the Run N Fun guys on river road and ran with them for about 10 minutes.  Also did 30 minutes of biking.  Last nice day before some cold rain comes our way.

Ran at lunch.  The first 20 minutes was the best I've felt in quite awhile, but by the end the achilles was hurting.  This is incredibly frustrating...I spend like two hours each day stretching, rolling, doing eccentric calf raises, and icing, but it's not getting better.  I don't know what else I can do for it.  52 days until Duluth.  I have to be back training within the next two weeks or the race won't happen for me.  Unfortunately my 'A' goals are probably already out the window.

Really encouraging run this evening.  Felt essentially nothing.  I looked down at my watch at 35 minutes and thought, 'Woah, I'm going to finish this thing feeling good!'  Hopped on the elliptical afterward for a workout: 5 min warmup, 10 min hard, 5 x 3 min hard (2 min recoveries), 5 min cooldown.
Elliptical.  Detailed above.
50 minutes elliptical

Ran in a light drizzle.  Felt pretty good once again.  Still can feel something going on down there (especially when I touch it), but it's definitely getting better.  I also ellipticalled at lunch in order to get a little more in for the day.
Best run I've had in a couple weeks.  Didn't feel any discomfort in the achilles, and my stride actually felt fluid for the first time in awhile.  Ellipticalled a little bit afterward.
30 minutes elliptical

Crappy run.  Achilles felt ok for the most part but my body as a whole felt like trash because I didn't fall asleep until like 4 AM last night.  I was toying with the idea of doing 10 but right before I went out I decided that it would be better to wait one more day.  By the halfway point of this 6 miler I was glad for that decision.  

This may be the fewest miles I've ever done in a week in which I ran all 7 days.  The only time I might have ever been lower would have been at the very end of a season when I was in high school.

Could feel the achilles for pretty much the entire second half of the run.  The pain level is only like a 3/10, but I'm not comfortable going farther or trying to do a workout on it.  Elliptical workout afterward,,,pretty much the same thing as last Monday except this time I did 23 min @ 'tempo' rather than 20.

I decided that I'm going to take a short break from this website.  I don't think I'll be gone long, but right now my injury and comparing the limited training I can do with what everyone else is doing is depressing me.
Elliptical workout.  Details above.
30 minutes elliptical

Lunch: 30 min elliptical

Evening: Ran 10, pretty much pain free!  Tried to focus on form.  First shirtless run of the year!
40 minutes elliptical

Lunch: 40 min elliptical.  I almost went for a run, but decided against it at the last minute.

Evening: Easy six miler in the rain.  Didn't mind it too much.  Six strides afterward.  They felt sloppy.
30 minutes bike

3 x 5 min @ tempo (1 min rest)
4 x 90 sec @ ~5K (90 sec rest)
4 x 30 sec @ ~Mile (30 sec rest)

With only six weeks until the half I have to get some quality running in.  This was supposed to be a pretty easy re-introduction to working out.  I took the first tempo interval out conservatively and built into it.  The next two were solid.  The 5K paced stuff felt much harder than stuff like this did several weeks ago, but I'm not too worried about that.  I felt a few twinges in the achilles afterward, but after stretching and icing it felt the same as last night, so that's good.

Lunch: 30 min shakeout on the bike

I didn't want to run in the morning because I wanted as close to 24 hours of rest as possible after last night's workout.  My plan was to do a late night 6 mile run after watching the 10Ks and 4x800s at MIACs, but I ended up deciding to just take the day off since I have to run in the morning tomorrow and I'm planning on going longer.  I justified it by telling myself that I don't really gain much fitness from easy 6 mile runs and that I am better off making sure that I have a good run tomorrow rather than taking any unnecessary risks with a quick turn around.  Then right after I ate dinner I kind of regretted this decision.  I had PT this morning, so at least I did something that will benefit me.

Ran down Shepard Road to the Crosby Farms Woods, ran in there for awhile, then flipped and went back.  Achilles didn't really bother me at all during the run but I could feel some soreness standing around at MIACs later in the day.  It was super windy.
Jogged around for a little bit in the morning.  Nothing notable about this one.

Ran over the Franklin Bridge and turned around about a minute later.  It looked like a really nice day outside but it felt like early April.  Achilles felt alright but my legs are pretty sore in general.
40 minutes elliptical

Ran out and back to the Crosby Farms Woods.  About 45 minutes into the run I did 4 x 60 seconds and 4 x 30 seconds with 60 seconds in between everything.  There was no stopping at any point in the run.  These were basically just long strides...I'm trying to get the legs re-used to moving faster.  It was a little windy, but overall a nice evening for running.  I've got a plan sketched out for the next six weeks.  If I can follow it I think I'll have a chance at running a fairly decent race in Duluth.  We'll see if I can pull it off.

Also did 40 minutes elliptical at lunch.

Ran in the morning when it was 50 degrees and calm rather than waiting until this evening when it is going to be 90 and windy.  Legs are super sore.  I guess I ran 20 miles in about a 13 hour timespan, but it still seems a bit ridiculous.  Not the most enjoyable run because I never felt loose, but I'm sure that doing it this evening would have been worse.
I figured I'd feel better tomorrow if I moved my legs again and stretched.

Workout Wednesday at Macalester.  Just under 80 degrees, a little bit of wind.  Eric Thies and Erik Teig were also on the track working out.  Unfortunately I did exactly what I didn't want to do and started off too fast.  This combined with the fact that I haven't done a workout like this in quite awhile made the last two intervals pretty tough.  Still got through it and kept them under 5:10 at least.  My breathing felt decent the whole way but this was tough on my legs.  The cooldown wasn't a lot of fun.  Hopefully I will improve quickly...I can't force it though.

Well, I've been on here a couple times already this week so I suppose I might as well start logging again.  I've got writeups from my hiatus saved on my computer and will paste them in when I have time.  Nothing that I did was anything to get real excited about.

This evening I just went for an easy run in order to recover from a mile repeats workout yesterday that was probably a bit too much for me right now.  My legs were a bit sore but they loosened up.  I probably won't get back to too much over 80 miles per week before the half...the priority will be getting in quality days and making sure my body absorbs them.  At this point I can't afford to lose a week due to overtraining, so I've got to be smart and avoid chasing numbers.  

Right when I got back I saw that Saksa ran 3:49 tonight at LAX.  Yeah buddy!

Ran in a light rain.  I went down Shepard Road to the Crosby Farms Woods, ran through the woods for a couple miles, and then came home.  I have a feeling that I'll be doing this run on a regular basis during the summer.  Felt ok, a bit tired from working until 2 AM last night.

I ran the Tiger Trek 5K in Stevens Point as a workout.  My aunt is the race director and this is the last year of the race.  My goal was to 'hard tempo' a time under the course record of 15:40, but I could tell pretty early on that running 15:3X was going to require a harder effort than I wanted to give so I didn't force it.  Ended up running 16:02 and felt alright.  Although this wasn't all out it is a bit daunting to think that in 5 weeks I am hoping to run this pace for a half marathon.  I may have to revise my goals...we'll see.  After I finished I jogged back and ran the last part of the course with Aleta, then I went out and did 3 x 2:00 hard with 2:00 recovery and then a cooldown.  It was a fun morning overall.

Late morning Xavier loop in Appleton.  My car was getting new tires and I had left my running shoes in it, so I had to wear an old, worn out pair that I found in the basement.  It was really humid.  Overall I felt decent.

First long run in a long time and the first time I did one from my new apartment.  I made it almost to downtown St Paul.  This was a run that reminded me that I really love the act of running, not just the competitive aspect of it.  The weather was nice and I felt awesome the entire way.  The last half of the run I felt like I was running on air.  If it hadn't already been 9:40 PM and if I wasn't coming back from injury I would have gone 20+.

Out and back over the Franklin Bridge.  I felt better than I expected to after the long run last night and less than great eating during the day.  The entire time I was running it looked like it was going to start raining but it held off.  I also did a few strides.  Had to hustle afterwards then to get to dinner at the 128 Cafe.

40 minute threshold run

Did this on river road, starting from the usual spot.  I didn't take any intermediate splits but I negative split the second half by about 35 seconds.  Felt pretty strong.  4 x '150' strides afterward...felt good on those too.  One month until the race and I'm feeling a lot better about it than I was two weeks ago.

Easy run on river road and Summit after watching the D3 10Ks.  Emma was All American again, so that's sweet.  Bill Jones took the men's race out super hard but then died with about a mile to go and Easker and Crain had an exciting battle over the last lap.  I felt really good on the run.  Could have gone longer but I took it easy in hopes of another good workout tomorrow.

This was an ok workout.  It was fairly windy, and at 7 PM after a long day/week of work there were a lot of other things I would have rather been doing.  For where I am right now the times are about what I expected, but if I had done this 2 months ago I wouldn't have been happy.  The 800s were the toughest part.  My VO2 definitely took a nosedive during my month off...fortunately I'm trying to get ready for a half marathon and not a 5K.  Legs were pretty dead by the cooldown.  Also, there was a mom and her daughter (who was probably like 6 years old) walking up and down the stairs in the bleachers.  At one point I heard the mom say, 'Each lap around the track is 400 meters, and there are 1200 meters in a mile.'  Seriously?!?

Ran at 7 AM since that was the only time I would have been able to get it in.  Legs did not feel very good, as I expected.  Lots of people on the path for early on a Saturday morning.  Went to La Crosse to watch nationals and had a pretty good time.

Did the same loop that I did last Friday through the Crosby Farms Woods and Hidden Falls.  Felt significantly better than yesterday.  I'm sort of tempted to race tomorrow...don't think I'm going to though.

Late night run after the Pacers/Heat game.  I haven't doubled in awhile or run in the dark in awhile (feels strange to say that after spending 5 months running in the dark nearly every day).  Felt pretty good, but afterwards my achilles wasn't too happy.

Nice evening long run.  Same route as last Monday towards downtown St Paul but I went out a little further this time.  The turn around in the middle of a long out and back is always a little bit daunting.  I felt good the entire time, just a little bit bored towards the end.  The weather's been great for running recently.  Usually it's 90+ degrees on Memorial Day.
35 min elliptical.  Did this instead of running twice.

Ran from Run N Fun with a small group.  We went down to Crosby Farms and then up Randolph.  My legs were tired but I still felt pretty good.  Talked with Nick most of the way.  I also ellipticalled at lunch in order to get in more minutes but save the pounding.  There's supposed to be a big thunderstorm tomorrow evening so it will probably be a challenge to get the workout in.

I thought I was going to be racing against a thunderstorm to get this workout in after work so I did it straight from my office rather than driving to a track, but the storm ended up holding off until about 10:00.  It was probably good to get this in on the roads anyways since that's where I'll be racing next month.  It was really humid; probably good to start acclimating to that as well.  Things went well tonight.  On the third and fifth intervals (very slight net downhill) I basically ran 5:00 miles.  Everything else was around 5:05-5:10.  Legs were tired at the end but I wasn't as trashed as two weeks ago.  Good day.
Short and easy run at lunch.  I'm kind of enjoying taking a really easy day the day after workouts.  I was pretty dang tired when I got up this morning but by the run I felt fine.
I was originally thinking I'd do my main run for the day this morning, but I didn't move fast enough to make that happen.  Had a good 5 miler once I finally got going on it.

Ran after work.  Made a loop going over the Ford bridge, down West River, over the Franklin bridge, and back on East River, then added on a little.  Have to mess around with this one a little bit to get it to be a full 10.  I also did strides.  My legs felt really good tonight but I had some stomach distress.

45 minute threshold run
5 minute rest (walk/jog/stand)
2:30 @ ~5K effort

This went pretty well.  I got to the point where I turned around last Wednesday in a slightly faster time, then negative split the return and kept going to hit 45 minutes.  Pace started around 5:30 and I probably got down to 5:20ish.  My aerobic system was good the whole time but my legs were starting to feel it the last 10 minutes.  Muscular fatigue will probably be my limiting factor in 3 weeks.  The 2:30 interval at the end wasn't as bad as I thought it was going to be.  Legs felt pretty tired the rest of the day, which was spent at work (noon to 10 PM on a Saturday).

Worked 10:30 AM to 10:30 PM, but took a break around 5 to go for a run.  Good thing I did; it helped my sanity levels.  Legs actually felt decent when I expected to feel like garbage after the workout yesterday.  One more long day of work tomorrow, 1000s Tuesday evening, and then 3 days of rest before I see what I've got next Saturday.

Early morning Ford to Franklin, with an add on at the beginning, plus strides.  I was tired this morning.  Running down West River I felt like I was already 6-7 miles into the run when I was really only about 3.  It was a really nice morning though, so an enjoyable run.  Now off to work for 15 hours.
Got home from work at 3 AM last night/this morning.  Slept until just after 10, then did an easy morning run.

My body didn't feel good after a long weekend and then being awake for 21 hours yesterday, and I was kind of dreading working out because I didn't think it would go well.  At about 6:00 I realized that nobody was making me work out today, so I decided I'd just go to Run N Fun and do the group run, then do my workout tomorrow, but when I got to the store I found out the group was going to do 2 mile repeats.  So, I ran with them on their warmup and then ran by myself for another 50 minutes.  Legs felt ok.  I'm glad I just ran easy rather than trying to force a workout.

Celebrated National Running Day on the track at SPA.  I didn't feel great doing this, but I ran at the appropriate effort and the times are about what I expected.  Considering some of the workouts I did at the U this winter I hoped I would be running faster now, but I'll take it for today.  Realistically 31:30ish would be a good performance on Saturday.

Ran along the river during lunch.  It was only like 52 degrees.  The weather has been strange this whole year.  A summer of 70 degree weather would be perfectly fine by me, but I'm sure we will get 90 and humid soon enough.  Felt decent on the run.
Easy pre race run and strides.  Felt alright.  Excited for tomorrow.

Miscellaneous Thoughts/Facts Regarding Today's Race:

� It�s somewhat depressing to think that I ran a time similar to today�s 5 years ago at outdoor conference, and 4 years ago I ran almost a minute and a half faster.
� This is the second time in six months that I�ve raced a 10K off of about five weeks of actual training.  I ran 33:28 at Club Nats in December�considering the difference in terrain the performances are probably about equal, but I ran quite a bit harder in Kentucky.  I�m hoping that I can stay healthy and don�t get the opportunity to try this a third time.
� I forgot to pack a singlet and had to buy one this morning at the expo for $10.  I can no longer make fun of Chris Massey for forgetting his stuff.
� This was the first time I raced against Tyler Morey since high school, and the first time I�ve ever beaten him.
� In 2 weeks in Duluth I am going to have to go out very conservatively.  Last year I got sucked out in about 10:00 for the first two miles.  This year I need to be out no faster than 10:20, and 10:30 might even be better.  It�s going to take one of the better performances of my life for me to crack 1:08 seeing as that's the pace I ran for 10K today, and even splits is the only way I�ll be able to do it.

Ran in the rain.  I was going to do the 10 mile Crosby/Hidden Falls loop but I didn't feel very good and decided at 3 to turn around and do my longer run later.  By the time I got back to my building I was feeling a little better so I kept going for 4 more.
9 PM double to and around the UST stadium.  Felt fine.

Last long run before the 1/2.  Went out and back on East and West River Road.  Weather was pretty nice.  I was kind of expecting to bonk since my body didn't feel that great all day, but I held it together the whole way and felt decently strong.  Made it back in time to see the last pitch of the Brewers game.
Ran with Adrian around Cedar Lake.  Felt a little flat, but not too bad.  Humid.  Conversation made the time pass quickly.  4 strides afterward.

Good workout on tired legs this evening.  I felt like I had a pretty good rhythm going.  Felt pretty strong...had to grind a little the last mile of the second one, but not a blood and guts effort or anything.  It was humid, and there was also some noticeable wind.  The rest was about half jogging, half walking, with a stride thrown in.  This doesn't scream, 'hell yeah, I'm gonna break 1:08', but it at least keeps the possibility in my mind.  Just a couple of tuneups left now.

Splits:
5:08, 5:10, 5:09
5:08, 5:13, 5:10

Easy jog at lunch.  Spent most of it thinking about what race(s) I want to do the rest of the summer and this fall.  Although I feel like I could start running more I'll keep doing these short days after workouts until probably July since it doesn't make sense to increase volume right now.  Felt fine, I didn't get a ton of sleep last night but the sleep that I got was pretty high quality.

Easy morning run.  Last night it was like I slept in a sauna.  Not sure why my bedroom was so warm, but hopefully it cools down.  Legs felt fine this morning.  Car wouldn't start so I had to go get a new battery.
Ran Crosby Farms Woods after work.  Legs felt ok.  I need new shoes.

6 x 2:00 hard (2:00 jog)
4 x 1:00 hard (1:00 jog)

This was a continuous run...no break before or after the fartlek portion.  I ran down to Crosby Farms, did the pickups in the woods, and then ran back to my apartment afterward.  Doing the fast stuff in the woods made me feel like I was running really fast.  Legs felt pretty good, although tired by the end of the cooldown.  It was really humid, definitely lost a lot of fluids on this one.

Got going at 9 AM to beat the heat.  Aleta drove me out the first mile and then I ran Franklin to Ford.  Legs felt tired, might have run a little too hard yesterday.  Spent the rest of the day watching golf.

Out and back on East River.  Kept going straight after Franklin instead of going over the bridge...it gets pretty hilly by the U of M hospital.  Legs were a little sluggish starting out but the last half hour or so felt great.  I'm starting to get more excited for Saturday.
Easy morning run.  Took me forever to get going on it, but felt good.

Shakeout and strides.  Strides felt really good.

US Half Champs Field Stats
� 159 entrants
� 2 Olympians (Meb, Abdi)
� 42 guys with PRs under 1:05, 61 under 1:06, 79 under 1:07, 90 under 1:08, 115 under 1:09, 130 under 1:10
� 25 Minnesotans
� 14 Run N Fun team members
� My 1:09:09 PR seeds me 118th overall, 12th MN, 8th RNF

The depth of the field is incredible.  You can count on the race up front going out very, very fast, which will have ripple effects throughout the field.  Last year I placed 57th out of 99.  Who knows where I'll end up this year, but if I can run smart there should be a lot of people coming back in the second half of the race.

Last tuneup workout.  I rarely do workouts in the morning and I didn't get as much sleep as I should have last night thanks to Ray Allen, so I felt a bit sluggish on the warmup.  The goal on the first four intervals was to start at half marathon pace and gradually speed up.  Mission accomplished.  Felt under control.  I didn't feel very snappy on the 200s, but that's fine.  2 nights of (hopefully) good sleep and 2 easy runs, then it's game time.
Easy run at lunch.  Felt fine, just got a little warm.  Got hit with a 'Run Forrest Run' about 5 miles in.

Ran from the hotel in Duluth.  I did an out and back on the last couple miles of the course, then strides.  Our room doesn't have a window so I woke up and thought it was still the middle of the night because it was so dark, but it was actually 8:45.  Legs felt good this morning.  Race day tomorrow, we'll see what I've got.

Super slow shakeout  run in the arb in Northfield.  It was a little muddy in there, but nothing too bad.  Considering that yesterday I woke up at 3 AM, raced a half marathon, drove 200 miles, and went to a wedding, my legs felt somewhat better than I expected, although I certainly wasn't up to much more than this.

The US 5K this afternoon was won in 14:54 with splits of 5:20, 5:03, 3:55.  I could have been on the pack until the last 3 laps, but then those guys would have put around 45 seconds on me in 1200 meters.  Crazy to think about.
Planned day off.  Can still feel the race in my legs, but I'm bouncing back fine.
Ran in the morning to beat the heat.  I tried to go down to the Crosby Farms Woods, but the trail was closed after this past weekend's storm.  Legs felt ok...got better as the run went on.

Ford to Franklin in the morning.  This loop always seems way longer than 9.  There are tons of branches down in Minnehaha.  Felt ok, haven't adjusted to getting up before 7:00 every day yet.  It's also really humid.

9 x Ford Hill

Legs felt very fresh starting out, so I guess I've come off of the 1/2 just fine.  Felt like I ran these really hard.  Got some 'WTF' looks from people who I would pass on my jog down and then blow by on the next repeat.

Standard post-workout easy day.  Out and back on River Road and Summit.  In two weeks it will be time to start running more on these days.  I got home from work and decided to relax and watch an inning of the Brewers game before heading out.  Unfortunately I ended up seeing the Crew give up 7 runs.  Felt pretty good on the run.  Griff would have been proud of the route as 90% of my steps were on grass.

Starting up the Saturday long run schedule again.  Weather was nice - low 70s and not humid.  I went out East River and then thru and around the U of M campus.  Felt great pretty much the whole time.  This was a little longer than 16 as I was definitely going faster than 6:30s.
Ran south along the river.  Crosby Farms is still flooded.  Legs felt a little tired today.
Morning run on river road.  Felt less than stellar this morning.
Double around O'Shaughnessy Stadium plus strides.
Out and back.  Tired this morning.

Nothing special here, just getting some aerobic power work in.  I haven't done much sub 5:00 pace running since before my achilles injury.  Times were on the slower side of the range, which I'm fine with.  During the rest I would usually jog for 1:10 and then walk the last 30 seconds.  This workout wasn't hard, but I do need to do a better job with sleeping and eating.  It felt pretty warm on the track.  This is my only workout for the week...have to remember that if I hit it too hard now I'll fizzle out before October.
Out and back on Summit.  I think I felt fine, don't really remember much about this run.
Out the door by 5:45 AM for Ford to Franklin.  My legs felt good despite limited sleep.  Drove up to the cabin afterward.

Ran from the cabin to the Plum Lake Library with Aleta biking, then she went in the library and I kept going towards St Germain until it was time to turn around.  I felt good at the start of the run but the last 15 minutes I kind of started running out of gas.  It was hot and humid.  Also did strides.

Ran from the trailhead in downtown Sayner towards Boulder Junction.  I got to somewhere on Trout Lake before it was time to turn around.  First hot long run of the summer...80-85 degrees and very humid.  Fortunately a lot of the run was on paths through the woods.  The only bad stretch was the 2 miles between McKay's and the Crystal Lake campground.  Legs felt good the whole way.  I stopped at McKay's for water on the way back, which helped me finish the run strong.

Instead of running in the morning at the cabin I chose to eat a hot breakfast and watch the Wimbledon final.  The drive back to St Paul then took 6 hours instead of 4 thanks to holiday weekend traffic.  Since I wasn't feeling real peppy after driving I decided to just cut my planned run in half.  Ran on Shepard Road in the rain.
Same out and back that I did last Monday morning.  Legs felt good, and the mid 60s temperature was most welcome.
Double around O'Shaughnessy and strides.  Really hungry by the time I finished.

10 x Ford Hill

I was originally scheduled for a 45 minute threshold run this morning, but at 6:30 the dew point was above 70 so I decided I'll do that tomorrow or Thursday when it's less humid.  The hills this morning were ok.  I was sucking wind by the end, but that's the point.  The humidity didn't really bother me since the hard efforts were pretty short, but I was soaked afterward.  Made it back inside 5-10 minutes before a big rainstorm started.
Decided to run at 10:30 PM and then sleep in tomorrow morning.  There were some interesting characters hanging out on the path.  Legs felt fine.

40 minute threshold run

Felt aerobically strong.  Pace was about 5:40 the whole time, slightly faster towards the end but not much.  Afterwards my legs were tired...it's been quite awhile since I've done back to back workouts like this.  Weather was about as good as it gets this time of year, just lots of mosquitoes.

After doing workouts on back to back days an easy day was in order.  That worked out well anyways since I didn't get out the door until 9 PM.  Coming back down Summit it was getting pretty hard to see.

Ran at 6:30 AM with a group from Mill City Running.  Pretty cool store.  We ran across the Stone Arch Bridge and on some trails I've never been on before.  Pancakes afterward.  Good way to start a Friday.
Franklin to Ford plus some strides and some extra.  Really windy.  I was also rushed in order to go out to eat.

Long run...ran with Adrian for around 11 miles in the middle.  We went down East River and then around Minneapolis.  It was really humid, definitely lost a good amount of weight on this.  Overall I felt a little bit low on energy but I didn't bonk or anything.
Late morning run on Summit.  Felt ok.  Some guy was trying to race me down the hill, which was annoying.

20 min tempo
6 x 30 seconds fast (1 min jog)

This was a moderate workout to prime the legs for Wednesday's 5K...if I race seeing as it's supposed to be 90+ degrees and humid and I'm horrible at running in those conditions.  Legs didn't feel good starting out this morning, but by about halfway through the tempo I was in a decent groove.  The 30s felt really good.
Slow run after work.  Humid, but not oppressively hot.  My legs didn't feel that good.
Felt pretty awful, probably caused by the weather.
Easy run #2 for today.  There was some sort of MDRA fun run taking place on river road.  Legs still felt lousy.  I'm 90% sure that I'm racing tomorrow so hopefully they will come around.
Posted results are pretty far off, though my time seems to be correct as I saw 15:50 on the clock and stopped my watch after the line at 15:54.

I'm going to take one day off each month in order to get some extra recovery and try to avoid burning out.  Given that I raced last night (sort of), the temperature is still in the mid-high 90s, and I'm driving back to Appleton tonight, today was the best candidate for July.
Ran the 5 mile loop that I did frequently in the summers of 2008 - 2010.  Hamstrings were really stiff starting out, and it was humid.

Went out to High Cliff...it's been two years since I've run out there.  Felt ok.  My right hamstring still feels funny so I skipped strides.  It was nice to run on shaded trails by the lake...felt much cooler.

First ever 20 miler.  The weather was great for a long run - 70 and not humid - so I took advantage of it.  Went all the way out the CE Trail to Kaukauna HS, then looped through Combined Locks, and then through Kimberly.  Ran past Paperfest and heard some guy playing a really bad cover of Come Together.  Legs and body in general felt good.  I never really ran out of energy, just got thirsty by the end.

Headed out just before noon after watching the British Open.  Xavier loop.  For the first six or seven miles my right hamstring felt like someone took a baseball bat to it.  Other than that I didn't feel too much residual fatigue from the long run yesterday.  There was some sort of car show going on in Pierce Park.
Easy morning run.  My hamstring still feels tendonitis-y, but it's better than yesterday.  The 68 degree weather was nice.  Crossed paths with Sathre and Peterson.
Ran up Summit.  Felt good for the first 2/3 but towards the end my hips were bothering me.  The burning sensation continued for the rest of the evening.  Hopefully this stuff isn't anything serious.

45 minute threshold run

My legs were tired and stiff on the warmup, but the workout went well.  Pace was a little slower...between 5:30 and 5:40 most of the way with the last mile under 5:30.  Nice cool, dry weather...MUCH better than last week.

Ran in Crosby Farms Woods.  I felt good energy wise but I had some pain at the insertion point of my right hamstring for the first half of the run.  The Houston Marathon posted qualifying standards for next year's US Half Champs.  They're pretty much the same as what Grandma's did the past two years.  Looks like it should be a go.
Easy morning run.  Right leg is better than yesterday but still not pain free.

Worked out with Adrian at Washburn HS.  There was lacrosse going on on the field but fortunately nobody kicked us off.  I felt good.  90 seconds is a lot of rest for 400s so this wasn't all that hard.  We usually jogged slowly for 1:10-1:15 and then took a few seconds to catch our breath before starting the next one.  Good workout.
Easy run from Mill City Running.  Spent the first half talking with AC and the second half talking with Reichenbach.  Good pancakes afterward with Tumnus.

Second 5 mile run of the day.  I believe this is the first time I've ever done this double.  Unfortunately my hamstring hurt so I wasn't able to enjoy the nice evening as much as I would have otherwise.
Late morning run down Minnehaha and around Nokomis.  Nice to get a change of scenery.  Temperature was in the low 60s and it was lightly raining.  Felt like cross country.
Snuck out for a second run at about 6:00.  It was raining.  Broke in a new pair of shoes, and also did strides.

Another good long run.  Started at about 11:30 after sleeping in and then putzing around for a little while.  I did Franklin to Ford, then turned around and did Ford to Franklin.  I'm not really sure why I did this, but I couldn't think of any other route to do.  Felt strong the entire way, and loved the 60 degree weather.  This was my first Monday - Sunday 100 mile week in 11 months.
Crosby Farms Woods.  I felt like a sack of garbage for most of the run.  Hopefully I can recover for a workout tomorrow.
Easy run in a light rain.  My hip and hamstring were tight for the first half, and I was tired, but still a good run.

Had a good workout tonight at Macalester.  Matt Haugen was out there coaching some people and he gave me some encouragement throughout.  The first one I somehow started off with a 78, then I found the pace.  Considering how lousy I felt yesterday and this morning I felt surprisingly strong while running this.  I can confidently say that I'm in the best shape I've ever been in at the end of a July.

Was planning on going for a 7 miler but my hamstring was really bothering me starting out.  When it hadn't gotten better by the time I got to St Thomas I decided to just turn around and go home.  Hopefully things are better tomorrow.

Hip and hamstring were still a little sore walking around today.  After going back and forth several times over the course of the day thinking about what type of run I should do I decided that if I had a coach they would probably tell me to take the day off, so that's what I did.
Flapjack 5 mile from Mill City Running.  My right leg feels much better.  My body in general is really tired from poor sleep this week.
Ford to Franklin.  Hamstring tendons were more irritated tonight, maybe from the morning run.
Ran around Calhoun and Isles with Pez.  Ben Jacobs bumped into us for a mile or so.  Good run with good conversation.  We were  sub 6:30 pace for most of it.  Leg felt pretty good.

5 mile warmup
38 minute threshold run
4 x 30 seconds fast (1 minute jog)
Cooldown

I did a long out and back on Shepard Road towards downtown St Paul.  The threshold was pretty hilly, which I suppose is good practice both for next weekend's 15K and for racing up Summit in two months.  16:30 for the first three miles, 16:17 for the next three, probably about the same pace for the last few minutes.  A two hour nap this afternoon recharged my batteries a little bit but I still felt tired.  Not sure when I'll be able to catch up on sleep though, lots going on right now.

Strange how running works...I started this run at 9:30 PM and figured I wouldn't feel good since I was hungry, did a long workout yesterday, and had been tired all day.  Instead I felt great.  Went out and back over the Franklin bridge.
Morning slog.  Tired.  Drove back to Appleton afterward.

After spending some time with Uncle Kress at the hospital I went out to High Cliff to run.  This loop is somewhere between 10.5 and 11 miles but I'll log it as 10 since I've done some rounding up recently.  Since I was a little pressed for time I ran low six minute pace the whole way.  The footing was pretty bad for a lot of the run but I felt decent.

Kind of a rough one this morning.  On the warmup I was feeling a little tired, but that's pretty normal so I didn't worry about it.  My hamstring was bothering me to the point where I couldn't do any strides.  At least I can directly attribute that to taking a bad step yesterday at High Cliff, so it should get better before too long.  Before the end of the first mile of the 2 mile I knew this was going to be a grind.  My body was just really tired overall and didn't have much fight.  Not too surprising given my schedule the past week or so.  That said, I'll take 5 miles at 5:08 average pace on a day where I felt terrible.

I decided to still double back this evening and then I'll take tomorrow really easy to get some recovery in.  Just went out and back on Shepard Road.  The last two miles I started getting really hungry.  All that I had eaten in the previous nine hours was a Clif Bar, so that makes sense.
Easy run on Shepard Road.  Felt pretty beat, as I expected.
Ran from work at lunch for the first time since before Grandma's.  I set my alarm for the Flapjack Five but ended up going back to sleep for 2 more hours.
Crosby Farms Woods after work.  Legs are feeling a little better, but still pretty dead.  Hopefully with 36 more hours I'll feel alright on Sunday.

Ran through Minnehaha Park.  I got a little lost on my way back so ended up adding an extra mile or so.  Felt about the same...legs still tired, hamstring and hip still sore.  We'll see how tomorrow goes.
Did not feel good this morning.  The best part of this run was when it ended.
Ran west on river road.  Felt much better than I did this morning.  On my way back just after the Lake St bridge I crossed paths with arguably the most attractive female runner that I've ever seen.
Lilydale from Run N Fun with a solid crew.  I didn't feel all that chipper but the company kept my mind off that.  Hamstring hurt during strides afterward.

I skipped doing a real morning run in favor of getting more sleep and instead just did a shakeout at lunch.  The workout didn't go particularly well.  Wasn't a total train wreck, but I am faster than this.  The last 2 miles were pretty much a grind, and doing a 5th was out of the question.  I really haven't felt good for two weeks now, and other than Saturday night my sleep has been good since last Wednesday night.  My iron levels must be low.
Easy run from work at the end of the day.  I was planning to go at lunch but wasn't able to, then decided to still run from my office for a change of scenery.  Pretty good run.

Fell back asleep after my alarm so I didn't make it to Mill City Running for the Flapjack Five.  Not too disappointed, as this way I didn't have to discuss the 15K with everyone there, I had a good run by myself on the river road, and now I only have to go 5 or 6 tonight.
Out and back six, with 6 x 0:30 strides in the middle.  Felt ok.

I ran 8 miles on Summit, came back inside to enter a Streak For The Cash pick, then went back out and ran the Crosby Farms loop for another 10.  This was a pretty tough run...I felt awful from about miles 2-4, then got in a groove for a while, then the last 3 miles or so I was feeling weak.  Made it pretty tough on myself by starting at 1:00.  I'm glad I got this in as it had been a few weeks since my last 18er.
Ran around while watching Aleta's triathlon.  Legs didn't feel very good after an 18 miler yesterday and 4 hours of sleep last night.
Franklin to Ford.  Legs felt sluggish.
Run and strides.  Strides felt great.  Workout tomorrow morning...what I actually do will depend on how hot it is.  Supposed to be a scorcher.

15 min/12 min/13 min @ tempo (3 min rests)

Super hot and humid this morning, but despite that I still wanted to get 40-45 minutes total of tempo running in.  I didn't pre-plan exactly where the breaks would be but just took them when they were needed.  My breathing was fine, legs still don't feel that good.  Hopefully a faster workout later this week will help.  I've also only been on increased iron for 5 days and it takes a little longer to really start helping.  My average pace was somewhere in the low 5:20s...not bad all things considered, but still slower than I would like to run for the 25K.  We'll see.  Cooldown was super short...not much to be gained from shuffling along at 10 minute mile pace.
Did an easy shakeout to get some blood flowing and so that I could just do singles both tomorrow and Friday.  Legs felt dead.  Stretched and elevated afterward.

Easy day.  It took me awhile to get going this morning.  It's still really humid, and the forecast for pretty much all of the next 2 weeks looks terrible.  Nice to be done running for the day at 8:30 AM.
Morning run.  The humidity has broken...it'll be back tomorrow though.

I feel pretty good about this one.  The temperature was in the mid 80s, but the path where I did this has a decent amount of shade and with a dewpoint of around 50 it didn't feel too bad.  I'm not sure exactly what my pace was, but definitely sub 5:00.  I felt stronger than I did Tuesday or last week.  It was good that I only had 4 intervals on the table as I think I would have had to dig for a 5th.  The 4 x 30 seconds felt good.  Short cooldown, then dinner at Cheesecake Factory.
Easy run on River Road.  Legs felt pretty dead.  Crossed paths with Mortenson and he looked like he was cruising.

'Long' run in Grand Forks, ND.  I ran from Riverside Park on the trail that Devin recommended.  Plan was to go 18, but after feeling like crap the first 45 minutes I decided I'd cut it short.  By the time I got to 75-80 minutes I wasn't feeling terrible anymore but I was still content with stopping at 90.  I started the run at 7:45 AM but it was still super humid and by the end it was starting to get warm.  When I stopped my shorts and thighs were covered in white foam.

Easy run from the hotel in Grand Forks.  I just did an out and back on University Ave.  Actually didn't feel too bad.  Now I'm back in St Paul, where the heat index is above 100.  I think I'll skip the second run.

When I first set up this cycle one of my main goals was to run really fast at Victory next Monday.  Last night I came to my senses (I think) and realized that PRing in the 10K when I've felt like ass for the majority of the past month and immediately after two weeks of 90+ degree weather is not realistic.  

New plan: taking today off and just doing one easy run tomorrow.  This will bring an end to a nice down 'week' (~60 miles in 7 days), and should get me back to feeling more normal.  On Wednesday I'll start getting back into a more regular training routine.  I'm not sure if I will do City of Lakes or not...right now I'm leaning towards just doing a couple of smaller races in September and putting all my eggs in the TC10 basket.

Ford to Franklin.  Already super humid at 7 AM.  I felt good for the first couple of miles, then sluggish for the last half.  Saw Mortenson, Carrie Tollefson, and Lance running 1000s on river road.  I can't imagine doing a workout today.
Crosby Farms Woods.  Sweat like crazy again.  I like running down there.
Shakeout and 3 strides in the dark.  My hamstring did not enjoy this.

4 mile tempo (21:10)
5 min jog
5 x Ford Hill

On the tempo I felt like I imagine Tony Hoff felt during my freshman year.  I was breathing pretty easily but my legs were just super sluggish.  After this I had low expectations for the hills and kind of expected that I'd do 1 or 2 and then have to pull the plug, but they went surprisingly well.  Cooldown ended up being a little longer than planned since I bumped into Kelly and decided to run with him for a little while.  Dew point of 72 still.
Franklin to Ford after work.  My legs actually didn't feel terrible today.

Ran in the arb in Northfield.  It's always great to run in there again.  They've cut down a bunch of trees towards the back (although the last time I ran back there was last November so for all I know this could have been done months ago).  My legs felt the best they have in all of the month of August.  Unfortunately I started the run a bit later than I had hoped to so by the end it was getting pretty warm.  I stopped at the Carleton gym to get some water and got some strange looks from some of the people there for a volleyball tournament.  I also bumped into Paul Thornton and his daughter about 30 minutes into my run.  Didn't recognize who they were until Paul talked to me.

Also, for any St Olaf people that read this, I'm racing alumni next weekend.

Ran an out and back thru the arb and on Canada from Aleta's parents' house.  Saw Thunder and Merrell driving home from church about a minute into the run.  Felt alright.  It's going to be 57 degrees at 8 AM tomorrow so I kind of wish I was racing, but it wasn't in the cards this year.
Ran the Crosby Farms loop with an add-on on Shepard Road.  I felt strong and the weather was great (temps in the 60s!).  There's a good chance that this run was actually 12.5-13 miles.
Shakeout and strides.  Hamstring bothered me during strides.
Shakeout before tonight's workout.  I was too slow in getting going this morning.  52 degrees outside, basically half of what it was last Tuesday.

I'm pretty happy with this workout.  The past couple days I've felt like I am bouncing back, and this confirms that I am.  Legs were somewhat lacking in turnover and felt a little flat, but with 99 miles in the past seven days (whoops) there's no mystery as to why.  Breathing wise I felt great the entire time.  Avoided really killing the 150s in order to protect my hamstring.
Ran down Minnehaha Parkway towards Nokomis.  I was pretty beat from yesterday's workout.  My hamstring was really sore so next week I probably won't do 150s.

Easy 10 on river road.  My schedule had an optional 25 minute sub-tempo but seeing as I worked out hard 36 hours ago and am racing in 48 hours I opted to just run steady.  Legs felt better than yesterday.  Saw Jon Peterson, Elizabeth Yetzer, Ladia, and Kampf at various points.

Easy double.  The days are definitely getting shorter...I started this run just before 8:00 and it was already dark.  In less than two months I'll be running in the dark every day.  Depressing to think about.

Ran and did some strides at lunch.  It was warm.  Felt just ok.

E-mail from Griff at 1 PM regarding alumni: 'The weather forecast suggests that it will not be a great day to race.  Oles will be instructed to be cautious and save the real racing for a later date.  Guess how that will go.'

Started the day pretty slowly and it was a couple of hours before I was ready to go for a run.  I went down East River, through the U of M and across the river on a bridge by the heating plant, then down West River to the Stone Arch Bridge, and a little bit past the Stone Arch Apartments before it was time to turn around.  Felt pretty good.  I negative split by like 2.5 minutes despite the way back being net uphill by a good bit.  This was a good effort.
I was really tired this morning and my legs felt dead from this weekend's running.  Glad to be done for the day, especially since it's going to be about 100 later.
I was asleep by 11:00 last night.  Felt rested this morning because of it.

Lilydale with Run N Fun, then some extra at the end.  We had a few pace pushers tonight but at least nobody started throwing down sub 6:00s.  I felt ok.  Did strides and my hamstring didn't bother me as much as it did last week.

Workout Wednesday.  St Thomas/River Road would have been the ideal place to do this but UST had a stage and a bunch of other stuff set up on the homestretch.  Didn't realize this until after my warmup, so I jumped in my car and quickly drove to SPA.  Did the tempo around the surrounding blocks.  It felt good and I think I hit it pretty solid.  Changed shoes and got on the track for the 800s.  These weren't real hard but I didn't feel much zip and couldn't seem to get going.  My first lap was always a 75.  By the end it was dark out; I need to get going earlier on workout days.  Also, I didn't feel anything in my hamstring from Saturday - Monday, but it decided to make itself known again tonight.

Got out after work in time to run the Crosby Farms loop before it got too dark.  It's finally starting to feel somewhat like fall outside.  Legs felt much better than they did after last week's workout.
Nice little run and six strides during lunch.  Felt ok; a little tired but that's fine.  Kind of excited to see what I can do tomorrow.

Franklin to Ford at about 10 AM.  I felt like I was kind of hung over after staying up to watch the Badgers lose last night.  Legs felt ok though.

I decided I'm going to race in the St Olaf Invite next weekend with the Run N Fun guys.  I figure it's either race or do a workout, and racing would be more fun.  We'll see how this goes; I've only really raced well on that course once and that was in 2007.
Ran again at 5:30.  Felt ok, but a bit tired.  Need to sleep well tonight.

Ran over the Stone Arch Bridge and then flipped a couple minutes later.  Cruised 6:40 pace the entire time and after the first mile I felt quite good.  Saw Matt and Tina walking their dog.  I think this winter I'd like to get to the point where I'm doing 1:30-1:40 mid-week and then 2:00-2:15 on the weekend on a regular basis.
Had to rush a bit to get this in between work and a dinner with friends.  Legs felt a little tired.  It was misting for most of the run.
Shakeout.  Didn't feel very good, going to have to eat quite a bit today.

Did this on the path downtown by my office.  Really humid for a mid-September evening.  I didn't feel exceptional tonight, but this was a good bit better than the mile repeats workout that I did a month ago.  On the third one my watch fell off and I went back for it; probably would have been in the low 4:50s if that hadn't happened.  The last half of the last one I was getting tired.  Could feel my strained hamstring at various points.  I should be able to run on this thing for 2 1/2 more weeks since I've been running on it for basically 2 months already and it only bothers me when I run faster than about 5K pace.  I might have to adjust a few sharpening workouts though.
It's like a 70 degree steam room outside.
Franklin to Ford.  Was debating between doing 8 and 9 and decided to just do the whole loop.  Felt a little tired, but tomorrow's an easy day so I'll be good for the race.

Easy run and strides at lunch.  Let's represent well tomorrow.

Just found out that the USATFMN cross country race is on November 3rd now instead of November 16th.  That doesn't work nearly as well with my planned schedule, but if I want to go to Club Nats on the A team (which I do) then I have to run well in this.  I'll figure it out.

St Olaf Invite.  Continued my habit of sucking ass every time I run in a meet that the St Olaf team is at.  I wore Matumbos and they are so thin on the bottom that after running over all of the gravel in the first mile my feet killed for the rest of the race.  Every step from miles 2-5 was painful.  Only 5 of our 7 guys showed up to race so I had to finish in order for us to get a team score; otherwise I probably would have dropped out.  I can't believe I lost to some of the people that beat me.  I'm glad I did that 10K last weekend so I at least got one good effort in before TC10.
