What happens in 2 weeks will pretty much entirely determine whether this cycle was a success or a bust.  So far very little of it has been positive.

Didn't really feel like running today...kind of demoralized after yesterday.  My body also didn't feel great after getting last night's sleep in two four hour chunks with an airport dropoff in the middle.  The situation required it though.  I finally got out after the football games ended and did an out and back on Summit.  I'll get it together and go long tomorrow.

This entire run was done in the dark.  Ran out and back towards downtown St Paul.  I decided before the run to just do 15 instead of the planned 17-18 since I felt like I had a cold coming on.  I got through the run fine, but seeing as I felt a good bit worse the next day running even this far was a questionable decision.
Just took it easy since I've got a pretty decent cold.  Strangely enough I felt better when I was running than I did at any other point during the day.

2 x 6 x 1:00 (1:00 jog between reps, 3:00 jog between sets)

I did this on the Franklin to Ford loop.  Felt pretty dang flat for most of this, but with a lingering cold (although I'm through the worst of it now) and after three straight days of nothing but slow running I suppose that's expected.  This winter I should be able to get back the pop that I had six months ago.  That said I felt like I ran these alright...probably averaged like 68-69 second 400 pace.  Right when I got home my phone rang with the news that Aleta's grandma had passed away.
This was as close as I get to 'junk miles'.  Just plodded along.

I was going to do this on the track, but with the weather (80s and really windy) and my cold I decided to do it on the river road and focus more on effort than time.  Since I'm racing on the roads it's probably better to do the workout there anyways.  This felt pretty hard.  Didn't feel like the sickness slowed me down too much but I was sucking some wind at the end of each interval.  This is the last hard workout I'll do until sometime in November.

Ran on the treadmill since it was raining pretty hard and I had to get the run in before going to Letich's wedding.  Legs felt tired from yesterday.  Got bored halfway through.  Before too long it'll be time to start getting used to that thing again...

Bummed around for most of the afternoon and then ran at about 5:30.  Crosby Farms loop.  Felt freaking terrible for most of the run.  

While I was out there I thought about how this fall kind of parallels my sophomore year outdoor track season...several weeks of mediocre workouts and runs that didn't feel that great, just feeling tired mentally, and even making a rookie mistake at a tuneup race (at the 2008 Carleton Relays I forgot to put my singlet on after my warmup and had to run across the infield right before my 5K started to get it, this year I wore bad spikes at Olaf).  Things came around the last week of that season and at outdoor conference I hit a big PR in the 10K, beat some people I had never beaten before, and scored for the team.  Maybe I can pull off something similar next Sunday.

4.5 miles easy
4.5 miles sub-tempo
4 x Ford Hill
Cooldown

Wanted to get a light workout in.  I ran Ford to Franklin and after crossing the Franklin bridge I ran the rest of the loop at sub-tempo.  Felt pretty smooth.  Jogged to the Ford Hill and did a couple repeats.  Those felt alright.  A guy was just standing next to the sidewalk the entire time holding a vodka bottle...he was kind of starting to creep me out.  I'm still a little under the weather, but I've got until Sunday to get to 100%.
From Run N Fun with like 8 guys.  Down to the river and back on Summit.  We started off with a 7:50 first mile (granted it was pretty much all uphill) and then picked it up.  I felt ok.
Didn't feel very good this morning, needed more sleep last night.

Ran 2 miles on the treadmill and then did strides down the hallway of my building, all in flats to break them in a bit.  There was a big thunderstorm going on, couldn't go outside.  Legs felt alright.

Terrible workout on the Mac track this morning.  The assignment was 5 x 800 @ 2:30ish and I expected to basically breeze through it.  Instead I struggled from the get go and didn't hit the time on a single one.  Felt like crap across the board...no aerobic strength, pace felt fast, form felt sloppy, hamstring hurt, coughing.  The challenge now is to not defeat myself mentally before Sunday's race.

Running.  Went out planning on 7, but ended up turning around early because I'm in a 'less is more' mindset right now.  Legs still felt a little flat, but I got a good night's sleep last night and if I can do that again tonight I should feel better tomorrow.  It's pretty windy and there are thunderstorms on the way...it must be a Twin Cities tradition to have crappy weather on marathon weekend.

Went to the Eau Claire meet in the afternoon.  The boys sent a message to the rest of the MIAC today.  La Crosse was only 26 points ahead.  A trophy is attainable.

One last easy run for this cycle.  Pretty much the same out and back on river road towards my old place that I did yesterday.  Legs actually felt ok for this one, kind of surprised since I slept lousy.  Strides afterward and those were alright.  Felt the hamstring but hopefully with some adrenaline it won't be an issue tomorrow.  Forecast looks good for the race.  Time to see what happens.

First day of rest.  My legs aren't sore from yesterday, I just have the same general fatigue that I've had for awhile.  I'm not sure exactly how long I'll take off...could be anywhere from 4 days to 2 weeks.
Rest.  It's kind of nice to not run...definitely frees up my evenings.

Rest.  The past couple days I've felt almost constantly hungry but most food doesn't really sound that good.  I'll have to figure that one out since I need to put back on a couple of pounds that I've lost.

Sketched out some training for the next couple months.  I'm going to use the period between now and Club Nats as a base phase with the main focuses being on building strength and getting in some good threshold work.  I won't be as sharp for that race as some of the other guys who are really focusing on it, but since it's almost a certainty that I'll be on the B team that's fine.
Rest.  I haven't been sleeping all that well this week without exercising.

Rest day #5.  Today my body feels better than it has in a long time.  There's a good chance I'll go for a run tomorrow.  Also, the last time I took 5 consecutive days off from exercising was 2 1/2 years ago.  Addiction?  Yeah.

Nick drove over to St Paul and we did a Ford to Lake St loop from my place.  It was a nice morning for a run and it felt good to get out there again.  I'll probably run pretty much every day from here, but no hard training until November.  It also sounds like the Club Nats roster is already set.  A 'race off' at the state race in a couple of weeks would have been nice, but I'm also ok with it not happening.

Went out at about 5 and did the Crosby Farms loop.  This was a little farther than I had originally planned on running today, but it was a super nice day and I can't run this loop during the week anymore because it gets dark too early.  After a shaky first 3 miles I felt good the rest of the time.  Watching Chicago this morning was really motivating...lots of impressive performances.  Wish I could have been down there.

Goal for next week: ~50 miles in six days and hopefully some strides.

Ran at lunch from my office.  Felt good.  Cloudy, but in the low 50s which is perfect.  Did three really light strides afterward (the first one honestly was barely faster than the run, the next two were at probably 5:00 pace) and didn't feel anything in my hamstring.  Later this week I'll try another short set, slightly faster.

The original plan was to go to Run N Fun this evening, but some stuff came up and I didn't get there.  Although it would have been nice to run with the team, it's not that big of a deal as I probably didn't need a 10 mile run tonight.  Instead I did the same Lake St Bridge loop that Nick and I did on Saturday.  Ran in half tights for the first time ever.  No strong opinion one way or the other.

At the start of the week I was planning on taking today off to go out to dinner with my brother for his birthday, but he cancelled so I decided to run.  Easy six on Shepard in the dark.  My hamstring was uncomfortable for a good portion of the run.  This is annoying; it's been 3 months.  Still a decent run though.
Out and back on river road.  It was lightly raining for pretty much the whole run.  My nipples got chafed.  Hamstring felt better than yesterday.  Felt good in general.

Ran to Lake Nokomis.  I got home from work just in time to get the entire run in before it got dark.  Nice fall weather, it's Friday, I got my acceptance letter for Houston this afternoon, and I get to watch the boys race at Drews tomorrow.  Life is good.

Drove some Run N Fun guys down to La Crosse for Jim Drews.  Before the race I ran the course...first 3 miles with the RNF team on their warmup then the last 2 with Perry.  Didn't feel that good, as I expected after 2 nights of 5 hours of sleep and right after a 2.5 hour drive.  St Olaf absolutely killed it this morning.  In my 4 years on the team we didn't have a single person break 25:30 on this course; today we had 5.  Average time 25:13 and only a 35 second spread off of one of the top 3-5 runners in D3.  Best news of all was the team score...Olaf 41 La Crosse 96.  Took it to 'em on their home course.  I didn't think I'd being saying it this year, but this team has a legitimate shot at winning nationals.  Most of the Run N Fun guys ran well too.  Great morning of cross country.
Turned around early because I felt crappy, then at the end I decided to just do two more miles and finish the 10.  Eating and sleeping were not good this weekend; got to get back on track.

Ran down East River and thru the U of M campus.  Felt great the whole time although by the end my hips were getting a little sore.  It's been a long time since I've run more than 10 miles continuously.  After watching exciting races the past three weekends I'm really motivated; have to stick to my 'slow and steady' plan though or I'll just end up right back where I was.

Run N Fun.  We did a loop that went down Randolph to river road, then back to the store via Shepard and West 7th.  I didn't like the route very much as I run in this area frequently enough on my own.  I ended up doing most of the run with Dohm, Chili, and Andy Siegel after Kieser and some others took off on a fartlek and Choker one stepped away from us.  Felt ok but by the end of the run I was ready to stop.
First time running before work in 3 weeks.  It was somewhat cold this morning, but still an enjoyable run.

Plan was to do 2 sets of 6 x 200 @ 35ish in order to get the legs going again.  I did one set and then my hamstring tightened up so I stopped.  Frustrating, but I don't want to end up with another injury that requires time of.  I'll probably do something like this again next week, and hopefully it will be a little bit warmer.

I decided last night that I would take today off, and in somewhat surprising fashion I stuck to it.  Biked four miles to get some blood flowing, then did general strength, sticked, and iced.  My first mile of the bike was 4:12, then I decided to speed up a little bit and see if I could break the world record in the 5K.  Ended up finishing it in 12:11.  My pulse was barely over 100.  Meanwhile some guy came and sat on the bike next to me.  I saw him look over at my resistance and RPMs and then try to do the same thing.  He made it about 2 minutes and then started slowing down.

I ran my Crosby Farms loop in reverse, going through the woods while it was still light out and then coming back on Shepard in the dark.  Felt really good...probably the best run I've had since Labor Day and one of my top 3 since about mid July.  Great weather too - 58 degrees.

4 x 4:00 @ Tempo (1:00 int)
4 x 100m Strides

First workout in a couple of weeks.  Did it along West River.  It was windy, but whatever.  I wanted something really easy, and I knew that my tendency would be to run too hard, so I made sure to keep it real relaxed.  The tempo intervals felt pretty good.  Strides didn't go so well.  My hamstring isn't much better than it was before TC10.  I don't feel it at all while doing normal running, but it's an issue doing anything faster than 5:00 pace.  I've been spending a decent amount of time working on it for 10 days now (after mostly letting it be for 2+ months).  If it doesn't improve after another week I'll probably go see somebody about it.

Up at sunrise to run with Dan.  We went down through Crosby Farms and then looped over towards his place.  I felt alrght; legs were a little tired.  We ran a bit faster than I usually do but that was probably good for me.  2.5 hour nap in the afternoon.

I got to work early this morning so that I could leave in time to get the whole run done before it got dark.  Glad I did this, as starting next week I'll be running in the dark in the evenings no matter what time I get home.  Went over the Stone Arch Bridge and turned around when I got under the Hennepin bridge.  I felt a little tired, but overall pretty good.  The first couple of miles I thought about what the results might look like if there was a MIAC alumni race at Como.  Settled on the below list for a possible top 10, assuming everyone showed up with roughly their average fitness from this year and had a reasonably good day.

1. Ben Sathre
2. Devin Monson
3. Malcolm Richards
4. Dan Greeno
5. Chris Erichsen
6. Dustin Franta
7. Kelly Fermoyle
8. Joe Sepe
9. Jake Marotz
10. Jack Delehanty (wasn't sure if I should include you since you didn't run CC in college, but decided to since if this race existed I assume you'd do it)

Decided to just run from my apartment rather than going to Run N Fun.  Went out and back on Shepard.  Legs felt less tired than yesterday, which is strange.  Instead of doing traditional strides I inserted 5 x 15 second pick ups in the last mile.  My hamstring eemed to tolerate these better.
Easy shakeout jog during lunch.  I did not sleep well last night.

8 x Ford Hill

Did tonight's run in a light rain and a pretty dense fog.  It felt like my legs weren't strong enough neuromuscularly to make this challenging aerobically.  Hopefully I can get my hamstring healed up so that I can do more faster running and fix that.  That said, I don't need to be doing hard workouts right now...steady progression is the name of the game.
Ran on river road.  Legs felt good.  Happy Halloween.

'Farewell to daylight' run before daylight savings time ends this weekend.  Starting next week I'll be running in the dark after work for 18 weeks.  I'm already kind of depressed about it.  Anyways, tonight I did the Crosby Farms loop in reverse, just like last Friday.  Added on a little bit and then ended the run at Lund's to buy some bagels.  Legs felt good, I was cruising for awhile.

5 x Mile Cruise Intervals 
5:21, 5:19, 5:20, 5:23, 5:21 (1 minute rest)

Did this on the Mac track because I wanted to get an accurate measure of where I am right now.  The temperature was nice but it was pretty windy.  This wasn't too hard, but I did not feel real strong or fit (which figures, because I'm not real fit right now).  Still an ok starting point.  Cruise intervals have traditionally been something I've responded well to.

MIACs this afternoon.  The Big O went 1-2-3-6-8-10, with Calvin sitting out.  We would have beaten the rest of the conference 20-36 in a dual meet.  Bring it on NCC.

Ran at about 11:30 after watching NYC.  Franklin to Ford.  It was insanely windy - gusts up to 40 mph.  My hamstring was alright but I could feel it.  The workout yesterday followed by sprinting around the course may have been a little much. 

Decided to pass on a second run.  My goal at the start of this week was to hit 80, but I think doubling today would have been forcing things.  I suppose there's not much of a difference between 78 and 80, but it's those 'extra' miles that put you over the top in a race (to a point, obviously).

Ran through the U of M, crossed the river, and then ran down West River on the Minneapolis side for awhile before turning around.  Felt pretty decent.  I don't know if I'll keep doing Monday long runs though...doing a long run entirely in the dark was not very fun.  Made it back in time for the start of the Packer game.

My options today were to run in fairly nice weather at noon by myself or in rain/snow this evening with the Run N Fun guys.  I opted for the conditions over the camaraderie.  Unfortunately the trail I usually run on from my office is closed after about two miles.  Hopefully it will be open before too long; otherwise I don't think I'll be doing too many regular length runs during lunch.  My legs felt pretty sluggish.  I didn't sleep well last night and was awake for awhile around 3 or 4 AM, so not good recovery from yesterday's long run.  I should feel better tomorrow.  5 x 15 second strides during the last mile.

26 min tempo
4 x 30 sec fast (1 min jog)

Ah yes, the first of probably 20 or so workouts that will be done completely in the dark.  I felt really good tonight.  The tempo was not extraordinarily fast, but the effort was in the correct zone.  A few more of these and I'll have my strength back.  I was really surprised by the 4 x 30 seconds...I wasn't even sure if I should attempt them but then I had basically no hamstring pain.  Good night.

Morning run before PT.  I woke up when Aleta got up at 4:15 and then never got back to sleep, so it's going to be a long day.  The PT appointment was kind of a waste of my time, but next week I should get more out of it.  If not I'll just cancel my other appointments.
Easy out and back on Shepard before going to the Highland Grill.

Ran in the morning because of the Gophers game tonight.  Unfortunately I got out the door about 30 minutes later than I wanted to, and then I was already in the shower when I realized I had forgotten to do strides.  The run felt good though.

8 x Lock & Dam Hill

This hill is both longer and steeper than the Ford Hill.  I felt decent, although my legs were definitely burning the last couple reps.  At the start of each of the last two I just said to myself, 'This will make me stronger.'  It was extremely windy this morning, but that wasn't really an issue for the workout.

Lake St to Ford loop (plus an extra half mile) after the 2nd wave of football games ended.  West River Road is not very well lit.  My legs felt tired sitting around this afternoon, but I actually felt pretty decent on the run.  Glad I got it in.

I thought I was going to be able to go for a run this afternoon on some trails in Carver, but it turned out that I was given incorrect information about the day's schedule.  Ended up running at about 8 PM on river road.  My stomach was a little off from eating a large, heavy meal earlier, but my legs felt good.  Just wish I would have gotten this in during daylight.

10 x 3:00 Cruise Intervals (1:00 jog)
3 x 30 seconds faster (1:00 jog)

It was pretty cold tonight - 20 degrees with a wind chill of around 10.  Felt pretty good during the workout.  The first half when I was going into the wind I was going a little slower, but the last couple intervals with the wind at my back I got some good work in.
From Run N Fun with a group of about 10.  Classic Highland to River Road to Summit loop.  I felt really tired most of the day, but felt good on the run.  Plum's afterward.

When I started this run I wasn't too confident in my ability to finish it, so since I didn't want to bonk and then still be 5 miles away from my apartment I decided to piece together a run with a couple of shorter routes.  I did 9 miles on Shepard, then a Ford to Lake St loop, then added on Shepard to finish it.  The last 10 miles I actually ended up feeling real solid.  It was nice to have the weather back in the 40s.
Easy run on Shepard.  Really hungry by the end.  Also did 4 strides and they felt practically normal.  It's about time.

Ford to Lake St tempo (~5.5 miles, untimed)
75 seconds at ~3K effort
4 x 100m strides

This went well.  I felt strong; I think I'm more fit right now than I thought I would be a couple of weeks ago.  Ran in half tights and a t shirt...pretty nice after having temperatures around 10 earlier this week.  I realized as I was crossing the Lake St bridge that this loop is basically the Get In Gear course minus the first and last little bit.  On the stretch of East River Road between St Thomas and my apartment I had some flashbacks to duking it out with Phil a year and a half ago.  Good times.

I got down to Olaf at about 9:30, parked at Buntrock, and went for an Iron Bridge run before the meet.  Pretty good run other than being stopped by a 5 minute long train on the way back.  While I was waiting Alex Phearman, Nibs, and Mike Roth showed up, so I ran the last mile with those guys.

Sprinting around the course during the regionals races.  I swear it's almost as hard to watch these races as it is to run in them.  The guys ran well...all 7 in the top 25.  Grant spotted Horton an 11 second lead at 5K and wasn't able to close it all the way, but he'll get him next week.  The course ran super fast.  After today I think we're in a group of 4-5 teams that all have a good shot at 2nd next week.  It'll take a miracle to take down NCC.  The girls took 3rd so they'll make it as well.  Another good day to be an Ole.
Evening run on Shepard.  My legs were pretty tired by the time I got to this one.  I also ate Taco Bell about 2 hours before, but my stomach actually wasn't that bad.
Ran at 1 PM.  Crosby Farms.  I felt pretty beat from yesterday, but I'm glad I got a run like this in.  Happy with these past two weeks, now time for a down week.
Lake St to Ford.  It took me awhile to get going.  Need to speed that process up.

9 x Ford Hill

It was only about 30 degrees this evening, but basically no wind.  Compared to the hills that I did last weekend this workout was not very difficult.  I could have done a couple more, but I was only looking for a moderately hard effort.  Legs are getting stronger.
50 min elliptical.  Took my day off for the month.  The elliptical wasn't too boring tonight thanks to the Sports Illustrated college basketball preview issue.
River road morning run.  Once again it took me forever to get out of bed and out the door.  By the time I got to the Franklin Bridge I was in a pretty good rhythm.  Also did a few strides.

20 min tempo (4 min jog/walk)
3 x 2:00 @ 5K-8K Effort (1:30 int)
3 x 0:30 @ Mile Effort (1:00 int)

I woke up this morning and didn't want to do this, but eventually got out the door.  It was hazy and a little bit windy, but really pretty good conditions for this time of year.  The tempo was solid.  I did it as an out and back and came back sub 5:20 pace.  Hit the intervals well too.  The last one was probably a 30 second 200, which would be the first one of those I've run in about 4 months.  My fitness is on its way back.

Ran on the treadmill at about 8:45.  Didn't feel like going out in the cold after a long day at work.  Whenever I work out in the morning and double back at night I always expect to feel like crap, but I usually end up feeling pretty good.

Shorter long run.  Stone Arch.  There was snow on the grass this morning.  15 is fine for the day after a workout and during a down week, but I have to make sure that I get some more 17-18 milers in over the next few weeks in order to be ready for Houston.  I ended up running today's run pretty quick...close to 6 minute pace for the last 10 miles probably.  Now off to Hanover for nationals!

Wow, what a day.  Pez and I got to the course at about 9:30 and got a short run in.  For all the rain during the week the course was not in too bad of shape.  Then the women ran first.  Noelle ran awesome and got 2nd.  She was basically right with the lead pack the entire race and then was the last one to fall off the St Scholastica girl.  The rest of the Olaf girls kind of struggled, but they're a young team and they'll have a couple more opportunities.  It felt like forever until the men's race started.  It was sunny, but with temperatures in the 30s and the wind it was kind of cold for standing around.  Since our guys had the box on the far right side I was nervous about the hairpin turn at 500 meters, but when they came back all of them were in good spots.  Just like last week Eli Horton was out front pounding, but Grant and Jake Brown were right around the top 10, Saksa wasn't far behind, and Calvin and Jake Campbell were in the 40s.  We held our spots for the first 10 minutes, and on the loop between 2 miles and 5K it looked like we were in control of the race as the NCC pack was still stuck behind our 4 and 5.  Phil asked me how we were looking and I told him that if we held our spots we would win.  The last 3K was probably the most excited I've ever gotten watching a cross country meet.  NCC was starting to roll, and every time I saw the pack I could tell that our lead was shrinking.  With 2 minutes of running left it was a tossup, but the guys were able to dig deep and slam the door.  Grant held off Eli for 3rd and Jake ended up 8th so we had the two low sticks that we needed.  Saksa was in 25th when he passed me with 500 to go; he finished 17th.  Jake Campbell got by 3 guys in the last straight, including NCC's #3, to finish 31st (one week after placing 18th at regionals, and two months after placing 31st overall and 8th on the team at the St Olaf Invite).  Calvin was hurting (he's been injured and hasn't been running much), but he did what he had to do and got across in 65th.  Phil and Dillon did well too - 75th and 122nd.  Right after the finish people (including the guys who ran) kept asking me if we had won, but I thought it was too close to call and didn't want to give out wrong information.  There was tension in the air as we all waited for the scores to be posted...it only took about 5 minutes but it felt like a half hour.  Finally it came up: St Olaf 84 North Central 86.  NATIONAL CHAMPS!  At that point the party was on.  After about 20 minutes of screaming, hugging, texts, and phone calls a bunch of us went out and did a 10 minute cool down.  The awards ceremony followed: the 4 All Americans got their medals, the guys went up and got the gold trophy, and we closed it down by taking a picture of the whole Olaf group and singing the fight song.  First national team title in any sport in school history.  I knew it was a possibility but thought it was more likely that we'd be 2nd.  On my way home as I walked through the airport wearing my National Champions hat a bunch of random people said congrats, which I accepted on behalf of the team.  On the list of best days of my life today is definitely in the top 10...even though I'm not on the team anymore I feel like my group laid the groundwork for this.  As always, it was a great day to be an Ole.  Let's do this again next year!

The Packer game went OT and then we had to go grocery shopping, so I didn't get out until about 5:30.  Just went out and back on Shepard towards downtown.  Kind of windy, but not too bad.  Legs felt good.  The down week went well.  Now it's time to go back up to the 90s, and on Thursday I'll see what kind of race fitness I have after a few weeks of miles, threshold work, and hills.  I'd like to be in the 25:30ish neighborhood.
The river is pretty much frozen, so the season of indoor doubles has officially started.

5 x 5:00 Cruise Intervals (1:00 int)
3:00 walk/jog
5 x 0:30 Fast (1:00 jog)

Good workout, but I probably ran harder than I should have.  Intervals 1, 2, and 5 were 5 minute miles, which right now is a good bit faster than threshold.  That said, I wasn't digging extraordinarily deep and for the most part I felt relaxed.  I'm still pretty pumped up from nationals.  I wore half tights, which was fine for the workout, but a little cold for the warmup and cooldown.
On the treadmill before PT.  Legs felt pretty rough; about what I expected for ten minutes after waking up and the morning after an evening workout.

Started from Run N Fun with 7 or 8 other guys, then when we got down to the river Kelly and Choker turned back and the others decided that they wanted to do a tempo workout, so I ran by myself up Summit to Victoria and back to the store.  Nice relaxed pace, felt good.  It's going to be cold on Thursday morning.
Easy run and 6 strides from work after working a 1/2 day.  Cold.  Legs felt good.

Course was 5.15 miles, so if you adjust my time to an 8K I would have been in the 25:40s.  I was hoping to be around 25:30, but given the 20 degree temperatures and snowy/slushy roads I'll take it.  Kind of scary to think that this is half marathon pace (possibly even slightly slower), but I've got 2 months to get there and lots more to do in training.

Extended Xavier loop.  I felt yesterday in my legs a little bit, but by the second half of the run things felt pretty normal.  Most people hadn't shoveled their sidewalks so the majority of the time I was running on about an inch of snow.  I also overdressed a bit.

Ran around Neenah with Mark Paulson.  We started with a lap of the high school, then went out to the point, then did two more laps around the NHS campus.  Energy wise I felt good the entire time.  My hips were starting to get tired towards the end.  It was nice to run with somebody; it's been awhile since I've done a long run that wasn't solo.
Ran the double downtown loop in Appleton.  I was cold when I woke up so I ended up overdressing.  Legs felt decent, by the middle of the run I was cruising.  Six strides after.

I wasn't planning on running again today, but after we got back to St Paul Aleta was going out for a run so I decided I might as well do the same.  Standard five mile out and back on Shepard.  Felt really good.  94 on the week with a good workout Monday, a solid effort Thursday, and a good long run Saturday.  Hoping for another good week next week.
Tired this morning.  Hopefully I'll feel more energetic for tonight's workout.

36 minute sub-tempo
4 x Ford Hill

Despite sloppy paths I decided to give this a go, thinking I could still mostly accomplish the goal.  Perhaps running in the snow/slush will be good prep for next weekend's cross country 10K.  My sub-tempo pace is usually 5:30-5:40, but tonight I bet it was more like 5:50s.  I didn't take splits but based on where I started and finished I know that I covered over six miles.  At the end of the workout I didn't feel tapped out, but this was only supposed to be moderately difficult so that's ok.  It looks like I'm going to have to head to the dome on Thursday in order to accomplish a high quality VO2 session.

Lilydale from Run N Fun.  Started with 10-12 people, then about half of the group peeled off to do a workout once we got down into Lilydale and I ended up finishing with Kotek after the others slowed down.  We added on a little bit to get a full 10.  My legs felt good but my stomach felt bloated for pretty much the entire run.
Treadmill.  My guess is I won't be running outside again until at least Saturday.

Ran on the treadmill at work.  Got to watch the Badger game, which despite being ugly basketball made the time pass a little more quickly.  By the end of this I was ready to get off that thing.  I don't know how Chris Erichsen does 120+ miles per week on a treadmill.

Morning hampster wheel spin.  Someone beat me to the exercise center this morning so the TV was tuned to some morning show instead of SportsCenter.  Also, last night I had some irritation on the inside of the back of my knee.  It was better this morning, but still present.  I'm still going to work out tonight at the dome because if I don't there isn't another option for getting something in this week, but I'll have to watch this over the weekend.

Worked out at the Metrodome.  The list of people there included the TCTC women, Reneau, Kotek, Andy Siegel, and John Davis.  The floor was slippery, which I'm sure slowed things down a little, but I felt good.  I roped Kotek into running the first lap of #4 with me...he bascially raced me for a lap (ended up being about 4:35 pace) and I didn't want to then slow down, so that interval was a mid-workout 'hammer'.  Closed it down well on the last one and felt like I could have done about two more if it wasn't December.  Cooled down with JD, talking about all things running related.  My lower hamstring tendon wasn't an issue during the workout.  It was a little sore afterward.

0 degrees, wind chill of -13.  I'm sick of running inside so I threw the gear on and went out.  It wasn't that bad.  The path is covered in packed down snow and ice, so a workout wouldn't be doable but a regular run is fine.  I'm still a little worried about this most recent hamstring tendon flare-up.

Another 0 degree run.  Fortunately I didn't really get that cold.  My face was red at the end but the rest of my body was fine.  I didn't check the wind direction before I started, but 2 miles in I realized I had been running with it so I changed my route.  

There is no spot near my building clear enough to do strides right now so I tried to do a couple down my hallway.  On my fourth one I just missed plowing over an old lady.  If she had come out of her door about two seconds later there would have been a big problem; fortunately I was able to slam on the breaks quickly.  I probably won't do that anymore.

Started the run after the end of the Packers and Vikings games.  14 degrees almost felt warm compared to the past two days.  It snowed last night and continued off and on throughout the day, so nothing was plowed.  My plan was to still try to do the whole thing outside.  Unfortunately once I got to the other side of 35 the path was pretty much impassable, so I turned around.  Probably for the best to not fight the snow for two hours.  I finished the last six miles on the treadmill and during this part I felt really good.  Ended the run feeling great.

91 for the week, which is good volume considering that the weather was crappy every day except Tuesday.  So so workout on Monday, good one on Thursday, good long run.  I'm still undecided about how exactly I'm going to apporach this next week, but I'm leaning towards really easing back and letting myself recharge.  I'm not peaking for Club Nats, but I'd still like to run well there.
Short morning run.  Legs were a bit stiff from yesterday and I felt like loosening up.
Treadmill after work.  Legs felt great, DVD player made the time pass quickly.
Another treadmill morning run.  Nothing to really say about it.

Worked out at the U of M.  The threshold and the mile both felt nice and smooth.  The 400s weren't too hard but my wheels are definitely rusty.  Makes sense since it's been months since I've done much of anything under 5:00 pace.  3 easy days before Saturday now.

54 minutes elliptical.  I've never taken a day off this close to a race without being injured or sick, but I figured I'd try it.  I probably got about the same type of aerobic workout as I would have gotten from an easy run and saved my legs a bit.  A little hungry since it had been 8 hours since lunch.

Out and back on river road.  The path has been plowed but not scraped clean, so there's a thin layer of packed down snow on the entire thing.  I felt alright.  Kind of overdressed.  4 x '150' strides afterward...did these down the middle of the road.  Heading to Portland this afternoon.

Ran from the hotel in Bend with Kieser, Parish, and Frye.  The run felt mediocre but my strides afterward felt good.  Apparently the course for tomorrow is absolutely brutal.  Saddle up for a ride on the pain train.
Shakeout from the hotel with Ben Jacobs

The course was insane.  Five 2K loops and you were always going up or down or turning.  I didn't think that I would ever run a course more difficult than nationals in 2009, but that course looks like Eau Claire in comparison to this one.  It certainly didn't play to my strengths as a runner, and without having done really any race specific or anaerobic training I knew going in that there was pretty much no chance of a great race.  Basically I just wanted to give it as good of an effort as I could.

At the start I didn't get out super hard and I ended up getting stuck pretty far back.  I ran most of the first lap in a crowd with my hands up and came to almost a complete stop on several turns.  I'd guess I was in 220th-230th after 2K.  After this I fell into a pattern of struggling up the hill then trying to both recover and pass people on the rest of the loop.  I saw a bunch of people fall, and on a lot of the downhills my main focus was on staying upright.  I just was never able to make the big move that I needed to.  The highest I got was probably around 180th.  With two laps to go I glanced down at my feet and noticed that I had lost one of my chips and that the other one was loose, so from then on I kept checking about every 10 seconds because I knew that if the second one fell off I had to go back for it.  Pat Parish passed me the last time up the hill.  Once I got through the sketchy footing part of the downhill finish I was able to get him back.  

Three days later I'm still not sure how I should feel about my performance.  I placed in a slightly higher percentile of the race than last year, and when I compared times for the Run N Fun, TCTC, WRRT, and other former MIAC guys that ran in both 2012 and 2013 the only people who added less time than I did were Joe Moore and Finnel.  That stuff is nice, but before I saw the course I thought that I could be in the top 1/3 of the field and I didn't beat any of the people that I had my sights on.  Most of those guys got out hard and I never saw them during the race.  I don't think I really learned anything about my fitness from this.  Houston is 5 weeks away, so I'll just have to take confidence from workouts over the course of the next month.

Mortenson woke me up at 8:50 and said that the group was running at 9.  There were 8 of us.  We ran on a trail along the river.  Some spots were icy, but most of the trail was pretty nice.  I wish St Paul had stuff like this.  Beautiful weather...about 40 degrees out when we ran and in the afternoon it got up to the mid 50s.  My legs felt lousy after yesterday's race, hot tubbing, and partying.  Hiking up a mountain in the afternoon didn't help, but oh well.  The view from up top was well worth it.  Also toured Deschutes Brewery.
One last trail run in Bend.  Legs were sore starting out but a relaxed run helped flush them out.  8 strides at the end.

Franklin to Ford, then turned around and did Ford to Franklin.  There was a thin layer of packed down snow on pretty much the whole path.  Probably about equivalent to running on dirt.  The first 5 miles or so I was a little hungry, then I felt good for most of the rest of the way.  The last 10 minutes I was starting to have some trouble breathing.  I made it back just fine but the end of the run was not comfortable.  Glad I got this in, as when I got home from work I would have much rather just sat down and watched TV for a few hours.
Hampster wheel spin at lunch.  First time doing that this winter.  I wanted a couple extra hours of recovery after last night's long run.

Franklin to Ford.  It was nice to only do the loop once today rather than turning around and running it again.  The temperature was in the low 30s, which felt nice but made the path soft and a bit slippery.  Legs felt tired.  About four miles in I bumped into Scott Schmick so I stopped and talked to him for a couple minutes.  He's just getting going again after another injury took him out for about 5 months.  I also passed some Collegeville guys.
Extremely tired this morning.  In about 40 hours I can rest; I'll be on the go until then.

Metrodome.  There wasn't much going on there in the fast lane tonight.  I think this workout went well.  The last couple of reps were getting tough but my pace stayed consistent (even speeding up a bit as I went).  I let it fly a little bit on the 30 second intervals.  It's nice to have a healed hamstring.  Stuff like this will help half marathon pace feel nice and smooth, and it should also help for the 3K, which is coming up fast.

Worked a 1/2 day, took Aleta to the airport, then ran before driving back to Appleton.  Not a very enjoyable run.  The path was in terrible shape and my legs felt like trash after yesterday's workout and minimal sleep.  At least I got it in.

42 minute sub-tempo (7.5 miles)

Went to Lake Park Fitness to do this on the treadmill since I didn't think it would be doable outside after yesterday's snow.  Their website says that they offer guest passes so I didn't think that I would have any sort of problem.  Had the following exchange with an employee:

Her: Can I help you?
Me: Yes I was wondering if I could please get a guest pass to work out.
Her: Well this is a private health club.  You're supposed to be a member to work out here.
Me: I don't live in the area and your website says that you offer guest passes.
Her: Yes, we usually do but we usually don't to college students.
Me: I'm 25 and have been out of college for over 3 years, so do I qualify?
Her: Well, technically you're also supposed to be sponsored by a member and have them here with you.
Me: Well, my parents are members.  Can they sponsor me even though they're not here right now?
Her: I guess.

There were maybe 10 people in the facility at the time, making it even more ridiculous.  Oh well, paid the $15 (seemed like a bit much) and got to do my workout.  I wasn't real excited about doing this on the treadmill, but it wasn't that bad.  Having 2 football games on helped the time keep moving.  I felt really strong and comfortable.  Definitely could have kept going for a long time at this pace, which is funny since it's the same pace I ran in last weekend's race.  I'll probably do one more of these before Houston.

Six months until Grandma's...

Ran on the treadmill in my parents' basement.  I hadn't run on that POS in nearly 2 years and had forgotten how much it sucks.  Oh well, I can deal with it for just a couple of days.  Legs were a little tired from yesterday.
Xavier loop.  About 3/4 of the sidewalks were shoveled, so it wasn't too bad.  Legs felt good when I was on the clear sections.  Also did six strides.
Treadmill double.  Felt a little tired from laying around all afternoon.

Worked out at the YMCA.  They have a three lane 11 lap to the mile track with sharp corners that I used once back in 2009.  Unfortunately this was the best option for getting this in as it's below 0 and snowy outside, treadmills don't go fast enough, and there isn't any other indoor track open on Christmas Eve.  Not ideal, but I did the best I could with it.  I was almost constantly passing people.  Got breathing pretty hard by the last two, so at least did some work.  At the end I did 5 laps of sprinting the straights and floating the turns...probably was about 10 x ~50 meters sprint with ~25 meters rest.  Warmed up and cooled down on a treadmill.  We'll see if I have time for a double later.
Treadmill double before church.  My family didn't really understand why I did this.  Oh well, I'm used to that.  Legs were tired but felt better at the end of the run than the beginning.

Merry Christmas.  Didn't feel like running in the morning in Appleton, but when I got back to St Paul I decided I didn't want to take a 0 for the day so I went out and did a Lake St to Ford loop plus a little extension at about 11 PM.  Didn't see another person the entire time.  My legs felt good and it was fun to be out there with nothing going on.  The path is still covered in snow.

26 minute tempo (5+ miles)
6:00 jog
4 x 30 seconds fast (1:00 jog)

Last night of Metrodome running.  There were easily 100+ people there, but not too many in the fast lane so there weren't any problems doing the workout.  This went really well.  Every lap that I took a split on was sub 5:10 pace, and I felt strong and smooth.  I suppose that doing a sharpening workout two days ago and then only six miles yesterday helped this a bit, but I still thought 5:10-5:15 would be a good day and I usually set optimistic pace goals, so to be ahead of that is great.  Cooled down with a group of Run N Fun guys (Siegel, Kelly, Lance, Nate Hall, Branigan, Kotek), and then at 7:55 Rick Recker gathered everyone and we all did one final lap as a huge group.  It's going to be tough to get quality workouts in now these next few weeks.

Felt really rough this morning.  I went outside because looking at the forecast I'll have plenty of treadmill time coming up, but after the fact I kind of wish I had stayed in.  Seriously St Paul, plow the path.

37 degrees out, which felt awesome.  Ran in half tights.  Legs were still tired but felt better than this morning.  I'm hoping I can get the long run in tomorrow before it gets really cold, but if I have to push it back a day I will.

Nice 2 hour long run.  No real route, I kind of just ran around.  It was in the mid 30s, so about as good as it gets this time of year.  Tomorrow it will be about 50 degrees colder.  Started off down East River, then I bumped into Metz and Malcolm about a mile in so I turned around and ran with them until they were done, then went back to West River.  Crossed the Franklin bridge and found East River unplowed so I flipped back to the west side.  When I got back to the Ford bridge I ran up the hill to check the time on the TCF Bank clock since I wasn't wearing a watch.  Saw that I needed 20 more minutes, so I went back to the path and did 3 more miles.

Treadmill run since the wind chill is about -23 outside.  Because of the way the sun was shining through the windows of the fitness center it was really warm in there.  Legs felt really good.  Went down to the parking garage afterward and did six strides.

36 minute sub-tempo (5:40 pace on treadmill)

I didn't feel quite as good on this as I did on my sub-tempo run 9 days ago, but it still wasn't too hard.  Watched Texas v Oregon and the timing worked out well as I finished right as the game got to halftime.

Day off.  My motivation has been lacking for about the past week and my body is feeling tired, so might as well give it a rest for a day.  I'll get back on it tomorrow.

That's it for 2013, although running wise I flipped the calendar to the 2014 season about two months ago.  PRed in the 8K and Half Marathon this year; unfortunately I wasn't able to use the fitness I had in the spring to get some other PRs because of the achilles injury.  I still wish I could have made it out to Hillsdale as I think I was in shape to run a really good 10K.  The second half of the racing year was a struggle thanks to low iron and a hamstring injury.  Thankfully those issues are cleared up now.

Results Goals for 2014:
1. PR in 3 of the 5K, 8K, 10K, and Half
2. No significant time off for medical issues
3. Marathon debut (it's time for this to happen)

Process Goals for 2014:
1. Continue to improve at the 'hard days hard, easy days easy' concept
2. Do the exercises I got in PT regularly, not just when something hurts
3. Sleep at least 7 (preferably 8) hours every night

Started off 2014 with a 10 miler on the treadmill. The first half was boring but once other people finished their workouts and I was able to put football on the second half passed pretty quickly. Legs felt good after taking yesterday off. Maybe run outside this afternoon?

4 miles easy
2 x 4 x ~200 (1:00 jog/walk int, 2:00 between sets)
Cooldown

After watching the Badgers lose (New Years Day tradition, 4 years in a row) I suited up for run #2. Started by running to St Thomas and back. I wanted to do something faster at some point this week and came up with the idea to do this in my parking garage. It took about 35 seconds to do a lap, so probably right around 200 meters considering the 90 degree turns and that I was wearing trainers. Legs felt ok; a little flat since I haven't done many strides recently and did a 10 mile run this morning. Only saw one moving car while I was doing this...I'm sure they were very confused. Nice to get a break from the treadmill.

-3 degrees, -13 wind chill. Usually I stay inside when it's below 0, but looking at the forecast I'm going to be inside for several days in a row starting on Saturday so I wanted to stay off the treadmill tonight. Went out and back to the U of M Hospital. I was basically running on hard packed snow the entire time. Face was getting cold the last couple miles, but other than that I was fine. Since I'm not going to the Packer game anymore I'll probably head down to Northfield on Saturday to do a workout.
Hampster wheel at lunch. Didn't feel good starting out but came around the last 10-15 minutes. The girl on the treadmill next to me was doing 20 second 'sprints' at 9 mph.

Ran to my old place on West 7th St and back. About halfway through it started raining ice pellets, which wasn't very comfortable. The 18 degree temperature was a nice change though. Legs felt a little sluggish once again, hope they come around for tomorrow.

Cool-down: 

Drove down to St Olaf to do this since there wasn't anywhere in the Twin Cities that would work. Since I haven't done a workout like this in months and my legs didn't feel good yesterday I wasn't sure how this was going to go. During the drive and the warm up I got decently psyched up, and by the time I started I was in a good frame of mind. I felt strong. Running on a 200 meter track felt a little strange and I don't have a ton of explosiveness right now, but aerobically I'm in a good spot. These were about 15 seconds faster than goal half pace and should help 5:0X feel more relaxed. Finished with 2 x 150 at about 95% speed. Definitely couldn't have done this 2 weeks before Grandma's last June, so I'm excited about the prospects for Houston.

Other things
-For most of the workout the Gustavus basketball team was warming up on one of the courts inside the track. Their guys kept walking into lane 1, which was annoying. Olaf ended up crushing them 80-56.
-While I was cooling down Chris Daymont was riding around Tostrud on an elliptigo. She was also wearing a boot.
-Ate at Hogan Bros after. I'd argue that the sandwich was worth the drive by itself; the good workout just makes it better.
Late evening double. NFL Playoff games today were awesome.

Treadmill during the first football game. Kept the pace slow, felt fine. Let's go Packers!

80 for the week with a day off...if you sub in the long run that I'm going to do tomorrow it's 84-85 in six days which is solid. This next week I'll do about 80 in 7 days with a moderate workout on Wednesday and the 3K at Bethel on Saturday.

-15 degrees outside with a windchill of around -40, so the long run had to be done on the treadmill. I got on about an hour before the BCS Championship Game started and ran until the end of the 1st quarter. My legs felt decent. Started getting hungry the last 3 miles or so. Hopefully I won't have to do any more long runs inside this winter.

Franklin to Ford plus strides and a tiny add on. Still a couple degrees below 0, but it only bothered me the first half of the run. Once I crossed the Franklin bridge and got the wind at my back I was fine the rest of the way. Legs were a little tired from yesterday. The path is still in rough shape...hopefully it will actually warm up to the 30s this weekend and then the packed down snow can melt.
Morning treadmill spin. It's been a couple of weeks since I've run first thing in the AM.

At the U. After reading Leaf's log from yesterday I was a little nervous about getting this in, but when I showed up there was pretty much nobody there and the Augsburg sprinters volunteered to move their hurdles out of lane 6 without me asking. Started off the with tempo and I think it went fine. The 800s were about what I was hoping for. I'm not quite as strong VO2 wise as I was last spring, but since the focus right now is on a half marathon that's fine. That gear will come in February and March. The 200s felt good. Cooled down mostly inside with Leaf.

Ran on the treadmill during lunch. It's finally a reasonable temperature outside but unfortunately I didn't have time to get all my warm stuff together this morning to bring to work and I can't run this evening. Someone had set the gym iPod to a rap playlist that made me feel like I was running at a club. For the second half of the run it was just me and a bunch of women in the fitness center and they kept looking at me...I think they thought I was the one who put it on. Legs felt ok.

***RACE***
Race Name: Bethel Open
Terrain: Track (Indoor)
Warm Up: 4
Race Splits: 2:54, 2:59, 2:56
Cool Down: 4
Overall Place: 2nd

I was hoping to run a little bit faster, but this is ok. I thought I could be anywhere between 8:40 and 8:50 so I just ended up on the slower side. A time trial on a slow track off of half marathon training isn't realistically going to lead to a fast 3K. I let Dan go right away and ran in 2nd. Felt pretty good the first K, then during the second one I started slowing down a bit and was hitting more 35 highs and 36s than 35.0s. Went through the mile in 4:40, which is the first time I've run a sub 4:50 mile since Shamrock last April 7th. I don't really have any anaerobic capacity right now. A guy passed me with 800 left and we alternated laps from there to the finish before I put about 5 seconds on him in the last 200 (closed in 29 high or 30 low). In 2 months with more specific training I'll split this in a 5K. Warming up and cooling down with Dan and Tyler was fun.

Since it was 40 degrees outside it made sense to run longer today instead of tomorrow. Legs felt great, no effects from the 3K. I probably could have gotten a little more out of myself yesterday, but oh well. East River Road was not in particularly good shape...lots of slush throughout and the stretch between Lake and Franklin was absolutely awful. Despite this I still made it to the Franklin bridge a minute faster than usual, so I was cruising. My original plan was to keep going out through the U of M campus and then do an out and back, but I didn't want to come back through this junk so I crossed the Franklin bridge. The path on West River was clean. Added on ~5 miles on Shepard to finish.

Decent week this week...nothing to get really excited about but got a few good efforts in. The main objectives now are resting up and making sure my legs feel good next Sunday.

Ran from work at lunch. It sucked, the path obviously hasn't been touched by a plow all winter. I'm not sure what the deal is with St Paul this year; my first two winters living here all of the paths were clean within 48 hours every time it snowed. Anyways, after spinning my wheels and slipping for roughly 2.5 miles I decided I had had enough so I turned around and then did the second five miles on the treadmill. Legs were a little tired today.
Treadmill before work. It snowed a couple inches last night. There's a decent chance I'll be running inside until I leave for Houston on Friday. Legs felt good this morning.
Ran on the treadmill at work during the first half of the Badger game. Time passed really quickly on this one. Badgers played sloppy in the second half and lost for the first time this season.

Last workout before Houston. Did it in lane 6 at the U, surrounded by the Hamline and Augsburg teams (including Tesema who was MIA all fall). Warming up outside wasn't much fun since it was snowing and very windy. The 2 mile was a little bit faster than I'm realistically hoping to run, but it felt smooth and it'll naturally be faster on a track than the roads. The 800s and 200s felt extremely easy. I'm ready to go on Sunday...rest well now.
Treadmill at lunch. Tired from yesterday starting off but felt good at the end.
Tired of the treadmill so I went outside. Out and back on West River. It was about 0, but didn't feel that cold. Legs didn't feel that great but I've still got 2 days. Off to Houston!

Ran from the hotel with Dan and Fernando Cabada. Cabada led us to a path that was about a mile away. It felt like we were running really slowly...save it for tomorrow I guess. Finished with strides. My legs feel good, I'm ready to go.

***RACE***
Race Name: US Half Marathon Championships
Terrain: Road
Warm Up: 3
Race Splits: Lots of 5:05-5:08s, 2 5:15s
Cool Down: 1+
Overall Place: 54th

This was a nice comeback performance. Woke up at 3:30 to eat and get ready. The hospitality for most of the weekend was awesome but the one glitch was the race morning protocol. It took forever for the buses to get us from the hotel to the starting line (which was only about a half mile - should have just had us walk) and by the time we unloaded there were only 45 minutes until the gun. This meant that my warmup routine was a little rushed, but I relaxed and it worked out. They also had us warm up by jogging back and forth on about a three block stretch. Anyways, the race started and I made sure to really stay relaxed the first mile. It helped that the guys up front 'only' went out in 4:45 compared to last year's 4:20. When I went through in 5:05 I said, 'perfect' to myself. I was a couple steps off of a pack of guys at this point so during the second mile I bridged that gap in order to run with people. Ended up packing it up with Dworak and two other guys for most of the race. We hit really consistent splits and everyone took turns at the front...worked out well. For the first 2/3 of the race I felt great. I was not breathing hard, I felt smooth, and the pace did not feel fast. It felt kind of like a long tempo run. The course was pancake flat so it was pretty easy to stay in a rhythm, and there were a decent amount of people cheering which always helps. At 9 miles I thought I might have a shot at breaking 1:07, at 10 I figured it was unlikely since I would have to close in sub 15:45 and I was hurting, and at 11 I knew it wouldn't happen. Passed 10 miles about 4 1/2 minutes faster than what I ran at TC10 which is kind of funny. It's a lot easier to race when you're not anemic and injured. Somewhere around 11 one of the other guys and my feet got tangled up and I almost fell. He yelled that he would buy me a drink afterward and I told him not to worry about it. The last mile I could see Brandon and Dan Kerr not too far ahead up the road and I wanted to try to get them but my legs were dying. I glanced at my watch at the 1/2 mile to go sign and saw that I needed to run 2:30 in order to PR by a minute...ended up just barely getting it. When I passed my parents right before the last turn there were two guys just ahead of me. I went around them and tried to 'kick', but I moved a little bit too soon and they both got me back in the last 50 meters. When I crossed the line my stomach, back, shins, and quads were all hurting. 30+ minutes later I did a short cooldown with Dan and Sathre which did not feel good. Overall, definitely happy. 1:01 PR, finished 21 spots higher than I was seeded, and had a lot of fun during the weekend. The fact that I was on sub 1:07 pace for most of the race leaves me hungry for more, but I'm not sure when I'll do another half. The plan right now is to focus on shorter stuff for the next couple months and then make the 26.2 debut at Grandma's.

Flew back from Houston this morning. My quads are pretty trashed from the race yesterday. Did 30 minutes of light biking to get the blood flowing, then stretched and rolled. I'm going to take it really easy this week and rest a bit both physically and mentally. The Alumni 3K will be my only race in February (and race is a pretty loose term for what that is), then I'll be ready to really get going in March.
Didn't feel like running today, so I didn't run.
Treadmill at lunch. Wind chills are about -20...I'm getting very tired of this winter. It felt good to run a little bit but my legs are still pretty beat up.
Same thing as yesterday. Legs are coming around. -35 wind chills today.
One last day off. I think I'm pretty much recovered from the race now so I'll get back to more regular training starting tomorrow.

Ran out and back on West River, turning around about a half mile past the Franklin bridge. Legs felt good and it felt good to be back out there. Still have one sore spot in my lower right leg. Seeing all of this weekend's track results kind of makes me want to go jump in some meets. That's not going to happen though.

Same run as yesterday but went out a half mile further. Felt pretty good; still working a couple kinks out but nothing major. I got cruising pretty well on the way back with a 20 mph tailwind. Four strides afterward.

Insomnia got the better of me last night...I slept less than four hours total and no more than 90 minutes continuously. So, I cut my run today short to avoid putting my body in more of a hole. Treadmill at lunch. Actually felt decent.

7 AM treadmill run. It's once again -15 degrees outside. Watched the Federer/Nadal match from last week. Only 7 hours of sleep last night but I felt fine getting up.

Did Body Pump at lunch with Jared since he's been trying to get me to do it for awhile. This was a reminder of how weak I am. I expect that I will be nice and sore tomorrow.

Out and back on Shepard to the Crosby Farms entrance by Elway St. This was my first time running outside in the dark in almost 3 weeks, which seems crazy. My body was a bit tired and sore from yesterday's weight lifting, but it wasn't too terrible.

USATF announced this afternoon that the 2016 Olympic Trials Marathon will be February 13, 2016 in Los Angeles. I still have a ways to go before I can start really thinking about that, but now I know exactly what the goal is.

Not a great day. I woke up and saw that it was snowing pretty hard, so instead of doing my morning run I just went straight to work. My commute took twice as long as it usually does. Got to the office and found out that the work I had been waiting on getting from somebody else in order to complete my part of a project that's due tomorrow was not done yet, so right away I figured my planned workout at the U was in jeopardy. Around noon I was in a holding pattern on all of my current projects so I went and did a shakeout run, at this point still unrealistically hoping I'd still be able to leave early. Long story short, the afternoon was chaotic and instead of leaving my office at 4 I left at around 8 after a 12 hour day. Got home and did not feel like running, but I eventually decided to do a short one to unwind a bit. Running on the treadmill did not sound fun so I layered up and went outside. Out and back on West River. Going into the wind my face was cold, then coming back I couldn't even tell it was below 0. On to tomorrow.
Treadmill. TGIF.

***INTERVAL***
Warm-up: 
Set...Reps...Distance/Time...Goal...Actual...Rep rest...Set rest
1.........6.....400 Meters....66 - 68....67, 67, 67, 67, 66, 67....1:15 jog....2:30 jog
2.........8.....200 Meters....31ish....31, 32, 31, 31, 32, 32, 30, 30....1:00 jog....____
Cool-down: 

At the U. There was hardly anybody there, as I suppose would be expected on a Friday since all the college teams have meets tomorrow. Felt better than I expected to for my first workout since the half. Lungs were burning a bit by the time I finished the 400s but I wasn't really getting lactic acid. I'd guess that I could run a mid 4:20s mile right now but it's fairly pointless speculation since I have no plans to race a mile this year.
Pretty lousy run this afternoon. Legs felt like lead and my stomach also felt weird. The temperature was in the 20s, which felt nice but made the path slippery. Can we just skip ahead to spring?

Good long run. I was relieved to feel much better than I did yesterday. Wanted to go all the way to downtown St Paul, but when I hit Randolph the path wasn't plowed anymore so I had to add on at the end to get the full distance. The wind chill was about 0, but with the sun it didn't feel real cold out. Four strides at the end. I want to get in the habit of doing strides after long runs this spring.

This was kind of a sloppy week training wise with one day lost because of sleeping issues and my plan for the second half getting fouled up because of work. The plan for this next week is to get back to full volume (90ish). I think I'm just going to do one workout, hopefully on Wednesday.
Nice run on West River. Legs felt great. The second half I was really hungry and all I could think about was the food that was waiting for me at the end.

Went to Run N Fun for the first time in a couple months. Other than Mortenson it's a completely different group of people from when I first joined the team two years ago. We did Lilydale. Roads were clear down there which was really nice. Legs felt good for the most part. My left hamstring is a bit tight.

Morning shakeout on the treadmill. Stopped at 30 minutes because a lady was standing over my shoulder waiting for me to be done and I was getting sick of it. Hamstring felt pretty much normal so I'm going to go ahead and try the 1000s tonight.

***INTERVAL***
Warm-up: 
Set...Reps...Distance/Time...Goal...Actual...Rep rest...Set rest
1.........3.....1000 Meters....2:55-2:57....3:01, 2:59, 3:00....2:00 jog....____
2.........3.....600 Meters....____....1:45, 1:43, 1:44....1:30 jog....____
Cool-down: 

Kind of a frustrating evening. Warmed up and did strides, feeling fine, then started off on the Ks and couldn't hit the pace I was hoping for. I was planning to do 4 or 5 but after 3 I decided to switch to 600s so that I could run faster than 3:00/K pace. Scrapped the 150s I was planning to do at the end (see below). It wasn't like I felt horrible during any of this, but it was more difficult than I thought and I'm obviously not in the kind of 3K/5K shape that I would like to be in.

My left hamstring does not feel good. Unfortunately it feels very similar to how my right one felt last summer/fall, so I'm worried about it. I didn't feel it during strides before the workout, but during the cooldown it was definitely noticeable. I'm going to start addressing this right away and hopefully I can take care of it in a couple of days rather than having it affect me for 3 months. The combination of a disappointing workout and the hamstring flare up reaffirms that I need to just take things gradually and not force it. I was kind of hoping that I'd somehow be in shape to jump in a 5K at the end of indoors, but that's not realistic. Not a huge deal as I've got bigger fish to fry later on.

Played it smart and took the day off from running. 30 minutes elliptical during lunch, followed by exercises. Still undecided about the plan for tomorrow. I may do a treadmill run as that shouldn't bother anything.

Ran 5 miles on the treadmill at lunch. Felt normal for the most part. I was going to do more than this today but I probably won't get out of here until after 8 PM so this will probably be it. Might be for the best anyway to have another easy day.
Did the same run that I did on Sunday. Felt really good, as I should after 5 miles total in the previous two days.

Ran in the morning in Madison before the Badger game. I parked at Tenney Park and ran through the part of the city where I used to live and then down to the lakeshore path. It was fun to be back here. Badgers won...Traevon Jackson with the winning bucket with 2 seconds left!

Not a great training week this week but at least I got some work in and I'm not going backwards. Hoping to put together a good one next week.
Ran at lunch while watching ski jumping. Legs felt really good.
Out and back on West River. Really cold but it didn't bother me too much. Legs once again felt really good. Tempo tomorrow...unfortunately it will probably be on the treadmill.

25 minutes @ 5:20 pace on treadmill

First tempo run in awhile. Unfortunately it was on the treadmill because running fast on the snow/ice outside in the dark is probably asking to get hurt. I wish the dome was still open...would have been perfect for this. Anyways, cardio wise I felt good the entire time. My legs felt like they were turning over really fast and were getting tired towards the end. I also started getting pretty warm the last 6-7 minutes. The good news is this didn't bother my hamstring at all.

Slogged through slush on East River. Legs felt decent starting out but by the end I was getting worn out from slipping so much. Nice to have a double digit wind chill at least...first time in quite awhile.
Franklin to Ford plus some, then strides.  Path is really sloppy.
Ran at lunch.  I usually like to double first thing in the morning on workout days but needed more sleep today.  I'm sure it will work out fine.

1 x 5:00 (2:00 jog)
2 x 3:00 (2:00 jog)
6 x Lock & Dam Hill (jog down)
4 x 0:30 (1:00 jog)

I didn't feel like going to the track today so I decided to just do something outside.  Footing wasn't great on most of the path, but I was able to make do.  Worked into the first couple intervals, then hit the hills and the 30s hard.  Happy with the effort, and my hamstring didn't bother me at all so it looks like that's a non-issue going forward.  Hustled when I got done in order to get to St Thomas for the 5K...Easker 14:19, Jenkins 14:23, Stilin 14:29, Jake Campbell 14:48, Phil Meyer 14:55.  Grant had run 8:23 earlier in the evening for the school record.  I'll probably never get tired of going to track meets.
Ran first thing in the morning before going to the U to time at the MIAC swim meet all day.  Out and back on Shepard.  The first mile felt kind of rough but the rest of the run was fine.

18 mile long run that felt like 20-22 because of all the slush on the path.  Good grief.  The stretch between my apartment and St Thomas should almost be considered un-runnable.  Sloppy conditions aside I felt decent and my energy levels were good the whole way.  This was a good week of training.  Time to start stacking them on top of one another.

Hampster wheeled it since the path was terrible yesterday and the snow we got today certainly wouldn't have made it better.  Watched UNC play like a JV high school team for 10 minutes against Florida St and then come back to be down by only 3 at half (they ended up winning).  Legs felt decent after yesterday.
Really warm in the fitness center this morning.  There was a girl in there lifting weights while riding a stationary bike.

Thomas Breitbach style 1200s: 5 x 1200 @ slightly slower than 10K pace with 90 seconds brisk jog in between (just short of 400 meters), then after the last 1200 go right into a hard 400.  My goal was to run 3:45s and then hopefully finish with a 65.  Started off with a good first one, then Coach Schmaedeke asked me to move to lane 5 because the Hamline 400 runners were doing something really fast in lane 6.  Unfortunately there aren't markers for long intervals in lane 5, but Hamline pays to use the facility and I don't, so I obliged.  I think it worked out fine for the next 3 1200s...just ran for 3:45 and took the occasional 200 split.  I guess I'll have to do this again sometime in order to get splits on the whole thing.  On the last one I kind of slacked off in the middle...I think because I was worried about the 400 that I knew was coming.  I popped out to lane 6 in order to get an accurate split on this and ended up running 65.1.  It didn't feel extraordinarily difficult, but I definitely couldn't run a mile at that pace right now.  5:00 pace on the 1200s definitely felt like it would be doable for an 8K, so hopefully I can keep progressing and be in shape to run real fast in a month.  Cooled down outside in twilight and 40 degree weather...nice little taste of spring.

Easy run on Shepard.  I was pushed for time because of going to the Gophers basketball game.  It was awesome to run in half tights and I didn't even mind the puddles.  Had a little bit of hamstring tightness but it went away after about 10 minutes.

Got myself out of bed and ran early in the morning in order to beat the blizzard that's expected later.  Went out to the U of M hospital, turned around when the path wasn't plowed anymore, then came back via West River and added on a few minutes to make it 12.  Felt good.
Ran on the treadmill during the blizzard.  Things are going to be messy for the next several days.  Legs are feeling good.
Easy run.  Went outside because I really didn't want to run on the treadmill, and for what I needed to get in the path actually wasn't that bad.  Did some strides afterward in the parking garage.

Morning shakeout for the Alumni 3K, but then after breakfast I decided not to go since the roads are still listed as hazardous and MN DOT is advising against travel.  Kind of a bummer since it's the first alumni race I've missed, but it's not worth ending up in the ditch and there wasn't going to be any competition.  Just means I have to wait 2 more weeks to get the spring season going.
It took awhile for me to come up with the motivation to run this afternoon.  Eventually got out there and did it.  The path's not great but it's somehow in better shape now than it was last weekend.

Sub-tempo on treadmill

The goal was 40 minutes at 5:40 pace.  15 minutes in I was starting to feel a little shaky so I decided to do 2 x 20 minutes with a half mile jog in between.  Ended up pulling the plug on the second segment at 16 minutes because I would have had to dig pretty deep to finish it and this was only supposed to be a moderate workout.  I felt a little off when I woke up this morning and I also don't think I put enough gas in the tank before starting this.  Kind of discouraging to not be able to complete a workout that's 10-15 seconds slower than my goal marathon pace, but I'm not going to dwell on it.
Woke up at 5 AM and couldn't get back to sleep.  It's going to be a long day.

8 x Ford Hill
4 x 30 seconds fast on flat ground

Second workout of a back to back.  I was a little unsure about doing this since I didn't finish yesterday's workout, but decided to go for it.  Ended up feeling nice and strong tonight.  Running on packed down snow made things a little slower but effort was there.  Looks like it's going to be another terrible week weather wise.

Decided to go to Run N Fun since I haven't run with another person in three weeks.  As we've done probably 90 percent of the times I've been there over the past year we did Lilydale.  Really cold temperatures and bad footing resulted in us running around 7:30 pace for most of the run.  I also should mention that the group stopped twice because I had to pee...felt kind of bad about that.
Lunch run.  Too tired to run this morning.

Weather wise this was one of the worst runs I've done in a long time.  25 mph winds, snow blowing all over the place, no pavement to be found anywhere because it's all covered in snow and ice.  This winter is really testing my commitment to running.

The speed is getting better.    Three weeks ago 3:00 was a struggle, tonight 2:58 felt pretty manageable, and hopefully in another three weeks I'll be able to hit closer to 2:55s.  Got in from my warmup and saw Anders and Nick jogging around the track, so that was cool to have some other people there.  The Grunewalds also showed up, as did Burseth.  For the most part the Ks felt alright.  Working decently, but not straining to hit the time.  Some guys were putting away some mats and they weren't paying very close attention to what was going on, so I had to weave out of lane 6 occasionally.  On the 400s I took a little bit more rest than originally planned, but this way I got to run with Anders and Nick for the first 2.  It's so much easier to run with other people than it is to run solo.  Cooled down a bit inside, then spent 10 minutes trying to figure out how to get out of the track (they had closed the event entrance), then jogged back to the car.

These 5 mile runs are starting to feel kind of pointless.  I'm thinking about pulling a Moore/Greeno and cutting out doubles...although I don't have the lifetime base built up that either of those guys does.

Ran Franklin to Ford at 5:30.  The nice thing it that it was light out for almost all of the run.  The negative was that the footing was atrocious.  I think I slipped/slid on every single step I took.  Spent most of the run swearing to myself because I was getting so frustrated.

Grant ran 8:17 tonight.  I remember watching Charlie Gamble set the Tostrud record at 8:25 and being absolutely in awe, and now Grant shattered it.  He should have a good shot at winning nationals in a couple weeks.

The schedule called for a long run today, but my options were to do it outside with negative 20 wind chills and horrible footing or inside on the treadmill.  Neither of those was attractive, so I'll cross my fingers that the weather will be a little nicer tomorrow (if not I'll have to just tough it out and do it anyways).  Felt good on this run; watched basketball on ESPN.

14 miles outside, then 3 on the treadmill.  Energy wise I felt great the entire way.  The wind chill was about -15, but for most of the outside portion I was comfortable enough.  When I got on the treadmill I kind of felt like hammering, but I'm going to do a tempo tomorrow so I'll save it for that.  Four strides at the end.  Glad I got this in.

I couldn't fall asleep last night so getting up early to run kind of sucked.  I thought I had to get to the office early in order to work a full day before leaving for the U to work out, but when I got in I found out my boss is taking the day off, so, a) I have minimal work to do, and b) I could have gotten here at my normal time and most likely nobody would have noticed or cared.  Dang it.

24 minute tempo (just over 4.5 miles)
4 x 150 fast

I went to the U since I decided I'd rather do this on a track than a treadmill.  Some other Run N Fun guys were there doing mile repeats.  I split my first mile at 5:18, then split three other 800s at 2:38, 2:36, and 2:36, so I probably averaged around 5:15s.  Felt strong and controlled.  This pace is easy, now over the next year and a half it's 'just' a matter of getting to the point where I can do this six times in a row.  Felt alright on the 150s; not a ton of pop but by this point I had done 30+ miles in the previous 25 hours so I wouldn't expect to be feeling real explosive.  Good workout, things seem to be in a good spot right now.

Easy run that actually wasn't all that easy because I spent the entire thing sliding and stomping through slush.  Probably should have just run on the treadmill.  Supposedly it's going to hit 40 at the end of the week.  It's time.

Decided last night that I didn't want to run this morning, so I slept in instead.  Ran after work and it went alright.  Some spots on the path are significantly cleaner than yesterday, but as you move towards St Paul it gets icier.  For the most part my legs felt decent.  Thought about marathon training for almost the whole run.  I've got a pretty good idea of what I want to do in the 8 weeks before Grandma's.  The toughest part to figure out is the last 2 weeks.
Hampster wheel.  My DVD player wasn't working very well which made things kind of drag on.

9 x Lock & Dam Hill

I felt kind of lethargic doing these, but got them in.  Played a trick on myself...before #8 I told myself I'd be done after that one, but then after completing it I jogged back down the hill and did another one.  Hoping for around a 4:25 on Sunday.
