Ran first thing in the morning.  Didn't feel great, but it was only 12 hours after my run last night.  In honor of Nick Ross I did some parking garage strides afterward.  Mile tomorrow.

Glorious.  50 degrees, and light out for the entire run.  Lots of puddles, but I didn't care.  If we can get more of this the weather gods and I will be on good terms again.  Anyways, long out and back on West River into Minneapolis.  Kept a good pace going the entire time (this may have actually been 18.5-19 miles).  I felt strong the entire run, but I'm definitely tired now.  Saw Tina walking her dog by the Stone Arch Bridge, and also crossed paths with Chris Erichsen and Zach Gengler but I'm not sure either of them knew who I was.

AM - 2.5 mile shakeout.  Really slow, just wanted to move since I woke up feeling pretty dead.

PM - High Bridge with Run N Fun.  Some of the old guard showed up, so that was nice.  Talked about MIACs (particularly the mishap in the 1000) and nationals.  Legs still felt pretty tired so I made sure to run easy, especially when people were hammering during the first half.
Shakeout.  Pretty soon I'll start going outside for these again.

8 x 800.  Goal was to start at 2:30 and cut down to around 2:20.  Wanted to get something decent in, but nothing too killer since it's my third 'stress' day out of four.  Anders and Nick showed up to run a very similar workout, so I ran the first two solo while they finished warming up, then did the middle four with them, then pulled away on the last two.  Things went pretty well with the exception of #5 where we went out in 71 and then came back in a 77.  Glad I broke 2:20 at the end.  The whole workout felt pretty manageable.  Definitely going easy tomorrow though.

I guess by 'going easy' I meant taking the day off.  Woke up this morning and my neck hurt so badly that even picking my head up off the pillow was a chore.  It didn't get any better over the course of the day and I can't really move my head to the side at all right now.  Running was out of the question.  I've never heard of someone missing a run because of a neck spasm before...FML.

Fortunately my neck felt better today.  I still don't have full range of motion, but I'm not totally miserable like yesterday.  Decided to run since it was so nice out.  It didn't feel normal, but I wouldn't say it hurt.  Running at twilight on a Friday evening got me thinking 10K.

Ford to Lake St tempo (5.5 miles)
5:00 jog
5 x Ford Hill
4 x 100m 'All Out'

Crushed it.  I was feeling pretty pumped up on the warmup so I made sure to start easy on the tempo in order to not turn it into a race.  Felt smooth and strong.  Once I got to St Thomas I let the legs go a bit and closed sub 10 for the last two miles, still feeling within myself.  The other stuff was uneventful...just got it done.  If I feel like this at the two 8Ks coming up I've got some great races coming.
Ran early with Dan.  We went over to Fort Snelling and then added on.  Felt alright and conversation made the time pass quickly.  We'll see about a double later.
Slipped out for a little jog in Northfield.  I ended up running into Bakken on Jefferson so I ran with him for a couple minutes.  Legs felt pretty good.

Long run to downtown St Paul.  Didn't feel all that great the first couple miles and 30 minutes in it was daunting to think that I had another 90 minutes left.  I ended up coming around alright and finished the run feeling like I could have kept going.  With races the next two weekends it'll be a few weeks before I do another one of these.

Ran out and back on East River while it was snowing.  The first half of the run snow was constantly hitting me in the face and making it hard to see.  Once I turned around that wasn't an issue anymore.  Felt a few twinges in my achilles with about a mile left.  It didn't hurt consistently, but kind of frightening.
Achilles felt normal getting out of bed.  Ks tonight.

I didn't run very fast tonight, but I'm happy with my ability to get through this one.  Legs felt tired on the warmup and didn't have a lot of life on strides, which gave me a feeling that it could be rough.  Started off slow on the first, and on the second I had to grind to break 3:00.  At this point I decided I would do one more and then decide whether I needed to adjust the workout.  After the third I knew I could probably finish all 5.  I must just not be recovered from Saturday and Monday yet.  Was planning some 150s or 200s afterward but after consulting with Nick I scrapped them.  Time for a few easier days now before Sunday.

Really easy treadmill run at lunch.  I wanted to watch the NCAA Tournament so this was an easy way to kill two birds with one stone.  Started right before the Badger game tipped off.  The Badgers were sluggish for most of the first half but got it together and ended up winning by 40.  Dayton upset Ohio State in an exciting game.  Welcome to March Madness!  My legs actually felt decent today; I expected to feel terrible, so that was nice.

Ran 25-30 minutes by myself, then met up with Dan and Sathre by the roundabout for a Lake St Bridge loop.  On the first portion I headed out towards Nokomis and there was a lot of ice on the sidewalks.  The river road was pretty clear.  Legs felt alright considering I stayed up until 1 AM watching basketball last night.  Coming back down East River Dan split one of our miles at 6:07, so we were cruising.  Let's see if my bracket can stay perfect today!
Ran again after work.  Did the loop around St Thomas that I did for doubles last summer.  I'm pretty sure this was my first time running on Summit in 2014.  It was super windy out there.

Pre race run.  I was stressed about some stuff heading out the door, which led to starting off too fast and then stressing out more about that.  At the turn around I turned my watch off and tried to just relax.  Legs felt kind of flat.  Did a few strides afterward.

Very cold and windy.  I've done this race three times now and the weather has never been real good for running.  At the start a front pack of 5 formed pretty quickly.  I knew that I couldn't run with those guys so I slowed down, hoping to run with Lundstrom.  After about 30 seconds he started dropping back, so I had to choose between either really hitting the brakes to let the chase pack catch me or continuing on solo.  I chose to try to grind it out by myself, which was hard.  By two miles I was already feeling tired.  Max Renner blew past me near the turn around by the law school at 3 miles.  I had about two minutes with him before he dropped me and kept rolling.  My fourth mile was straight up slow.  It was into the wind, but running a 5:20 in an 8K is pretty bad.  At this point I knew I wouldn't break 25 which was kind of demoralizing.  I was able to bring it back down a little the last mile but couldn't make up any ground on Max.  Throughout the whole race I felt like I was running hard, but unfortunately afterward I didn't feel like I really used everything I had.  

We lost the team race to TCTC by 10 seconds.  Max was 10 seconds ahead of me, so if I would have beaten him we would have won.  That guy ran a great race.  Even with the conditions I still thought I could break 25 minutes today...perhaps I underestimated the effect of the cold/wind, or perhaps I'm not as fit as I thought I was.  I guess I'll have more of an idea after next weekend.  I kind of feel like I let the team down, but we'll have opportunities to even things up at other races.

I was slow getting going this morning, but I decided to still run and get to work a little later.  Out and back on East River.  It was about 15 degrees and lightly snowing.  Looks like we're in for another spring like last year's.  My legs were a bit tired.  Thought about yesterday's race some more and I'm less disappointed with it today than yesterday, but I'm still hoping for a big improvement next weekend.
The windchill was back below 0 this morning.  I chose to stay inside and watch a DVD rather than go out in that.  Legs felt much better than yesterday morning.

23 degrees, wind chill of 11.  I like the fact that now it's light out when I run after work, but is it too much to ask for it to also be shorts weather?  Anyways, ran out and back down East River to the U of M.  Felt alright for the most part.  Saw Aaron Easker running by St Thomas and then saw Mike Mittelsteadt by the Franklin bridge.  Finished with strides.
Easy shakeout.  Going to be busy today from 7 AM to 10 or 11 PM.

Legs felt flat throughout the workout, but I still hit about the times I was looking for.  The Augsburg sprinters were doing 150s and it worked out that they would usually finish one of their repeats right as I was starting one of mine (so I guess they had about three minutes rest).  This was a different sort of workout, but it was probably good for me to get this gear going.  It's been awhile.  I felt like my gas tank was running on empty, even on the warmup, which doesn't make sense seeing as I ate a big dinner last night and a decent amount throughout the day today.  Guess I'm just going to have to put down even more.  I think I'll take tomorrow really easy.

Ran at lunch.  I decided that a really easy day was in order since I've been feeling a bit flat recently and I want to run well on Sunday.  It would have been pretty tough to fit in much more than this today anyways with everything I have to get done.
Out and back on West River.  Legs still don't feel that good; I've got 48 hours to come around though.
Ran in Chicago with Dan, A Town, and Nick.  Also did a few minutes by myself shortly before those guys arrived.  Really windy along the lakefront.  My legs actually felt decent today.
Worked a 12 hour day, then when I got home it was really windy and lightning out so I decided to eat and watch baseball instead of run.

Ford to Franklin (9 miles) sub-tempo

It's been quite awhile since I've gotten in a good sub-tempo run, so I'm glad this one went well.  Legs felt a little strange on the warmup, probably because I hadn't run in basically 2.5 days.  I was worried about starting off too fast so I made sure to really start easy.  First mile was probably about 6:00, then I picked it up.  Coming off of Sunday's race and with a hard workout looming on Friday I was hoping to keep this moderate and that I could average 5:40-5:45.  I ended up coming in at 50:40, which is just under 5:40 pace, and the whole thing felt smooth and controlled.  Did six strides afterward.  Probably worth noting that I was really tired a couple of hours later.
Lake St to Ford.  Once I actually got moving I felt decent.
Easy run #2 for the day.  Out and back on Shepard.  Felt alright...neither good nor bad.

Ran at lunch.  Felt good for the most part.  About halfway through it started hailing/raining ice pellets.  My face felt like it was being stabbed with tiny needles.  6-10 inches of snow expected in the next 24 hours, then maybe it will actually be spring.
Hampster wheel.  Really hoping that this is the last time on that thing until November.  Watched the end of the Gophers winning the NIT.  What an accomplishment.
Rough morning run.  Extremely tired.

Had a much needed good workout.  After how tired I felt this morning and most of the day I kind of expected this to not go well, but I pulled it together.  On the first interval I didn't look at my watch until 800 and ended up going through in 2:29, then after that I found the pace I was looking for.  Felt strong...I was definitely working but this felt easier than the Ks that I did 2 weeks ago which were at only a slightly faster pace.  The music that the Augsburg guys had going definitely helped.  I was planning on a 4th 400 at the end but had to cut it because at 5:55 the entire Coon Rapids track team came into the fieldhouse and took over.  That's (hopefully) it for indoor workouts for the year.

Easy run on Shepard.  Great weather, just wore a long sleeve and half tights.  Can't wait for next week's forecast.  Legs were a little tired from yesterday, but not as bad as I expected.  Long run tomorrow in Northfield I think.

Ran from Aleta's parents' house in Northfield.  Basically I ran to Walgreens, then ran on the old Monday threshold course for the next 50 minutes until it was time to turn around.  This was the first time I've ever run miles 2-5 of that loop in the reverse direction.  About 2 minutes before I was going to flip I got chased by a dog; thankfully it didn't see me when I came back.  Beautiful afternoon with 55-60 degree temperatures, but a bit windy.  I felt good almost the entire run but then the last 5 minutes I was starting to get worn out.  Aleta's mom gave me a huge piece of chocolate cake right when I got back.  It tasted good, but my stomach did not feel good after eating it.
Out and back on West River.  Absolutely beautiful evening and my legs felt pretty good.  4 strides at the end.  It doesn't get much better than the running I've done the past 4 days.
Ran from work.  Found out at 11:20 that I was supposed to be on a conference call at 1:00 so I got out pretty much right then.  Legs felt good.

25:30 tempo
4 x 30 seconds fast

Tempo on the river road.  I went out 13 minutes, then was 30 seconds faster on the return.  Most of the difference can probably be attributed to the wind.  Legs were tired on the warmup but the workout went off without a hitch.  Uneventfully well is how I'd describe it.  Brandenburg's injured and won't be able to run the 10K next week.  I'm kind of bummed since we would have been able to work together for most of the race.  Hopefully I don't end up running by myself for 20 of the 25 laps.

Franklin to Ford.  I ran the first 2 miles with A Town, who was cooling down after a workout.  Super nice weather...a lot of people have come out of hibernation this week so the paths are more crowded than they have been (granted they're also much wider now that the snow is gone).  Legs felt alright.  I was pretty hungry.

At the end of the run coming back over the Ford bridge I was passing a woman who lives in my building and is probably about 40.  She looked over at me and started speeding up.  I thought she'd drop back again after a short distance, but she stayed right next to me.  At this point it would have been awkward if I put in an obvious surge, so we ran stride for stride across the bridge (which was still kind of awkward).

Ran with Dan and Kampf.  We were supposed to meet at 7:10 and when I hadn't seen them at 7:16 I assumed that I missed them so I took off, but then I found Dan a minute later.  Started with a loop on some trail in Minnehaha then did a Lake St bridge loop.  Felt a little tired, but not too bad.  Nice spring morning.

Ran at 10 PM, so nearly 14 hours after I finished my first run.  Long day is an understatement.  I probably would have just scrapped the double but I wanted to do strides before tomorrow's workout.  I ended up being glad I went out because it was perfect running weather...50 degrees, no wind, under the stars.  If conditions could be like this next Friday I'll be ecstatic.

5 x 800/400 (1:00 between reps, 3:00 between sets)

Birthday workout on the track at Mac.  Thankfully Matt Haugen didn't mind me working out at the same time as the Mac team.  After doing indoor workouts all winter the outdoor track looked huge on first glance.  There was some noticeable wind on the homestretch, but the temperature was great.  I wanted to get a hard effort in today and definitely accomplished that objective.  The 1:00 rest after the 800s was getting pretty short by the last two sets.  It was hard not to start too fast on the 800s coming off of the faster 400 and then the long rest.  Felt decent for the most part.  I had to dig a little on the last few reps, but I never doubted that I could finish the workout, so the amount of effort expended was about right.  2:20 is probably somewhere between 3K pace and 5K pace right now.  Hopefully this helps 10K pace feel relaxed next week.

Did nothing productive today.  Finally got out on a short run at 7:30.  Felt rough the first mile, then loosened up a bit, but I don't think I was ever under 7:00 pace.  Had a pounding headache when I stopped.

I slept in too late this morning, then had to go on a bunch of errands during the afternoon.  Got home at 3:00 and was starving so there wasn't time to eat and then run before going to Run N Fun.  Thus, I got out the door at about 7:00.  Went out and back down East River to the Stone Arch Bridge.  It was super windy and starting off into the wind I felt a bit underdressed.  Legs felt good the entire time but the rest of my body felt lethargic.  Need to go to bed early tonight.  On a side note, thanks to Run N Fun for all the new gear.

Ran the Crosby Farms loop for the first time since November.  Lots of fallen trees down there after the winter.  It was a bit chilly this evening - looks to be the theme for the week.  Legs felt a little sluggish.  I never really got back to sleep after Aleta left at 4:45 AM, so that's probably why.

When I saw that the wind chill was 8 degrees I decided I'd rather just hit the hampster wheel than bundle up.  This ended up working out well since I saw a really cool piece about Boston on SportsCenter.

Short tuneup workout before Friday.  I was hoping to do the tempo on the river road and then the intervals on the St Thomas track, but UST's track was locked (fortunately I checked this before starting my warmup) so I went to SPA instead.  Felt good on the tempo...no splits but I think I was moving well.  Unfortunately when I got on the track my sense of pacing was pretty lousy.  The 400 was too slow and then on the 800 I started off too fast.  Oh well, can't undo it now and this workout isn't going to make or break my race on Friday night.  It was chilly this evening...full tights would have been too warm but I was somewhat cold in half tights basically from the end of the tempo on.  72 hours to game time.  Rest up.

This was one of the most unpleasant runs I've done in awhile.  35 degrees and raining steadily.  I stopped at Walgreen's towards the end to pick up a prescription...unfortunately it wasn't ready yet which meant I got to sit there in my soaking wet clothes and freeze for 15 minutes.  A hot shower was definitely necessary when I got home.  Legs felt ok.

Pre race.  I don't like doing these runs by myself, as I way over analyze how my legs feel.  I didn't feel transcendent today, but I think I'm ready for tomorrow.  Hopefully a) the weather holds up and b) we get on the track before midnight.

On my first stride a guy who I ran past looked at me and said, 'go get 'em.'  Then on the third one a lady yelled out the window of her car at me, 'why do you do this?'  Some days I wonder the same thing.
Pre race shakeout at about 12:40.  Feeling good.

Crosby Farms loop in reverse.  It was really windy.  Physically I didn't actually feel that bad and I considered going further, but I realized that if I did I'd probably pay for it down the road.  Even though last night didn't turn out how I wanted it was still a hard 10K in spikes and I still have to recover from it.  Still frustrated, but I'll regroup for next Saturday.

Easter Sunday long run.  Kept it shorter since I'm in between two 10Ks.  Best weather day of the year so far - nearly 70 degrees and sunny.  Everyone was outside this afternoon.  I did an out and back over the Stone Arch, and the area by the bridge was by far the most crowded I've ever seen it.  Felt ok, have a little delayed fatigue from Friday night (probably just as much from staying up until 4 AM as from the actual race).  One more week of moderate mileage and then I jump into the meat and potatoes of marathon training.

Ran an out and back down East River.  Low 60s and really windy.  Legs were tired.  I definitely did not eat enough this weekend and most of what I ate was junk, so that's probably why.  Meb won Boston this morning.  Super inspirational.
I feel like a sack of garbage.

6 x Cruise Miles (1:00 rest)
5:17, 5:18, 5:17, 5:18, 5:18, 5:15

3:00 jog

4 x 400 @ ~3K Pace (1:00 jog)
70, 71, 70, 68

Went with a pretty easy workout tonight since I haven't been feeling chipper for awhile.  This weekend also marks the end of the 'speed' cycle of my training and one more set of VO2 intervals won't make a difference in how I race on Saturday.  The miles were easy.  Seeing as I've been running 5-10 seconds per mile faster on continuous tempo runs I probably did them a little too slow, but that's fine.  The first 400 was a bit of a shock to the legs after six miles of slower work.  Nice to get 7 miles of quality.  Just like yesterday the temperature was nice but it was a bit windy.  Hopefully the well will be full for Get In Gear now since I didn't take anything out of it tonight.

Wednesday evening run in the rain for the second week in a row.  This one wasn't quite as miserable since it was a little warmer.  Did the Crosby Farms loop.  I didn't see a single other person down there, which has to be a first.  Legs were a little tired, but ok.

Ran at lunch.  I decided to do a noon/night double today so that I could sleep in.  I was hoping the rain might let up by the time I went, but it didn't so I got wet.  Threw in 4 x 30 seconds strides towards the end.
Double around St Thomas after work.  Felt alright.  Glad it stopped raining.
Pre race run from work at 12:30.  Legs feeling pretty good, hopefully they stay that way.

Ran down to Crosby Farms with Adrian.  Pouring rain for the first 40 minutes, then it let up towards the end of the run.  My legs felt pretty unresponsive, so that combined with the weather led me to call it a day at 8 rather than continuing on to hit 10.  Nice to run with Adrian; I probably wouldn't have run today if I had to go by myself.
I need to start getting regular doubles in again, but I laid in bed too long this morning.  Slept lousy last night and felt like I was hungover when I got up.
Ran on river road in a light rain.  Wasn't all that bad, especially compared to what I ran in yesterday.  Legs felt surprisingly good, which is always nice.

Tuesday night long run.  For the third day in a row it was raining so I wasn't real excited about doing it, but the conditions didn't end up being that bad.  The rain ended up letting up about 15 minutes after I started.  I started running from my apartment at 6:10 and went to Run N Fun to meet the group.  They were leaving just as the store was coming into view, so I timed it pretty well.  Kotek was leading the group...a couple blocks in he went straight and everybody else turned left (don't know if this was planned or not).  He didn't turn around.  We ended up doing Lilydale.  Talked about racing and D3 track with Kieser for most of the run.  Kieser ran back towards my apartment with me and then turned back at Randolph & Hamline.  When I passed the SPA track I got the idea to throw in a mile at around marathon pace.  I decided to go for it and ran a 5:23.  It actually felt pretty comfortable considering I was wearing a jacket, tights, and wet trainers and was 15+ miles into my run at this point.  I then took Randolph all the way down to the river and did a short add on to get 19.  Never ran out of energy.  Good run.
Ran OAB on West River.  Legs were tired from yesterday, probably didn't crack 7:00 pace tonight.  Wild won 5-4 in OT!

Ran from my office at noon.  This was probably a little long for in the middle of the work day, but I didn't have much to do so whatever.  For the first time since Saturday I didn't get rained on.  Made it to the Crosby Farms entrance and then turned around after running in the woods for a few minutes.  Legs felt good, good run.
Lake St to Ford after work.  Legs felt good again.  6 strides.

56 minutes sub-tempo

Since this is my heaviest training week in quite awhile I was dragging all day at work, but I got through this workout alright.  Crossed 9 miles at 51:26...45 seconds slower than I ran when I did something like this a month ago, but I had a lot less cumulative fatigue going into that one.  5:43 average pace is still within the target range.  I felt like I could have kept running this pace for a long time.  If I kept this up for a marathon it'd be a 2:29.
Ran around the arb at Gustavus before Aleta's triathlon.  Great morning for running.

My calf was tight after last night's workout and it wasn't totally gone on this morning's run, so I decided to elliptical this afternoon rather than run.  It's (hopefully) not that big of a deal, but I didn't think an easy run was worth taking any chances for.  Kept the heart rate around 120 and watched some NBA playoffs.
A run on a nice 40-50 degree morning is probably one of the better things in life.

Ran with Kieser and Adrian from my place.  We went out to Nokomis, looped the lake, then ran on some other paths before turning around.  Everything aside from my right calf felt great.  The calf is annoying.  Not sure if I should workout on it tomorrow...I guess I'll decide when the time comes.
Lake St to Ford.  Spent most of the run scheming about how to maximize points at MIACs next weekend.

OAB to the U of M Hospital.  Legs feeling a bit tired, but I got through ok.  Calf/achilles was a bit of a nuisance when going up hills.  Hill repeats might not be in the cards for this week.  If I decide I can't do them I'll probably try something like 15 x 1 minute tomorrow.
I decided to cross train this morning in order to ensure that I could do a quality run tonight.

12 x 1:00 Hard (1:00 jog)
4 x Ford Hill

Oof.  I had forgotten the feeling of doing a faster workout while running high mileage.  I wanted to get the legs going though so I don't totally lose the ability to run sub 5 pace before Brian Kraft.  This wasn't actually that hard; I just did not feel a lot of pop (as would be expected).  I probably started around 10K pace and worked down to around 3K pace.

Ran down to Fort Snelling.  It looks like there are a bunch of nice trails down there; I'll definitely be heading that way more often.  It was a pretty nice night and my legs felt decent after taking this morning off.  Went bowling afterward with Dan and Cassens and rolled 2 x 92.  Looks like I need some practice.
Ran in a light rain.  I felt good and wished I could have done my longer run of the day.

Got home from work and flipped on the NFL Draft.  Pick #5 was on the clock so I decided I'd watch until the Vikings picked because I wanted to see if they took Manziel.  Unfortunately they didn't; I was hoping they would since that would have made the local sports talk radio shows fun to listen to this summer.  The second their pick was in I turned off the TV and left, hoping to be back in time for the Packers pick (#21).  Did an easy 10 on the river road.  The weather was pretty nice...I bet they could have done the TC 1 Mile (or at the very least still had the two pro races).  Timing worked out well because when I got back the Packers were on the clock.  Welcome to the team, Ha Ha Clinton-Dix.

3 miles @ marathon pace (5:25-5:30)
1/2 mile jog
3 miles @ marathon pace (5:25-5:30)
1/2 mile jog
2 miles @ marathon pace (5:25-5:30)

It was really windy...thought for a minute about pushing this back another day, but I can't do the workout and a 20 miler on back to back days and I don't want to have to do a long run on a weeknight right now when every day holds the potential for me being at work until 9 PM, so today was the day.  This was also my first time running with my GPS watch.  I started at the roundabout by Minnehaha Park and ran out three miles, came back for the next three, then did an out and back for the last two.  Felt good and finished feeling like I can do a lot more running at this pace (which is good, since the race is over 3 times as long as the 8 miles of quality that I did).

Slogged through a slow Franklin to Ford loop in the morning before going to MIACs.  Legs were tired; hopefully they'll come back for tomorrow.  I tried to run in the grass as much as possible.  Weather was nice.  Aleta passed me just before the Lake St bridge as she was finishing up a 60 mile bike ride, then I intersected with Nick Ross a little later.  I yelled at him that he was probably running a minute per mile faster than I was, but after hearing about his workout it was really more like 2 minutes.  Lots of bikers on West River.

First of three planned 20+ mile runs before Grandma's.  It was a pretty nice day for it...maybe a little humid, but 60 degrees and not too windy.  I started off with a lap around Nokomis, then ran in Fort Snelling for a long time, then finished with an out and back down East River to St Thomas.  For most of the run I felt good and was clipping along at sub 6:15 pace.  The last 15 minutes I was getting worn out, and I also started to become exponentially more irritated with all the people on the path who wouldn't get out of 'my' way.  I need to start practicing with fluids and Gu before the marathon since there's no way I'll be able to race 26.2 miles without taking in any fuel.  I'm pretty happy with this training week.  Probably one more at 90-95, then a down week.

West River 10.  It started lightly raining pretty much right when I walked out the door, then by about 3 miles it was pouring.  I was glad to be wearing a long sleeve shirt.  My legs felt good, which was surprising after how beat I was at the end of yesterday's run.  I also did a 2 mile morning shakeout just to get moving.

Lake St to Ford.  Felt alright.  The calf soreness that was bugging me last week has been gone for several days, but my achilles felt funny walking around my apartment after the run.  Hopefully it's nothing to worry about.

Ran a lap around Nokomis and then along Minnehaha Creek.  It was windy.  25 minutes into the run I started getting pretty hungry, and then all I could think about for the rest of the run was food.  Did strides afterward and did not feel much pop.
Kind of tired this morning after staying up to watch the Wild.

Workout Wednesday at Macalester.  Temperature was perfect but had to deal with some swirling winds.  Legs definitely felt flat/tired and I don't think I could have gone much faster without really ramping up the effort, but other than that this was pretty easy.  When I finished my pulse was around 160 (pretty low for the end of an interval workout); three minutes later it was down to 90.

Ran from my office to 35E and back.  The past month or so I've been unintentionally making a habit of doing longer runs during lunch on Thursdays.  Legs felt ok.  When I first got down by the river a guy started screaming at me about how me was going to jump in (which would be a bad idea since in that area there is no easy way to get out), then when I ignored him he started screaming f bombs at me.  He was still standing in the same spot when I was coming back, so I crossed the street a block early to avoid running past him again.
Double after work.  Felt ok, kind of hungry.

Ran in Fort Snelling.  After three straight nights of not getting enough sleep I was tired this morning.  Hopefully with a decent night tonight I can get through tomorrow's workout alright.  I'm looking forward to taking a down week next week.

In Appleton for the weekend.  Stuff came up and my schedule had to be re-arranged, meaning I wasn't able to do the workout today.  Instead I ran the Xavier loop that I do pretty much every time I'm home.  Felt fine.

10 mile sub-tempo run

My plan was to run the first 7 miles of this at sub-tempo (5:40ish) and then close with a couple sub 5:30s.  I did two laps around my old morning 5 mile loop since I didn't want to have to stop at all.  The first lap was easy despite a decent amount of wind.  Every mile was in the 5:37-5:42 range.  Around mile 6 I first started to get the feeling that I might run out of gas before the end.  At 7 miles I sped up and ran a 5:26, then for the 9th mile I turned straight into the wind, and the wind combined with my lack of breakfast blew me up to the tune of around a 5:50 (much harder effort-wise than the 5:40s I was running earlier).  I thought briefly about ending the workout, but I decided that I needed the mental benefits that would come with grinding through another mile when I was low on energy so I finished the run and told myself to just get back under 5:45.  Shuffled through a laughably slow cooldown afterward.  I was still full from last night's dinner when I woke up this morning so all I ate was a granola bar, then I started the run 30 minutes later.  I need to be smarter than that.  All in all, not the run I was hoping for, but still a decently productive workout.

Took a needed down day.  Super windy out there, but fortunately the afternoon thunderstorms had stopped.  I felt decent...better than I expected to.  I'm shooting for 75-80 miles this week, which should be pretty easy to get with a 20 miler in there.  Huge dinner tonight.

Ran on Summit.  I stuffed myself with Pizza Luce at lunch and then had some cheese curds and beer at a happy hour 60-90 minutes before I went running, so my stomach did not feel good for the first half of the run.  Things eventually settled down.  My legs felt good after yesterday's easy day.
Sathre and Jacobs were running by my apartment when I walked outside, so I ran with them for about 2.5 miles then turned around.  Good morning run.

This went well.  I did 6 x 5 minutes at what was supposed to be half marathon effort along the path by my office.  I probably should have just done mile repeats since I was running 5:00-5:05 pace on all of the intervals.  Felt kind of tired from life as a whole during the day and on my warmup, but during the workout I felt really strong.  I wish I could run a half next week as I think I could run a pretty good one right now.
From work at lunch.  Really nice day outside.  Legs were a little tired from last night, but nothing terrible.  Hopefully I'm ready for a 20 miler in about 17 hours.

20 miler #2.  I told my boss I'd be late getting in today because I wanted to do this in the morning so that I could have an extra half day to recover from it before Monday's 5K.  Weather was pretty much ideal...50 degrees, sunny, no wind.  Hopefully we can get something like this on race day next month.  I bumped into Dan and Kampf 5 minutes into the run, so I joined them for the next 65-70 minutes.  We did a Lake St Bridge loop to St Thomas, ran a lap on the UST track, ran up Summit to Macalester, ran a lap on the Mac track, and then went over to SPA and did a lap there.  When we got back to Minnehaha Park those guys split off to head home and I continued on to Fort Snelling for my last 9 miles.  When I finished I was tired, but I felt like I could have kept going and I definitely wasn't as trashed as when I did this 12 days ago.  Being able to run with other people for a good chunk of the run made it a lot easier mentally.

Ran with Kieser, Kotek, Ruter, Lars, and Eli on a route that Kieser put together.  We started off running the first couple miles on a sandy trail, ended up in downtown St Paul, then worked our way back to the starting point.  First run of the year in 80 degree weather.  Legs felt alright on the run, then not very good on the four strides that I did afterward.  Kind of what I'd expect for the day after a 20 miler.  Nice to run with a good group.

Paul got 2nd in the 1500 at nationals (almost won!), Grant was 4th, and Jake was 11th.  Great way for them to cap off the best year the Big O has ever had.

Lake St to Ford.  I was going to do more than this today, but I ran further than originally planned yesterday and I've got work to do tomorrow in an absolutely stacked race so I decided to just do a standard pre-meet.  Legs felt ok.  It feels like summer outside; have to start adapting to that.  I got some funny looks from bikers while I was doing ballistics.

I was fairly sure that I was going to double back tonight...wasn't really planning on going this far, but since I didn't really feel that beat up from the race and I'm busy tomorrow I figured I'd make today a high mileage day and then I can take tomorrow pretty easy.  Ran Ford to Franklin at 8 PM.  The humidity had broken a little bit from where it was this afternoon, so that was nice.  Legs felt fine...wouldn't have guessed that I raced this morning.

Easy run over to Fort Snelling and back.  I tried to go exploring on some of the side paths once I got over there, but I never really got anywhere.  Legs felt ok.  It's going to be a long week...it's not really ideal that the busiest week of the whole year at work and the highest mileage week of my buildup are overlapping, but I should be able to get through it.
Morning run.  Tired this morning, need to go to bed at night rather than watch extra innings Brewers games.
Crosby Farms loop, plus some extra at the beginning.  Legs were tired tonight.

10K in 33:17
5:00 jog
Mile in 4:58
2:00 jog
800 in 2:30
1:00 jog
400 in 69

Decent workout.  Felt tired all day but didn't really have any trouble doing this.  I won't be able to run 5:20 pace for the marathon, but I already knew that.  Hopefully it's cooler than this for the race and the allergen count is lower.

Ran from my office at the end of the day.  I was originally planning to run at lunch but ended up going to Chipotle with a co-worker instead.  Legs felt like lead this evening.  Earlier this week I was wishing I was running Dam to Dam tomorrow, but with the weather and the way my legs feel I'm glad I'm not since I'd probably throw down a 1:15.

Because of the weather (it feels like August outside) and my legs feeling sluggish I decided it would be better to split today's miles into two runs in order to be more ready for tomorrow's long run.  This morning I ran to Nokomis, did a lap around the lake, then ran home.  Legs were better than yesterday, but not great.
Easy 5 in a light rain after spending the afternoon at work.  Wore the Pegasus 31s for the first time.

This was the longest run I'm going to do before Grandma's.  I would guess that I really covered 22.5+ miles, but I'll round it down to be safe (and to balance out some other runs).  For my confidence's sake I needed it to go well, so I'm glad that it did.  I started off running down West River until I ran out of path, then I turned around, crossed the Stone Arch Bridge, ran up the transit way to TCF Bank Stadium, ran around the U of M campus for awhile looking for a drinking fountain, then came home via East River.  It thunderstormed pretty much all night, which made for a lousy night of sleep but cooled things down a little bit.  Unfortunately the Minneapolis Marathon was a casualty of the storm.  I saw a bunch of participants out running the course anyways.  Took a Gu at around 100 minutes and didn't have any problems with it.  Energy wise I felt great the entire time I was out there.  I think I felt better at mile 20 than I did at mile 3, and at the end of the run I was still running 6:00-6:10 pace.  It's nice to know that I could have easily cruised a low 2:40s marathon today, at the end of my biggest week and after feeling like crap for most of it.  Hopefully after Grandma's this will still be the longest run of my life time-wise, but we'll see.

I was tentatively planning on taking a day off at some point this week since I took one around this time in my buildup for Houston and I felt like it helped me quite a bit.  Figured today made sense since it's the day after a big long run and I'll probably be at work until midnight.  From tomorrow through next Monday I'm going to do one more ~95 mile week with a couple of workouts, then I keep going back and forth on what exactly I want to do in the last 10 days leading up to Grandma's.

I left work just before 2 AM last night and told my boss on the way out that I would not be coming in today.  Slept in, bummed around for a little while, then did Lake St to Ford at 11:30 AM.  Felt alright, probably about as good as I ever feel after staying up so late.

Flashback to college...ran with Adrian, Anders, Schwock, and Tim.  This was the first time I've run with Schwock in over 2 years.  We ran around Isles and Cedar.  The pace was pretty relaxed, which was nice.  It'd be fun to do more runs with this group.

2 x 5.5 miles

Did this on the Lake St to Ford loop, going the usual way the first time and the other way (Ford to Lake) the second.  The goal was to do the first loop at ~5:40 pace, then the second one at 5:25-5:30.  It took a little while to find the right pace on the first loop but the second half I split 2:49 for several half miles in a row.  Felt controlled.  My rest was about 4 minutes jogging with some water.  The second loop I was in the mid to high 5:20s going down West River, then I ran a 5:44 on the mile from the Lake St Bridge up the St Thomas hill (yuck), then I brought it back down to a 5:24 and 5:23 to finish.  For the most part I felt decent.  I'm still trying to wrap my head around the idea of racing 26 miles.
I'm going to the Brewers v Twins game tonight so I had to run this morning, which meant I did 24 miles in about 14 hours.  Legs were tired from last night's workout.
Easy shakeout.  Legs feel better than yesterday, but I once again didn't get much sleep last night.
10 miles on river road.  Felt alright.
Ran a lap around Lake Nokomis in an absolute downpour.

1 x 5:00 (2:00 jog)
2 x 3:00 (2:00 jog)
4 x 1:00 (1:00 jog)

Pretty easy fartlek, just wanted to get a little something in.  I was going to do this in Crosby Farms, but as I was headed that way I realized the paths down there would probably be flooded so I did it on Shepard instead.  I'd guess that I started with about a 5:00 mile and then got a little bit faster on the shorter intervals.  Watched the Belmont afterward and California Chrome didn't win...bummer.
Ran out and back on West River.  Felt more tired than I thought I would, not sure why.

It feels kind of weird to call 17 a long run when some of my workouts recently have been almost that long.  This went pretty well though.  I met up with Grant at the bottom of Summit and ran about 10 with him, then added on.  Good conversation about training and running in general.  I'm still feeling a little tired...hopefully I'm not getting sick.
Easy run in Fort Snelling and then 5 strides.  Legs felt good.

3 x 3 miles (1/2 mile jog in between)
#1: 5:28, 5:20, 5:23 (16:11)
#2: 5:21, 5:31, 5:33 (16:25)
#3: 5:28, 5:29, 5:24 (16:21)

Last big workout before Grandma's.  When I got home from work I was feeling tired and really didn't want to do this, so I borrowed a page from Dan Greeno's book and took a caffeinated gel.  Let that sit for a half hour or so and then headed out.  I started the workout from the roundabout by Minnehaha Park.  That's not a good place to warm up for a workout because there were a ton of people milling around and nobody was paying any attention to where they were walking.  Anyways, starting off I felt really good.  The first repeat was ridiculously easy and felt like I was jogging.  I might have gotten a little too excited...dropping a series of ~5:20 miles early in the marathon will not turn out well so hopefully I won't do that.  The last half of the second interval was up the three hills on East River.  Good practice for Lemon Drop.  On the last three miles I tried to just maintain even effort and not press to get to the end.  I felt pretty good when I finished.  Total time for 10 miles was 55:46, which is 2 seconds faster than I ran at TC10 last fall.  The hay's in the barn...now it's taper time.
Really easy run on Shepard.  I was the captain of the 7:20 pace train this evening.

West River 10.  Really tired getting up; with the race in one week I need to start making sure that I get some sleep.  That said once I got going I felt decent.  Pretty nice weather, 55ish and no wind.  For a couple miles on the way out there was a guy about a half mile up the road that kind of looked like Burseth...I never caught the guy so I'll never know if it actually was him or not.

Double and a couple of strides after work.  I was going to be pressed for time to begin with and getting stuck in traffic on my way home meant I had no time to spare.  Went to Victory 44 for dinner.  Not in any hurry to go back.

2 x 5:00 @ 10K Effort (3:00 jog)
4 x 0:30 @ Mile/3K Effort (1:00 jog)

Easy fartlek.  It thunderstormed pretty much all day but when I went out around noon I caught a break for the most part.  It was really windy, so I did the intervals with the wind at my back.  On the 5:00ers I could tell that my legs were still a little tired from Wednesday.  With about one minute left in my cooldown the storm kicked up again and I almost got knocked over by a gust of wind that must have been 40+ mph.

Late morning run...started with a lap around Nokomis then came back to the river and did a Lake St loop.  Nokomis is overflowing onto the pedestrian path in several places so hopefully we don't get too much more rain.  I didn't feel all that great but I was still running 6:20-6:30 pace.  Got chafed on the inside of my thighs...that's the third time that's happened when I've worn those new blue Run N Fun shorts (out of the 4-5 times I've worn them), so I won't be wearing those for Grandma's.

Franklin to Ford.  Weird to think that this will be the longest run I do all week.  I didn't feel very good...wasn't terrible but especially on the hills my legs felt a little weak.  I went to bed early last night and got up at 6:30 this morning in an attempt to reset my sleep cycle.
Watched the US v Ghana match (BOOM!) and then got a light second run in during a thunderstorm.  Didn't feel very good, but I'm not worried about it yet.  Also did a few strides.

I was supposed to work out tonight but I had a headache and felt lethargic and couldn't motivate myself to do it.  Just did an easy run over to Fort Snelling instead and I'll do the workout tomorrow morning.  Not a big deal.

Morning workout on the St Thomas track.  Went through the opening that Kampf showed me a couple weeks ago.  It's super humid outside; I was dripping sweat after just the warmup.  The 2 mile felt alright.  I threw in an 82 on the third lap but brought it back down just fine.  I was two seconds off on the 1200, but I'll blame the humidity.  The effort was where I wanted it to be.  My legs still don't feel amazing, so I'm hoping they'll get there over the next 72 hours.  I've got to be positive...I've worked too hard to let the demons take me down before Saturday.

Easy run from my office at lunch.  It was humid and windy, but not raining.  My legs felt much better than they had been feeling the past several days.

Also noticed that I am at exactly 2,000 miles for the year, which puts me on pace for just under 4,300.  Taking next week off will hurt that pace a little bit, but if I can avoid any extended time off I'll get my biggest year ever (which makes sense, since the last time I went a full calendar year without at least one extended break was 2009).

Easy jog.  I didn't feel very good, but I rarely do when the dew point is in the upper 60s.  Drove to Duluth in the afternoon and felt like I got into a decent racing mindset when we got up there.  Tomorrow I see what I can do over 26.2.  Here goes.

Pre Race

Had kind of a restless 'night' of sleep as I kept waking up and thinking my alarm was going to go off soon.  Finally got up at 4:15 and had a bagel with peanut butter, then got my stuff together and headed over to catch the shuttle.  Ate a Clif Bar on the bus (2 hours before race time).  It was not comforting to take a 45 minute bus ride to the starting line and realize that I now had to run all of that distance in order to get back to town.  When we got there I worked my way through the crowd to the elite tent.  It was about 50 degrees with light winds and a little bit of mist from time to time.  40 minutes out I went for a slow 10 minute jog, then did ballistics, and maybe 3 light strides.  Got to the corral between 7:35 and 7:40.  For some reason they started us 5 minutes late, but finally we were off.

Race

Until the day before the race I had not been planning on wearing my GPS watch, but on Friday I decided that I would wear it so that a) I could monitor my pace early and make sure I didn't get out way too hard, and b) I'd be able to have all of my splits at the end.  It was a good thing that I wore it because most of the elites were out super hard and I would have gotten sucked into that as well.  Went through the mile in 5:21, running by myself with a ton of people (including several women) ahead of me.  I just settled into a rhythm and tried to stay relaxed and roll.  By 2 miles people were already coming back, and even at 4 miles I started seeing people walking on the side of the road.  I was passing people at pretty regular intervals, and except for some guy that I caught up to that then played cat and mouse with me for a couple miles I didn't get passed by anyone until mile 22.  For most of the first half I felt like I was floating.  I was expecting to see basically no fans out there, but I thought that there were a decent number of cheering sections (not quite like Twin Cities, but it wasn't too lonely).  I gave a wave to Lisa Skildum and Zeke at the 5 mile mark, then I saw Grant at mile 6 and told him, 'Only 20 miles to go.'  My 'best case scenario' goal before the race was to run 2:23, and I came through the half right on pace at 1:11:29, but since the second half of the course is tougher than the first I figured at this point that I wasn't going to hit that so I started focusing on 2:24-2:25.

Miles 17 and 18 I ran a 5:35 and a 5:37.  I knew that if I slowed down anymore that it would really hurt my time and I hung on for one more mile, but after mile 19 the wheels started to come off a bit.  At the 19 mile mark I came to a complete stop to grab my bottle and starting up again was tough.  It's tough to describe exactly how I was feeling during miles 20-24.  My cardio was fine, mentally I never got the light headed/bonking feeling, and I felt like I had plenty of energy, but it was just tough to move my legs very fast.  I think it was part physical weakness, part mental weakness (from not knowing what to expect at this point, having never done this before), and part the fact that this is the toughest part of the course.  By the time I got to the top of Lemon Drop I felt like I was dying and when I saw a 5:59 split I wasn't sure if I was even going to break 2:30.  Max caught me at around 23 and tried to get me rolling again.  I hung just off of him.  Once I got into downtown I saw a bunch of friends cheering (the two people I most vividly remember are Anders Bowman and Adrian), and I realized that I was actually going to finish and got a bit of a second wind.  With a mile to go I thought I might still be able to break 2:26, but I ended up being just over.  Coming down the finishing straight was a pretty exhilarating feeling, even if my legs were way too tired to sprint. 

Post Race

When I first crossed the line I still felt alright (probably from adrenaline), but by the time I got my bag a couple of minutes later my body was in a world of hurt.  My hips were the worst part and I could not walk normally.  Found Aleta, talked briefly with some other people, and then eventually made the walk to the shuttle.  The shuttle dropped us off on the opposite side of the mall from where I wanted to be and I proceeded to walk across the parking lot at about 2 miles per hour.  Once I got a shower, drank a bunch of water, and ate some solid food I came around quite a bit.  We stopped twice on the drive back to the cities so that I could move a bit and stretch, but by the evening I felt significantly better than I had immediately after finishing.

Thoughts

Overall I am happy with my performance.  My time goal was 2:23-2:25, and I wasn't that far off.  My main objective in doing this was to get the experience of running a marathon so that I can be better prepared for it in the future, and I feel like I learned quite a bit.  I now know what it feels like to get 18-20 miles in and still have a good amount of running left before you're done.  Training wise I came into this off of a fairly short marathon specific cycle.  That was ok for this one, but for my next marathon I will do 10-12 weeks instead of 8.  I liked the course, although I don't think it's as fast as some people claim.  There are plenty of rolling hills out there.  I took Gu at miles 9 and 19.  Didn't have any problems with it and I'm sure it helped me.  Maybe next time I should do a third?  I need to practice more with fluids before my next one, as most of the times I took water I either spilled most of it or was only able to get a sip or two.  Fortunately it was only 50 degrees so drinking a ton of fluids wasn't essential.  Overall I had fun out there and it was awesome to see so many Oles, both racing and cheering.  Also great to get a ton of positive comments afterward.

Rest Day #1

Yesterday at mile 2 someone was holding a sign that said, 'Just think: You don't have to train tomorrow.'  Yup, that's about right.  Got up before 5 AM for the second day in a row, watched Aleta's triathlon, took a 2+ hour nap, bummed around for a little while, and watched the USA v Portugal match.  My legs (mainly my quads) are definitely shot today.

My legs feel a lot better already.  I'm still going to take the whole work week off from running though.  In the spirit of the old 'week of fat' from college I got some Taco Bell for dinner, and the people in the car ahead of me paid for my meal for some reason.
Rest

Rest day #4.  I'm already starting to think about race plans for the fall.  Right now I'd say I'm leaning strongly towards the Cal International Marathon on December 7th.  The tradeoff with running this would be that I wouldn't be able to do the Houston Half again, and I really enjoyed that race/trip last winter.  The nice thing is that I don't have to make a final decision for a couple of months.
Bad day
Last planned day of rest.  Hopefully going to start running again tomorrow.

First day back.  Did Lake St to Ford.  It was nice to run again, but I've barely eaten or slept in the past 36 hours and I could definitely feel the effects.  Also have a lot going through my mind.  I was surprised how many people were out running early on a Saturday morning.

Met Dan at Minnehaha and we did a loop over to Fort Snelling.  My calves were sore before the run and during the first mile, but they loosened up.  Just usual 'starting back up' stuff.  It was humid; I'm guessing that's here to stay now.  Nice to run with Dan and get a little break from my thoughts.

8 miles with Grant.  We started from his place on Grand and did a loop that went up Summit, down to Run N Fun, took Randolph all the way to the river, and then came back up St Clair.  Couple of good hills on this loop.  Legs felt decent.  Did some pedestal when I got home.

Ran with Adrian and Pojke from my place after the disappointing soccer game.  We just did an out and back on East River.  Felt pretty good and liked the 65 degree weather.  We got some Chipotle afterward.  I'd have to go back through my log to be sure but I think the last time I ran with other people on three consecutive days was when I was in college.

West River 10.  The last section leading up to where I usually turn around was blocked off, but there was no actual construction going on so I ran around the barrier.  Thought about how the weather right now is pretty much ideal 100 mile week weather.  Unfortunately when I get up to serious volume it will probably be 90 degrees and humid every day.  Oh well, just enjoy this while it's here.  Legs felt alright.

Lake St to Ford in the morning.  I'm traveling tonight so I wanted this out of the way first thing.  The run seemed to take forever; it felt like river road had somehow accordioned out.  I also did strides for the first time since before Grandma's.  On the first one my right achilles felt a little funny, but then that disappeared for the rest of them.  I need to start eating more.

I'm at my family's place in Door County for the first time since 2010.  Started off Independence Day with a run from the house to downtown Egg Harbor and back.  There were a ton of people in town getting set for the parade (which didn't start for another couple of hours when I ran through).  The weather was really nice and my legs felt good, so good run.  The hill from Highway G up to the Horseshoe Bay property (a tough half mile of climbing) got me sucking some wind.
5 miles around Horseshoe Bay and then six strides.  Nothing really to say about this one.

Originally I was thinking I would go to Peninsula State Park to run, but then I decided I didn't want to drive 20 minutes each way for a 9 miler so I just ran from the house.  The temperature was cool but it was humid so I still had a good sweat going.  Legs felt good.  Watched the Wimbledon final afterward - Djokovic over Federer in an exciting five setter.

Ran early with Grant - we met at river road and Summit at 6:10.  We went over to Fort Snelling.  My plan was that we would do the loop that Dan and I did last weekend, but I couldn't remember where exactly the bridge to cross Highway 5 was and we didn't have a lot of extra time to spend looking for it so we just turned around and went back the way we came.  I'll have to take another pass at this run later this week and try to figure it out.  By the time we got back to my apartment we had hit about the time what we were looking for so we called it a day and I drove him back to his place.  The last 10 minutes I was starting to feel a little tired.  I've lost a little fitness but it'll come back quick.

Ran with a huge group from Run N Fun on a loop that Kieser made up that went east on Shepard/Warner, through some parks, and then came back through downtown St Paul.  I did six strides when we got back to the store.  Legs and cardio both felt pretty good and it was nice to be around the group.  Good pizza afterward at Skinner's.
Ran in Fort Snelling.  After fairly quick runs the past two days I made sure to keep things really relaxed this morning.  I was tired getting out of bed, but not on the run.
Easy double after work.  Saw a woman changing her baby's diaper in the grass at the bottom of Summit...kind of an odd place to do that.

First workout since the marathon.  Did it at UST.  Nothing real hard; I just wanted to wake up a few energy systems that have been dormant for a little while.  I felt about how I'd expect to on an intro workout - not real sharp or strong, but not struggling to hit the paces.  Weather was great for July.  It'd be nice if I could get a full night of sleep sometime soon.
It looks like this site is finally working again, so now I can log my past week of training.  Ran with Grant on river road this evening.  We took it pretty easy.

Starting to build the long run back up again.  It was only about 73 degrees outside this morning, but the humidity was basically 100%.  Ran in Fort Snelling and then added a bit on river road to get over 100 minutes.  I started feeling a little hungry 30 minutes into the run but somewhat surprisingly I held up alright the whole time.  Four strides at the end.

When I was driving around in the afternoon I saw that the gate at the top of the Magoffin hill was open for the first time in a month, so I decided to try to run in Crosby Farms.  After just a couple minutes down there I abandoned that mission, as the paths are definitely not runnable.  There are a bunch of trees down and there are puddles and mud everywhere.  Ended up going out and back up Summit to Macalester.  I felt really good this evening.

40 minutes sub-tempo

Easy sub-tempo run in the rain.  I went back and forth on the warmup about how long of a workout I should do and eventually settled on 40 being fine.  Pace was in the 5:40s, which felt really controlled (as it should since I just ran over three times this distance at a faster pace a few weeks ago).  It felt good to do something a little harder and blow off some steam after the boss busted my balls at work.  Six fast strides afterward.

Ran around Nokomis, which is overflowing to the point where pretty much all of the pedestrian path is under water.  Legs were a little tired this morning, but nothing terrible.  This 'September in July' weather continues, as it was in the 50s this morning.  Went to the All Star Game in the evening - Mike Trout MVP, 2 long ovations for Jeter, Ramirez and Lucroy each with 2 hits, AL wins 5-3.  Awesome time.

Since I was up late last night for the All Star Game I decided I'd just do one longer run today rather than a double.  I ran out on West River until the point where it was blocked off, then came back on the trails that went through the trees, then added on a little at the end.  Bumped into Adrian, Frankie, and Pojke, so I ran with them for a few minutes.  The first 15-20 minutes felt like they took about an hour, then after that I felt good the rest of the time.
Morning run.  Felt fine.

It's been quite awhile since I did a 200s workout.  I ended up doing it at Minnehaha Academy since none of the tracks I usually use were available.  Lots of rest in between intervals; the focus was on running reasonably fast without straining.  I started off too fast with a 31.3, then settled into 32.x, which felt about right.  Hit 31 again on four of the last six.  I was really surprised by how fast the last 300 was - not that 43.4 is really something to brag about, but before I did it I told myself that I would be happy to run a 46.
Legs were stiff from last night's workout.  Combine that with getting out the door behind schedule and I decided a mile in that I'd go short and then run again tonight.

I wasn't real excited about running after work, but I got out for an easy six on Shepard.  Thought about training.  I've got a good idea now of what I want to do during the 3 weeks between the 15K and Victory.  I'll probably end up mostly just winging it until the 15K.

Long run at French Regional Park in Plymouth with Kieser, Marty, and Jake.  The route was alright.  Really hilly, which made it tough but was probably good for me.  Last night I got drunk for the first time in a couple of years - I went out planning on having a beer or two and then going home when everyone else went to the bar but that's not what happened.  I didn't feel too terrible this morning and avoided really blowing up on the run, but it was definitely a little rough.  The last 20-30 minutes I was ready to stop.  On uphills I started falling a stride or two behind the other guys.  Kieser eventually started gapping us; he was feeling good.  As we were coming up on 90 minutes and we hadn't gotten back to the park yet I started getting worried that we were lost.  Marty, Jake, and I decided to call it a day when we got back to the cars rather than adding on.  Nice to run long with the group, I'd like to do it again sans hangover.  Had lunch at Panera with Pez afterward.

Drove out a couple miles so that I could run on a slightly different section of river road.  Ended up turning around shortly after the Stone Arch Bridge.  The humidity is going up, but it wasn't too bad yet.  Supposed to have a triple digit heat index tomorrow.
Got the main run for the day done early since the heat index is supposed to reach 100 this afternoon.  Out and back on river road.  My legs didn't feel that good, especially on uphills.

Lake St to Ford at about 8:30 PM.  Roughly 13 hours in between runs today.  It had cooled off a little but the dew point was still about 75.  Saw Grant attempting to run a workout.  My legs felt really good; didn't expect that.

12 mile run
4 x Ford Hill
Short cooldown

I'm only doing one real workout this week but tonight ended up being a solid 'medium' effort.  Met up with Grant and ran most of the first 12 miles with him.  It was one of those nights where we were cruising but neither one of us felt the need to slow down.  We split a bunch of miles in the 6:00-6:10 range.  Did the hills at the end and they felt pretty good.  After the past couple of days' humidity today's dew point of 57 felt awesome.

After work I drove over to Minneapolis and parked just off of Hennepin on the east side of the river, then went for a short run before Torchlight started.  My legs felt pretty flat, I think mostly because I need new shoes.  Saw Jack about 20 minutes in and stopped to talk to him for a little bit.  The Torchlight course is point to point so I was only able to make it to two spots, but it was still fun to watch.  Kieser had a really impressive race and ended up taking it, then the other guys sealed up the team title.  Had a good time socializing with everyone afterward at the finish line and then at Mill City and Bulldog.
Easy morning run.  Really tired getting up this morning after two short nights in a row.  Hopefully tonight's workout goes smoothly.

3 x 5:00 Cruise Intervals (1:00 rest, 2:30 set rest)
3 x 2:00 @ 5K Effort (2:00 jog rest)
3 x 0:30 @ < mile='' effort='' (0:30='' jog=''>

On my warmup I saw a high school team doing a 5K time trial on Shepard Road.  Every single kid was wearing spandex shorts and no shirt, and more than half of them were carrying ipods.  With regards to my workout, it was kind of rough.  I ran alright but didn't feel very good doing it.  Looking at my eating and sleeping since Tuesday's run I had it coming.  Still got some work in, now moving on.

Franklin to Ford.  After watching pretty much everyone at my office slide out early I decided to follow suit so that I could get to Run N Fun and get new shoes.  Definitely felt a difference.  Kept things relaxed.  Hoping for a high mileage weekend.

Grant wanted to do a tempo at Lake Harriet and needed a ride over there, so I went with him.  We did one lap together for his warmup, then split.  It seemed like every person in Minneapolis was on the lakes this morning so I ended up doing a lot of my run in the surrounding neighborhoods.  It was really humid for 9 AM, but I felt pretty good.

Ben Jacobs invited me to a Twins game at about 2:30 and the game started at 6, so I got out the door for run #2 just after 3.  Stomach wasn't feeling great from lunch, but this was a real relaxed run so it was fine.  Strides afterward.  Sathre, Jacobs, and I walked all over Minneapolis after the game to watch the Aquatennial fireworks and then we stood at the train station for a half hour waiting for the light rail.  My legs were killing me by the end of the night.  Stuffed myself with food before bed in hopes of rallying for the long run.

Long run with Grant, Kieser, Easker, Jake, Ryan Mugan, Alex Ciesielski, and Ryan Peterson.  This was a little longer and a little faster than I was planning on, but that happens sometimes.  Kieser mapped out a route around Vadnais Lake.  I thought it was a pretty nice loop.  Couple of hills but not constantly rolling.  We ran by a bunch of really nice houses.  Beautiful weather with the temperature in the upper 60s.  We started off relaxed, but by halfway we were cruising.  The second hour was pretty steady around 6:00 pace and then we threw in a couple 5:45-5:50s towards the end.  I was only planning on going about 17, but since I felt good I decided to just go the whole way with Kieser, Easker, and Grant.  I think I'm going to adjust my plan for this coming week as after this I don't really need a formal sub-tempo run on Tuesday.  Got some Perkins afterward but my stomach wasn't feeling the best so I had some trouble getting the food down.  Fun morning, and definitely a much more quality run than I would have gotten on my own.

After a 35 mile weekend, and especially yesterday's run, an easy day today was in order.  Ran out and back 10 on river road and kept the pace really relaxed.  I could tell that my legs were tired, but they weren't real destroyed.  Another nice 63 degree morning.

Easy run on West River on another 60 degree morning.  Felt great.  I've gone to bed by 10:30 each of the past two nights; maybe I'll keep doing that.  Saw Dan hammering at what looked like about 5:00 pace.  Moderate workout tonight.

2 sets of 1-2-3-2-1 (2 min jog after 3 min intervals and between sets, otherwise 1 min)

Crosby Farms is finally open!  Haven't run down there in over 2 months other than about 5 minutes a couple of weeks ago, so it was nice to go someplace 'new'.  I did a longer warmup (30 minutes) and then just rolled into the fartlek without any stopping.  Started off at around half marathon effort and moved closer to 8K/10K effort towards the end.  It was pretty easy, but a good way to get some quality in.  Finished with six strides.  I signed a new lease today to move up one floor and live in a one bedroom unit - now I just have to wait to hear when exactly I'll be moving (it'll be September 1st +/- 5 days).

Ran out and back on Summit.  It was nice to do most of the run on soft surfaces, but I had to stop at a bunch of lights which is why I don't run there very often.  Legs felt alright.  My hips, upper hamstrings, and lower back were a bit sore.  Must have done something funny while doing core yesterday.

Fort Snelling.  Great weather and after the first 10 minutes my legs loosened up and I felt good.  I saw a Bill Miles doppelganger walking on the path about 4 miles into Fort Snelling.  Still have some minor irritation in my left hamstring.  One hamstring or the other has bothered me for the majority of the past 13 months now.

Easy run from my office.  Wore my new pair of Luna Racers in order to start breaking them in.  A woman passed me on her bike and in between gasps for air said, 'I'm barely going faster than you are!'  Legs felt good.  Went up to the Velodrome afterwards.
My legs felt surprisingly good this morning after a somewhat restless night of sleep.

I repeated the 200s workout from a couple of weeks ago.  Kampf was hanging out at the track when I got there so before warming up I chatted with him for a few minutes.  I ran fairly similar splits (a few more 31s this time) but I didn't feel quite as good.  No straining, but my legs were heavy from recent mileage.  It also seemed like I was always running into the wind, no matter which direction I tried.  Instead of running a hard 300 at the end I decided to just run the last 200 fast.  I ended up banging out a 27.95 and felt like I even had one more gear available.  I probably won't do this workout again this summer but I'm going to keep mixing in some stuff that gets the fast twitch fibers going.  I've got plenty of aerobic strength so getting my muscles used to working at faster paces is what will allow me to get off the plateau I've been on in the 5K and 10K.

Morning Ford to Franklin loop.  I stayed up a little late last night and then had to get up at 7 to get this in, so I was tired starting off but after a few miles I got into it.  The city just painted 'Speed Limit 10 MPH' in a bunch of spots on the path.  Wasn't breaking the rules this morning but that'll happen in a few days.  After the run I got my stuff together and then we went out to A Town's cabin for the day/night.

Ran with Dan, A Town, Thies, and Cassens (rollerblading) from the Hinrichs cabin just outside of Spicer.  We ran on country highways so it kind of reminded me of the roads around Northfield.  Running with the guys made the time pass quickly.  My legs felt decent.  Fun weekend overall at the lake.

Doubled back at 7:30.  This way I'll go long tomorrow evening and then do one run on Tuesday.  Went out and back on Shepard.  A couple miles in the middle turned into an impromptu sub-tempo because I was pissed off.  Hopefully I didn't do anything too dumb.  5 minutes after I got back it started raining pretty hard.

Monday evening 18er.  Did a long out and back across the Stone Arch Bridge and almost to the end of the path.  I didn't want to run quite as fast as we went last Sunday but I held a pretty steady 6:20ish pace for most of the run.  Felt alright.  I wasn't real engaged in the run mentally (thoughts were elsewhere), so that made the last half hour kind of drag on.

From Run N Fun with Kieser.  The group was all spread out tonight with some people doing a tempo and others running with the girls.  We started off doing High Bridge, but about 25 minutes in (by the Holiday station) we got cut off by an extremely long train so we detoured and created an alternate route through downtown.  We tried to cut through a construction site but the second we got around the fence a cop car started driving towards us so we abandoned that.  Good run despite my legs feeling a bit sluggish.  Did strides at the end.  We went to Plum's afterward.  I used to like Summer Shandy but apparently I don't anymore.

The pillow almost won this morning but I got it in.  Felt alright by the second half.

Houston posted standards for the 2015 US Half Champs.  They're significantly tighter than 2014.  I was planning on at least signing up for the 2015 race even though it's only six weeks after CIM since it was such a fun trip last year and I think I could run reasonably well on residual fitness and a couple of post-break tuneup workouts (six weeks from Grandma's would have been last weekend and I could have run a half just fine in decent weather).  I hope to be fit enough to break 1:07 at Des Moines this fall, but it doesn't look like that even gets free lodging anymore and I'm not going to spend ~$1000 to run a race unless I'm going to be ready to run really well in it.  I guess after CIM I'll just take a good break and then get ready for the spring.

25 min tempo
5 min walk/jog
5 x Ford Hill

Decent workout tonight.  Total mileage is a conservative estimate.  I felt like I was running in the correct effort zone for the tempo but I didn't take any splits on it.  Splits don't really matter at this point.  Hills were good; feels like my legs are getting stronger.  The 15K on Sunday should give me some sort of an idea of where I am - plan is to run 5:30s for the first 4 miles and then try to speed up.  If it's really humid I'll stay on 5:30s for longer.

These next 5 days are a bit of a down period.  Sometimes really easy days are the hardest ones to get out the door.  I stayed at work later than normal, then went grocery shopping, then when I got home I felt more like watching TV than running.  I sat down for 5 minutes, then made myself go.  Ran down Minnehaha Parkway to the creek and along there.  Legs felt tired and sluggish.

Easy morning jog.  Felt better than I did yesterday.  Some bro (the look was complete with a headband, armband, and iPod) 'held me off' for about a minute when I was trying to pass him, then he gave up.
Last run with Grant before he heads home for the rest of the summer.  We did an out and back into Fort Snelling.  We kept the pace nice and relaxed and I felt good.  It's pretty warm out.
Easy run and six strides.  I went in Fort Snelling again in order to be in the shade.  Pretty humid.  Legs felt pretty good, so I should have a decent showing tomorrow.

35 minutes elliptical.  Today was a planned day off from running.  Decided to do a short elliptical workout so that my legs wouldn't go 48 hours without moving after yesterday.  I was surrounded by all the stereotypical 'gym guys' in the fitness center (lady walking on the treadmill at 2 miles per hour, guy biking as hard as he can and spraying sweat everywhere, two guys lifting weights and grunting on every rep as if they were trying to pass a kidney stone).  I don't really feel beat up from the race, which is good since I might race again on Thursday.

Unfortunately the day got off to a bad start when I woke up at 4:30 and quickly realized that I would not be getting back to sleep anytime soon.  I read for about an hour and had some breakfast while waiting for the sun to come up, then started my run shortly after 6:00.  It was 58 degrees outside and felt like fall.  Went to Fort Snelling.  I went down a different path than the one I usually run on and this one reminded me of running the lakeshore trails in Madison.  Legs felt ok.  Spent most of the run mulling some stuff over but didn't really come to any conclusions.  Hopefully work doesn't drag too much today.

Lake St to Ford.  Not the best run - low motivation to do it, tired, sluggish legs.  Earlier today I was thinking about doing something like 4-6 x 30 seconds fast, but with the way I was feeling that would have been forcing things so I didn't.  My left knee also felt weird for about 2 miles in the middle.  All whining aside, I felt better after the run than I did before it.

Ran around the lakes with Adrian and Pojke.  I was glad we were taking it easy because my legs felt really sluggish.  Nice running and catching up with Adrian, and he hooked me up with a bike for the progressive dinner on Saturday.

I couldn't come up with any specific workout that I wanted to do this week and after changing my mind about 10 different times I eventually settled on the classic UW workout (although I ran the 400s faster than the 3200 because that seems intuitive to me).  I would have liked to shoot for 9:50 but it was windy and my legs were still feeling pretty dead so I adjusted my goal to 10:00 since I didn't want to strain.  I basically ran even 75s.  The 400s were pretty easy at this pace but trying to go faster would not have been.  Hopefully this weekend I can catch up on sleep and make sure I avoid falling into a hole.

I did this workout (with 8 400s) in 2012 and hit essentially the same times.  At that time I had been doing workouts on the track for several weeks so I was sharper, and I remember thinking that it was a really good workout.  8 days later I ran 31:23 in terrible weather at Get In Gear.  I realize that you have to take more than one workout into account, but this comparison suggests that I'm in a decent spot.  As long as I can get in a good stinger workout next week I'll be ready to run hard at Victory and Alumni.
Plodded along the creek.  I'll do another short run tonight.
Legs didn't feel very good on this one.

Good long run.  We're starting what projects to be a week of high humidity, so I wanted to get up and on the road early.  I didn't get going quite as early as I had hoped, but I started the run just before 8:30 which worked out well enough.  Between the Ragnar Relay and some sort of group long run on the TCM course there were a ton of people out this morning.  I did the same Stone Arch out and back that I did 12 days ago but this time I went out a full hour.  Negative split by about 2.5 minutes on the return, so I was moving.  In terms of aerobic energy I felt great the whole time, and while my shorts were soaked the humidity didn't really phase me.  Had some spasms in my hamstring the last four miles

Late morning run in Fort Snelling.  I wanted to run slowly today, and I did.  Legs were dead from yesterday's run and then all the biking and standing last night at the progressive dinner.  My hamstring started acting up again the last couple of miles.  Hopefully it doesn't prevent me from doing workouts this next week.

Franklin to Ford at 6 AM.  My hamstring flared up at 5 miles but I had to shuffle through four more in order to get home.  I'm really confused on what set this off as I haven't done any really fast running recently.  Perhaps I overcompensated last week when my knee was bothering me and the hamstring ended up taking too much of the load.  Tomorrow's workout is in serious jeopardy.

20 min tempo (2:30 rest)
4 x 3:00 cruise intervals (1:00 rest)

I did this in the morning on East River Road.  Fortunately the weather was pretty nice.
