I felt strong the whole way through and was able to pick up the pace nicely on the cruise intervals while still keeping things at threshold effort.  My hamstring didn't complain until the last interval of the workout.  Unfortunately it's pretty sore now.  The idea of a high mileage week is out the door since it looks like I can only run once per day right now.  Cooled down with Ben Jacobs after he caught up to me.

40 min elliptical.  I wanted to try to stay in my normal routine and keep my minutes about the same, so I hopped on the elliptical while watching the Little League World Series.  Felt pretty spry; I'm always surprised when that happens coming back from morning workouts.

Ran up Summit to Macalester, came back via Randolph, then added 5 minutes along the river to make it 7.  There are a few too many stoplights on this loop, but I'll add it to the list of morning run possibilities.  Looks like the Mac track is done so hopefully I can get on it next week.  Hamstring didn't bother me at all this morning.
Another easy run, this time just out and back on Shepard.  Felt good.

It was tough to find the motivation to get going this morning since it was raining and I was tired.  Went out and back on East River.  Felt some tightness in my hamstring the last couple miles but it wasn't as bad as earlier this week.  It wasn't an issue trying to do strides either.  I'm glad I had previously decided not to run after driving back to Appleton later today so that I have 24 hours rest before tomorrow's workout.  Hopefully a) the dew point is under 70 and b) my hamstring doesn't rebel against running sub 5:00 pace.

Morning workout in Appleton.  It was 68 degrees and 100% humidity so I was glad I got going early.  Did the miles on a loop by my house and took a little extra rest because of the weather.  I felt pretty strong.  It was nice that this pace didn't feel like I was sprinting.  The fartlek was alright.  I should be ready for these races.

Memorial to CE.  I didn't get going as early as I planned on so I got rained on for the last half of the run.  This actually felt pretty good since it was so muggy outside.  Legs were alright after yesterday's workout.  I had forgotten about the Saturday farmer's market in downtown Appleton.  Running through that was a little annoying.

CE Trail to Kimberly.  I decided to switch the long run to tomorrow when the dew point will be 15-20 degrees lower.  I felt really good this morning so part of me wished I would have gone ahead with it, but I also had a bunch of other stuff to get done.

Easy run at 10 PM back in St Paul.  I saw a couple making out on a bench and the girl definitely saw me, then a couple minutes later when I was on my way back I saw them walking on the path which was a little awkward.  I also had some strange pain in my left knee.  I don't think it's anything major.
Did the usual Stone Arch long run.  Had a few minor aches in my left leg but for the most part I felt good.  The drier weather felt amazing.  Did the ALS Ice Bucket Challenge afterward.

Worked out on Macalester's newly resurfaced track.  Great to be out there on a nice evening.  I feel stronger running this kind of pace than I have since before Shamrock in 2013.  My legs felt a little tired, but this still wasn't overly difficult.  It wasn't easy, but I didn't have to go beyond normal workout effort.  The last 400 started off at the same pace as the others, then I stepped on the accelerator when I got to the steeple pit.  I ran the first six 600s thinking that I had locked my keys in my car and trying to figure out how I would solve that problem, then I realized that I hadn't actually done that so that was a nice relief.  It's nice that I can still hit a speed workout the day after doing a 16 mile run.  Training will be pretty light for a little while now.
Easy run along Minnehaha Creek.  Legs were alright.  It was 60 degrees with a light breeze and no humidity.  Can we please get a morning like this on Monday?
Morning run in Fort Snelling.  Felt ok, my head is kind of stuffed up.

16 min tempo
3 min rest
3:30 @ ~10K effort
2:30 rest
4 x 30 seconds fast (1 min jog) 

Pre race tune up this morning - fairly standard operating procedure with a short tempo and then some faster stuff.  Felt pretty good on this, and I felt especially sharp on the 30 second repeats at the end.  The humidity was about 100%.  Ran into Dan on my cooldown so I ran with him for a few minutes.

Evening shakeout.  Did my 5* route (which means it's not quite 5), but I ran more than 9 miles this morning.  I swallowed a bug with a mile and a half left and then coughed for the rest of the run.  Legs felt fine.
Fort Snelling.  I started off fast and just kept cruising.  Legs felt really good.  At one point I passed a biker and then he rode about 5 feet behind me for about a mile.

Pre race.  I felt great on the run and had spring in my step on my strides.  It's supposed to be humid tomorrow morning but I've done some workouts in humid weather during the past month so I should handle it alright.  Tomorrow's going to be a big day with the race and then moving.

Well that wasn't what I had in mind.  I woke up at 3 AM and spent the majority of the next 3 hours in the bathroom.  Must've eaten something bad yesterday.  Decided to try racing anyway and it wasn't a good idea.  My body was straight out of gas before the 2 mile.  Once Ruter and Tim passed me (a little after 4) and I was no longer needed for the team score I pulled the plug.  I stood and talked to Siegel for 6-7 minutes and then jumped in with Jeremy when he came by (he was just running easy) since I had to get back to the start/finish somehow.  I'm disappointed but I'm not going to worry too much about it - there's nothing that I can do about it now and in the grand scheme of things the Victory 10K isn't a super important race.  I'm glad I get a shot at redemption on Saturday.

Got out for a run at 8:30 after spending almost four hours getting jerked around by Comcast.  Between that and the stress of trying to unpack my stuff and figure out how to fit it all into an apartment with a good bit less storage space than my last one I was not in a very good mood.  Fortunately the run lifted my spirits a little bit.  I kept things nice and easy.  My GI bug is still going strong - I don't feel too much weaker yet but I hope my appetite comes back soon and that I can get back to normal by this weekend.
Easy shakeout on another 60 degree morning.  It started lightly raining the last few minutes.  Felt alright, didn't sleep very well last night.

10 x 1:00 (1:00 jog between)

Long day.  Didn't get out until 8:30 again.  Hopefully this doesn't become a habit.

Ran from my office after work before going to Mark's to watch the Packers.  It was disgustingly humid - dew point of 74.  I hope this was the last humid run until next summer.  My legs felt awful and my stomach is still messed up.  Tomorrow has to be better, right?

Easy run and strides at lunch.  The dew point is down to about 50, which feels awesome.  My body still doesn't feel all that strong, but I felt worlds better than yesterday so if I can continue the upward trend I'll be ready for a good effort tomorrow.  I just have to stay tough for the entire 15-16 minutes.
When I got back to St Paul I took a nap for an hour and a half, then decided to run again.  Did Lake St to Ford.  Once I got going I felt decent.

Late morning Crosby Farms loop.  I went out last night and ended up crashing at Prez and Luke's place in St Louis Park, then Luke gave me a ride back to my car this morning and I ran when I got home.  Felt rough starting off (most likely from my lack of a real breakfast) but I eventually came around.  The weather is amazing.

CIM is three months from today.  It's almost time to start focusing in on that.

I had to take the morning off of work to have the cable guy come and get me hooked up, so since the appointment window wasn't until 10:00 I got up early and knocked out a long run.  Went out along the creek, around Nokomis, and then into Fort Snelling.  I felt strong but I tried to avoid really hammering this one.

This afternoon at work I didn't have a ton to do so I put together a skeleton of a training schedule for the next 3 months.  For the most part I'm pretty happy with it.  Part of me is tempted to send it to Mortenson or Griff for critiquing/suggestions, but I'm not sure if I actually will.
Ran with Adrian and Pojke.  Didn't feel that good, but still a good run thanks to good company and a change of scenery.  Also saw Tim Lillehaugen and Hannah Dennis running (separately).
50 degrees, windy, and raining this morning so it was a little tough to get going.  Fortunately I felt better at the end of the run than I did at the beginning, so I'm glad I did it.

Up Summit to Victoria, down to Run N Fun, up Randolph to Snelling, back via St Clair.  Still only about 50 degrees, which feels slightly cold for standing around but great for running.  My legs felt really good.  I must've had too much water during the day because I had to stop a couple of times.

Did this from my office after work.  The weather was true cross country weather as it was about 50 degrees and somewhat windy.  Felt great to run hard and still barely break a sweat.  I felt pretty good throughout the workout.  It was nice to be able to do this on some rolling hills.  Short cooldown in order to get to the velodrome.

Franklin to Ford.  Super tired this morning.  I'm going to need to caffeinate up for tonight's drive home and then I'm looking forward to sleeping 10 hours tonight.  Also had to break out a long sleeve shirt and gloves.
Xavier loop.  I slept in and got going at about 10:30.  The weather felt like late October.  Legs felt good for the most part.

Ran to the Lawrence Gym and back, then did strides.  I used to do this route all the time when I was in high school.  Weird to think that that was about 10 years ago.  I've been feeling pretty fast on strides recently; I kind of wonder what I could run for an all out 400 right now.

10 mile sub-tempo

5:52, 5:44, 5:48, 5:39, 5:43, 5:47, 5:44, 5:42, 5:39, 5:33
Total: 57:11 (5:43 average)

First long sub-tempo run of this marathon cycle.  I did 2 laps of my old 5 mile morning route in Appleton (just like I did in May).  The wind was tough in spots.  It took a few minutes to find the right pace, as I started off with a 3:00 half mile, but once I got going mid 5:40s felt pretty smooth.  Didn't really try to pick it up at the end but I must have subconsciously sensed that I was almost done.  I didn't feel beat up when I finished, and I'm guessing that I could have maintained this pace for quite awhile, so I'm happy with where I'm at.

Went to the Packers home opener in the afternoon.  We got off to a rough start and went down 21-3, then stormed back for a 31-24 win.  The Jets' tying touchdown was negated thanks to someone calling timeout before the play started.  Jordy Nelson 200 receiving yards.

West River 10 in the dark.  I decided to run through the construction to my turn around, then on the way back I couldn't see all that well and I tripped on something and scuffed up my knee and hip.  I guess that's what I get for going somewhere I wasn't supposed to.  Other than that the run was alright.  Kept the pace nice and slow.  I was tired most of the day from a late night last night.

I didn't feel like running when I woke up this morning so I waited until lunch.  Ran along the river.  There were a ton of weird grasshopper like bugs that kept circling my ankles for most of the run.  Also saw a guy running reasonably fast in flip flops, and another guy practicing some sort of martial arts on the side of the path.  Strange characters hanging out in downtown St Paul today.

1 x 6:00 @ 8K Effort
7 x Lock & Dam Hill
1 x 3:00 'Squeezing It Down'

Lower volume, high intensity workout.  Felt as good as I could have reasonably hoped to.  I started with the 6:00 piece to put some junk in my legs before the hills.  I definitely was running sub 5:00 pace.  Took the hills one at a time.  Tonight's ride on the pain train will help me at Griak if I decide to race there.  

Met one of my new neighbors in the elevator when I got back.  Not a very friendly lady.

Edit: I mapped out the 6:00 interval (it was an out and back) and I was about 4:45 pace on that.  Then on the last interval I started from the same spot but made it further, so that was a low 2:50s 1K.  Looks like I ran a little too fast, as 4:45 pace is certainly not 8K pace.

Busy day today, and I also felt pretty beat, so I just did an easy 8 in Fort Snelling.  It seems odd to me that a workout that totaled only about 16 minutes of intervals would zap my legs like this, but I suppose it was at an intensity that I'm not used to.  Good burger at Tiffany's this evening.
Crosby Farms loop in reverse then a short add on to get 11.  Legs felt a little better than yesterday but still pretty bad.

Slow shakeout that did not feel good.  Doing a long tempo on Sunday followed by a short night and then working out again on Tuesday has put me in a hole.  I'm still going to do a tempo tomorrow night but I'll have to be really careful to not go too hard.  Then hopefully some extra sleep this weekend will bring me out of this.

20/10 Tempos (3 min int)
3 x 400 in 70 (200 jog)

I wanted to keep this workout low key since I ran too hard on Tuesday.  Ran on a different course than usual and didn't take any splits.  Nice to just go based on feel.  I finished the 10 minutes right next to Minnehaha Academy, so since I was feeling good I jumped on the track for a few 400s rather than doing the usual 4 x 30 seconds.  Total time for that mile (with the recoveries) was 5:12.  I felt better on the cooldown than I did on the warmup, so I think I executed this right.  It was a fairly humid evening.

Arb run from Olaf before the meet.  Felt alright.  Jake Brown was out of the lineup with a roller skiing injury so Eau Claire got us by 5 points.  The guys who raced ran well.  It's weird to think that I am 5-8 years older than the guys on the team now.  Oh well, I think the only way I'll ever stop going to this stuff is if I move away.
Evening double after a thunderstorm.

Sunday morning 20.  Got out the door just before 10 AM.  A little windy, but pretty near perfect temperature.  My creativity for coming up with a route was lacking, so I ended up heading out the usual way down East River and across the Stone Arch Bridge, then on the way back I added on a little bit over by TCF Bank Stadium and then crossed the Lake St Bridge and finished on West River.  My legs never felt super, but they were good enough to get through it.

Brewers lost 1-0.  That just about does it for their playoff hopes, after being in 1st place for the first 5 months of the season.  There's always next year...

Fort Snelling.  I just barely got this done before it got dark.  Unfortunately the days of being able to do that are numbered, as today is the equinox and by next week sunset will be before 7:00.  That said, for tonight it was fun plodding around Pike Island at twilight on a nice 65 degree evening.  My legs were pretty tired from yesterday's run so I took it easy.
Lake St to Ford.  Classic fall morning; got to savor these.  Legs felt good.
High Bridge with the Run N Fun group.  Legs felt great and it was fun to run with other people for the first time in awhile.  Did an add on with some people at the end to make it 11.

12 x 1K Cruise Intervals (1 minute jog rest)

Worked out at Boom Island with Mason Frank, Kieser, Dan Sevcik, and Roni Teich.  It was a nice place for a workout but unfortunately it took me 45 minutes to drive there from my office.  Mason was doing 16 x 1K, so Kieser and I sat out the first two and then jumped in.  It took me about five repeats to fully get Kieser's loop down...not a good day for my sense of direction.  Our first one was 3:19, then we started working it down.  Hit a few in the 3:15 range, then a bunch at 3:11-3:13, then two at 3:10, and my last one was 3:03.  Average was about 3:12.  Mason was right next to me the whole way until my last one, then he finished up with a 3:08 and a 3:01 by himself.  I felt strong.  I suppose 3:12s is about my PR half marathon pace, so it should feel pretty easy, but I think this was a good intro marathon workout.

Medium long run this evening.  Went around Lake Hiawatha and the golf course, along the creek for a bit, around Lake Nokomis, and then home.  It got dark about an hour in.  My hamstring was bugging me a little at the start but overall my legs felt good.  Watched the last four innings of Jeter's final home game tonight.  The Yankees blew a 3 run lead in the top of the 9th, but that set the stage for Jeter to get the game winning hit and he delivered with one of his classic liners into right field.  You can't make this stuff up.
Felt alright even though I stayed up too late last night.

Lake St to Ford loop
5 x Ford Hill
Short cooldown

I wanted to do a few hills tonight in order to get my fast twitch fibers (the few that I have) some work for this week, but with long workouts on Wednesday and Sunday I kept it to 5 repeats on the less steep of my two hills.  Shortly after I started running I bumped into Jake Smith so we ran together for probably 3 miles.  He was moving a little faster than I was planning on, but it wasn't anything crazy.  The hills were fine.  Glad my hamstring didn't object.

Morning run in Fort Snelling before going to watch Griak.  It was a warm day (temperature got up to 80) so I'm definitely glad that Griff suggested I not race.  Felt good on the run.  Griak was fun; the highlight was watching Olin Hacker outduel a guy down the home straight for the win in the high school race.  Wayzata was dominant.  The field in the D3 men's race was down this year since everybody's going to Eau Claire on Friday instead.  Hit up Adrian's Oktoberfest party in the late afternoon/early evening.

10 mile sub-tempo #2

5:44, 5:39, 5:42, 5:38, 5:42, 5:42, 5:42, 5:36, 5:41, 5:33
Total: 56:39 (5:40 average)

Dennis Kimetto ran about a minute per mile faster than this to set the marathon world record in Berlin this morning.  That's definitely humbling.

It was warm this morning.  I got out the door around 9:30 and in hindsight I wish I had gotten up an hour earlier.  I was also a little worried that sprinting around at Griak and the amount of time I spent on my feet yesterday might affect the workout, but it still went well.  Stayed on West River since there was an all women's race taking place on East River and it would have been awkward running next to that.  I got into a nice rhythm for most of it.  I lost some time on the uphills, so that'll be a focus as I keep getting more into marathon specific stuff.  In the last mile I passed a biker who then didn't like the fact that I passed her and tried to race me for a minute.  Since it was my last mile I was down to play along a little bit.  She then turned off.  30+ seconds faster than 2 weeks ago, on a tougher course and with warmer weather.  Good progress.  It's been a good 3 week stretch.  Now I'm going to take a bit of a down week.  TC 10K next Saturday, Des Moines Half in 3 weeks.

Lake St to Ford.  This is all I'm running today.  Originally I was going to take the day off and do a normal double tomorrow, but I decided instead to just split that double into two singles.  Didn't feel too beat up from yesterday, so that's good.

Fort Snelling.  40 degrees this morning so I wore half tights and a dry fit shirt for the first time since April.  Ended up feeling surprisingly good this morning.  Didn't see another person between mile 1 and mile 11.

Originally I was going to do a workout this morning but I stayed up until midnight watching the Royals/Athletics game and before bed I saw on the forecast that it would be raining at 6 AM, so I decided that I would sleep in an extra hour and do the workout at night instead.  It was indeed raining when I woke up so I'm glad I made that decision.  Tired today.  I hope Giants/Pirates tonight is a blowout because I can't stay up for another late finish.

Good workout tonight on the track at SPA.  I'm glad I waited until tonight since there's no way it would have gone this well in the morning, and I also underestimated how long this would actually take.  It was a little windy, but overall the weather was pretty nice.  I felt extremely strong clicking off lap after lap.  I was still running sub 6:30 pace on the rests, not just shuffling around.  My hamstring was tight on my warmup and I could still feel it a little bit at times during the workout so I didn't do the 200s that I was planning on finishing with.  Not worth taking any risks with those.  If I can run this pace for 10K on Saturday I'd be pretty happy.  Looks like it's going to be cold and windy, so that'll be fun.
Easy run at lunch.  Got rained on the last couple miles.  Legs feel good despite yesterday's workout.  Go Pack Go!

Franklin to Ford.  Upper 30s and windy, which is about what it will be tomorrow morning as well.  Legs felt ok.  Might double later today as there really isn't much point in tapering for a 10K that I'll (probably) be soloing in crappy weather.

Easy 5 on river road.  Legs felt good.  I spent most of the run daydreaming about running a fast 3K this winter...not sure why that was on my mind since I doubt I'll really try to do that, but for tonight it was fun to think about.  Also, when I left the Dodgers were leading the Cardinals 6-1 but when I got back the Cardinals were up 10-6.  Still windy.

Crosby Farms loop.  This run wasn't very fun.  I got up at 5 AM for the 2nd day in a row and biked all over the Twin Cities for the 10 mile and marathon (did 20-25 miles total), and stood at the St Thomas hill for over an hour cheering.  I enjoyed watching the races, but this wiped me out.  Came home and sat for an hour or so, then ran.  Legs felt like I was finishing a bad long run pretty much the entire time.  Hopefully I'll pull it together for tomorrow.

Overall it was a good day for Olaf alums.  Run N Fun had a good showing in the 10 mile but kind of took it on the chin in the marathon (except for Anders).  The 10 mile was about 40 seconds short, but even with the adjustment the top 20-30 still was faster than I would have guessed.  Watching the top guys in the marathon got me excited for Cal.  9 weeks.

Took the day off from work - got a lot of PTO to use by the end of the year.  I was originally planning to run in the morning but I looked at the forecast when I woke up and saw that it would be in the high 50s in the afternoon so I decided I'd go then.  I went all the way up Summit to the capitol, cut through downtown to the river, did a short out and back to the Warner bridge, then ran all the way back to my apartment via Shepard/Mississippi River Blvd.  The last 11 miles were into the wind, which was a bit draining.  For the most part I felt good.  Took a Gu at 90 minutes and it helped.
Easy 5.  Beautiful fall morning.  My legs were a little tired starting out, but they warmed up.

Run N Fun.  We did a route on some roads southeast of Lilydale that I've never run on before.  At 4 miles I turned around with Choker, Little, and Jake, but none of us remembered how to get back so we ended up getting a little lost.  It didn't help that when we were going out it was light out and by the time we flipped it was dark.  Made it back eventually and we hadn't actually added that much time.  I felt decent, which I'm sure was helped by our relaxed pace.  Did six strides at the end.
Lake St to Ford.  Hard to get up this morning, but I did it.  This is going to be a pretty high mileage week.

2 x 4:00, 2 x 3:00, 2 x 2:00, 2 x 1:00 (rest = jog half the time of the previous rep)

30 minutes of fartlek - 20 of which was fast.  Ran this on West River.  I just went through the motions tonight and punched the clock.  Got some bottoms-up work in before next week's half but I didn't want to hit anything too hard coming off of Monday's long run and with a big workout coming up on Saturday.  Big steak for dinner afterward.
Out and back to the U.  Dark for the last 9 miles - got 5 months of that coming up so I guess I better get used to it.  Felt good this evening, although I should have worn gloves.

Pike Island.  This is one of the last times I'll be able to do that run after work so I'm glad I got out early enough tonight to get it in.  Felt a little tired, but not too bad.  I ran into Colin and Amy Royce walking their dog on the trails down there so I stopped and talked with them for a few minutes.  Swung into Lund's at the end to get some stuff for dinner, then did a few strides.

5 miles at marathon effort - 26:55
5:25, 5:18, 5:24, 5:25, 5:23

8 x 1K slightly faster (1:00 jog between)
3:14, 3:15, 3:16, 3:14, 3:15, 3:14, 3:13, 3:12

This workout was long, and my legs were definitely tired by the end of it, but I wouldn't say that it was really a ball buster.  I couldn't decide what exactly I wanted to do for a workout and ended up deciding that this would be a good bridge between the cruise interval workouts that I've been doing and the straight marathon pace interval workouts coming up.  I did the tempo on West River Road and the Ks on the track at Minnehaha Academy.  I was hoping to be more around 5:20s on the opening 5 mile but the wind slowed me down.  5:23s is still alright though; that's 2:21 low pace.  The instantaneous pace feature on my watch wasn't working right - a couple times it said I was running sub 5:00 pace and the next time I'd look it would say 5:4x.  Eventually I just stopped looking at it and waited for the beeps every half mile.  The wind was definitely annoying on the Ks, but I stayed consistent and clicked them off.  I'm happy with this.

Super easy Nokomis loop.  I felt like I could have done more today but with the half in a week I thought it would be best to get yesterday out of my legs as quickly as possible.  Gorgeous weather, good run.

Fort Snelling.  There was a fairly large downed tree blocking the path, so hopefully the city comes and cleans that up soon.  It's also pretty dark at 7 AM now.  Legs felt ok.  I was 2 minutes faster on the way back even though I was trying to relax.  Must've been crawling the first few miles.  I felt like I was a little low on calories.

Ran into Tim by St Thomas so we ran together out and back on Summit.  We were running about six minute pace at first and both of us thought that the other one was the one pushing it.  Felt really good for some reason this evening.

45 minute sub-tempo (roughly 8 miles)

I cut the distance down a little this week in order to not have too many real long efforts in too short of a timeframe.  Also didn't wear my GPS watch and instead just ran off of feel.  The first 20 minutes were into the wind, then I turned around.  Felt like I had a good rhythm going.  I was pretty tired when I got up (stayed up too late last night and then didn't sleep great after having a few beers), so I'm glad the workout came together alright.  Finished it with a few strides that didn't feel real snappy.  Now I need to make sure I get some rest in order to have a chance at feeling good in the race on Sunday.
10 miles on river road in the dark.  It was one of those low motivation days.  I felt surprisingly fresh; probably because I hadn't run in about 35 hours.

Lake St to Ford.  Perfect morning - 40 degrees, sun shining, absolutely no wind.  I'm trying to savor this weather as much as possible, knowing what's coming shortly.  Saw the Team USA Minnesota guys towards the end.

Basically did half of a workout tonight.  The goal was to turn the legs over a little before the half and end the workout feeling good.  Unfortunately I felt a bit flat/tired, but a couple real easy days now should bring things around.  It was almost 70 degrees this evening.
Ran at lunch.  Felt ok, nothing special really.  It's pretty windy.
Pre race run and strides at about 10:30.  Felt alright.  The official goal for tomorrow is to break 1:08.  Really as long as I don't totally bomb I'll be ok with whatever I run.  Off to Iowa.

Didn't cool down after the race, instead I stood around watching friends finish and talking with the Lillehaugens and then the Monroes.  By this time it had been over and hour since I finished and there was no point, so I decided I'd just do a shakeout in St Paul.  After racing and then driving about 4 hours I was pretty stiff starting out.  I'd be surprised if my first mile was under 9 minutes.  Got moving a little more respectably towards the end though, and I felt better afterward, plus I got to enjoy more of the 65 degree weather.

I decided that working late and getting some stuff done would be more beneficial to my life than going for an easy run.  Legs don't feel anything like they did the day after Houston or Grandma's, so I should be able to get some decent running in this week.

Ran High Bridge with the Run N Fun group.  Felt really good, never would have guessed that I ran a half marathon two days ago.  Kotek kept trying to join in on conversations and most of what he was contributing was inaccurate, as usual.

Rolled out the door at 9:00 after working late and then having to go to the store.  Two winters ago I did quite a bit of running at 9 or 10 PM.  I'd like to not have that become a regular habit again this year, but now that I'm back to living alone there's a decent chance it will.  Ran around Nokomis.  It's not very well lit over there so I probably won't go that way at night too often.  Four strides at the end.  Feeling pretty good, I'll probably go for a longer run tomorrow.

Did a medium long run over the Stone Arch Bridge.  I didn't get done with work quite as early as I hoped so I didn't get the whole run done before dark, but I got to about 12 miles.  It was almost 70 degrees again; this month has been one of the best weather months of any in recent history.  Legs were a bit tired on the hills.  I think that's more because I haven't gotten very good sleep this week rather than because of the half.  Stopped and talked to Tyler for a few minutes on the way back.

Had to stay at the office until 9 PM.  I didn't want to take another 0 after already taking a day off this week so I got in 5, but that's it.  I was planning on somewhat of a rest week this week, but not quite to this extent.  Tomorrow I'm getting back on the horse.

I watched most of the Monster Dash field run past my building, then did my run.  Out and back in Fort Snelling.  Once again an absolutely gorgeous fall day.  My legs phenomenal.  I was running low 6:00 pace and felt like I wasn't trying at all.  Maybe I should have moved tomorrow's workout up a day.

Ran Lake St to Ford while the sun was setting.  While I was out there I thought about how it would probably have been a lot of fun to be spiking up and racing in the Jack's Twilight 6K in these conditions, but a 6K on grass doesn't really benefit me at all right now.  Did a few strides at the end.

30 minutes at marathon effort (26:48 through 5 miles)
5:18, 5:27, 5:16, 5:24, 5:23, 2:44 then an extra 28 seconds

4 x 1 Mile (1:15 jog between)
5:13, 5:11, 5:11, 5:11

1 x 1K
3:10

This was a more difficult version of the workout I did two weeks ago.  I feel like it went ok, but it could have gone better if not for three mistakes which are all easily correctable and kind of annoy me.  I've stayed up until after midnight just about every night this past week, I didn't get my full normal pre race/long workout breakfast, and I got out too fast at the start.  That said, I battled through and got the 10 miles of work in.  Three miles in I felt like I was going to blow up, then I settled down.  It was pretty windy; I think the last workout I did where the wind wasn't a factor was the Ks with Mason over a month ago.  I wasn't feeling up to fighting the wind for a 5th mile repeat at the end so I decided to just finish with a slightly faster 1K.  Next weekend's workout will be strictly marathon pace.  I'm thinking something like 4 x 4K.

Ran from my office at 5:30.  It's the last week until March of being able to run outside after work without it being pitch dark.  Didn't feel very good...definitely still recovering from that workout yesterday.
Lake St to Ford (the usual).  It's colder out than it has been.  Felt good when I got going, but it took me 30 minutes to get out the door after I woke up.  Need to cut that in half.

River road to Marshall to Summit loop from Run N Fun.  Nice relaxed pace.  Added about 10 minutes at the end by myself and did four strides.  Got done just in time to see the Royals score 7 runs in the second inning.

40 minute sub-tempo
6 x 30 seconds fast (1:00 jog)

Fortunately I was able to get this in before it got dark.  Unfortunately after two really nice weeks of weather it looks like we are indeed going to have a change of seasons, as it's definitely cooler outside.  Started the sub-tempo shortly before the Lake St Bridge, then crossed at Franklin, hit the hills on East River, and finished pretty close to my building.  Based on how I felt at the end I thought I might have run a little too slow, but I figured out later that I averaged right around 5:40s, which is what I was looking for.  The 6 x 30 seconds felt a little weird since I haven't been doing stuff like that recently.

Worked a half day today, and was probably only productive for half of that time.  Long run in the afternoon.  My idea was that yesterday's workout would put some fatigue in my legs at the start and make today's run more marathon specific.  I followed the path along the creek all the way to Lake Harriet, ran two laps around the lake, then back home the way I came.  Covered plenty of new territory today since I had never taken the creek path anywhere near that far.  I felt pretty good, although the last 15 minutes I was wishing that I had brought a Gu.  I didn't have to slow down, but my blood sugar was definitely getting low.  Timberwolves game at night.  Got the W!
Slow recovery run.  Did the shorter Crosby Farms loop.  Last time running outside after work without it being pitch dark until March.  It's only 18 weeks...

12 miles in the morning with Jacobs and Dohm.  We ran around Como from Ben's place.  Pretty solid pace, and good conversations about sports made the time pass quickly.  Adding an extra mile for all the running around that I did at the MIAC meet in the afternoon.  The boys dominated: 1-2-3-4-6.  It'll be fun to see if they can make a run at another national title in a few weeks.

Solo Fort Snelling run.  I pulled myself away from the NYC coverage because I wanted to be able to do both of today's runs in daylight rather than doing the first one at noon and the second at 6 PM.  Felt kind of tired from some combination of all the time I spent on my feet yesterday (not to mention all the sprinting at the meet) and staying up really late last night.
Macalester loop.  This morning I wore tights, dri fit shirt, headband, and gloves; this afternoon I ran in shorts and a t shirt.  Felt good.  Planning on working out tomorrow.

4 x 2.5 Miles (2:30 jog rest)
13:20 (5:22, 5:19, 2:39)
13:15 (5:14, 5:22, 2:39)
13:22 (5:22, 5:20, 2:40)
13:10 (5:16, 5:18, 2:36)

Did this on West River Road, back and forth from the Ford Bridge to just past the Lake St Bridge.  The weather was perfect for working out this evening, aside from the fact that it was dark.  50 degrees, minimal wind, it rained during the afternoon but had stopped by 6:00.  I missed a couple of splits because I couldn't read my watch, but I was able to get most of them.  I felt really good and had to hold myself back at points.  5:20 pace feels smooth.  I have to remember that the race is over 2.5 times as far as this, but if I can keep progressing for five more weeks I am going to shatter my PR in California.

River road loop from Run N Fun.  I went a little longer with Kieser, Jake Smith, Ruter, and Kotek.  Felt ok, not super stellar.  Went to Lucky 13's for dinner afterward and I won $19 playing bingo so that paid for my meal.  Kelly was the big winner, getting about $70.

5 x 3:00 Hard
5 x Ford Hill

I wasn't sure if it was a great idea to do another workout 36 hours after my last one, but this one was fairly light and I never felt like Monday took much out of me so I went ahead with it.  I didn't feel that great on the 3:00 intervals.  This was the first time I've run more than 30 seconds at sub 5:00 pace in several weeks, so that makes sense.  It's going to take me awhile after the marathon to get in shape for shorter/faster races.  I ended up running into Dan at the bottom of Summit so I ran about a mile with him back towards my place.  I almost didn't do the hills at the end, but they felt decent enough.
Six on Shepard after work.  Felt good, but I was running about 7:30 pace.
Ran an out and back to the Cathedral.  Felt good.  Running up Summit while the sun was rising was kind of cool.

TGIF.  Work kicked my butt this week and my body did not want to function properly this morning.  Decided after this run that I was pushing tomorrow's workout back to Sunday.  That really works out better anyways since the weather is supposed to be a little better that day and then I'll be lined up for an easy day on Monday when we're supposed to get a bunch of snow.
Felt better than I did this morning.  It doesn't say much for my social life though when my Friday night consists of going for a 10 mile run and then watching basketball by myself.  Oh well.
Fort Snelling.  If we actually get the snow that's in the forecast this might be my last time running here for a few months, which would be a bummer.  Legs felt alright.  It was windy.

15 mile sub-tempo/95% marathon pace run

5:49, 5:38, 5:41, 5:40, 5:40, 5:35, 5:41, 5:42, 5:38, 5:33, 5:47, 5:35, 5:30, 5:36, 5:24
Total: 1:24:28 (5:38 average)
First 5: 28:28, Middle 5: 28:09, Last 5: 27:52

I basically treated this like a race, except for the fact that I stayed up later than planned last night and thus got started a little later this morning.  I warmed up in several layers, did ballistics and a few strides outside, then came back inside to use the bathroom and change into some lighter stuff.  Also decided to wear my flats.  My goal was to fall asleep at 5:40ish pace and hopefully naturally speed up as I went along.  The first 5 miles were effortless.  Had to put a little more into it to stay on pace through the hills on East River, but I stayed right on it.  At 8 miles I took a Gu.  Got it down fine but then it took me about a half mile to catch my breath.  I'm not sure what happened on mile 11.  Must've been a particularly windy mile.  Running the last 2 miles I felt like I still had a fair amount of energy left, but after I stopped my legs quickly tightened up and the cooldown was not comfortable.  I'm hoping that was more a product of the temperature rather than of my legs being trashed from the workout.  If this was actually 95% of marathon pace then this is right in line with my 2:20-2:21 target.

Easy treadmill run.  I probably could have run outside but I didn't want to risk taking a spill on an easy day.  I originally thought that I wanted to stay off the treadmill until after CIM, but looking at the extended forecast for the month there's pretty much no way that  would happen.  Hopefully I can at least get my workouts in outside.  Felt ok; I could tell that I worked hard yesterday.
Treadmill again.  Didn't have it in me to fight the elements.
Lilydale with the Run N Fun group.  About 50 minutes in I had to leave the group because I needed a bathroom, so I finished by myself, adding about 10 more minutes when I got back to the store.
Early morning Ford to Franklin.  Got really annoyed by the ice and cold.  Worst run I've had in awhile.
Ran around Calhoun and Isles with Joy Esboldt.  Finan was around for a little while too after he caught us on Isles.  Good run.

2 x 22 minutes @ marathon effort (4:00 rest, regular running pace)
4 x 3 minutes cruise intervals

East River Road was fairly clear, so I was glad that I didn't have to hit the treadmill for a workout.  Unfortunately it was only about 20 degrees and the windchill was around 10.  I felt good running this and I think I did a good job of keeping the pace up.  The cruise intervals at the end were close to 5 minute pace.  Only a couple big workouts left now.

Easy recovery 8 miler.  Ran on West River.  The path on that side of the river is significantly icier than the path on the east side.  Didn't really want to do this run, but it went fine when I got going.  It's cold.

'It takes miles when you're tired, miles when it's cold, hundreds and hundreds of miles, when no one is watching, and no one cares.'
-Narrator, 5000 Meters: Nothing Comes Easy

Started the run just before 11.  It was cold, windy, and snowing.  It takes a lot of digging to find the motivation to start these runs, but once I get going it's not that bad.  My legs felt alright.  When I got back I pulled up the regionals results.  1-3-4-5-8, 21 points, Grant won in 24:13.  I'm jacked for next Saturday.
Easy jog inside and then a few strides.  Did this after the Badger game ended.  Melvin Gordon set the D1 record with 408 rushing yards, and he sat out the whole fourth quarter.

3 weeks until the marathon, so it's time for the longest long run.  Kieser came over and joined me for the first 1:42, so I only had to go 48 minutes alone.  Since it snowed yesterday I was worried about the footing.  It wasn't great, but the paths had (mostly) at least been cleared a little bit.  We did an out and back on Shepard towards downtown St Paul, then I added on.  I felt alright.  I had plenty of aerobic energy and I didn't bonk, but my left leg (mainly my hip/hamstring area) was feeling worn out the last 20-30 minutes.  It's a bit sore now afterward, so I hope that I didn't injure myself out there.  I carried a Gu but wasn't able to get more than about a half of a sip out of it because it froze.  As long as I recover alright I got what I needed out of today.
Planned off day.  Legs weren't as sore this morning as I thought they would be.  We had our company winter outing at Cooks of Crocus Hill this evening.

Treadmill.  The windchill was in the negative double digits this morning...screw that.  Today is the ESPN college basketball tip off marathon, so there was live basketball on TV at 7 AM.  Too bad that only happens once per year.  Legs felt good, I think the day off yesterday helped.

After several long workouts in a row I needed to shake things up a little, so I headed to the U of M for a track workout.  Kieser, Mason, Marty, and Roni were also there but the 8 x 1K workout that they were doing was too intense for me.  Nice to at least have other people on the track at the same time.  The mile was easy.  The 600s weren't too difficult either, but I'm glad that I'm running a marathon in 3 weeks and not a 5K.

Ran out and back down East River and through the U.  I bumped into Jake Smith 5 minutes in so he joined me for about 4 miles.  He was pushing the pace a bit.  Didn't feel that great.  I'm ready to start tapering, but it's not quite time yet.
Felt like I had been run over by a train this morning.  I need sleep.  Tonight really needs to be the last time that I'm up past midnight until after CIM.

Ran on Shepard.  The path is clear so I'm going to workout outside tomorrow morning.  Since the windchill will be about 0 my pace will be slower, but I don't think I've got a 50-60 minute treadmill workout in me mentally.

60 minute sub-tempo/progression

I decided yesterday that I was going to run this outside.  The windchill was around -2, but it really didn't bother me too much.  I started going into the wind down Shepard, then had it at my back for the second half hour.  If I were to guess I'd say I started in the 5:50s and got down to 5:15-5:20.  The only time I felt like I was slowing down was on the uphill by 35E (the MDRA 15K hill).  Once I got to the top of that I pretended that I was chasing down Lundstrom and Jake again.  Felt ok...my body is tired from lack of sleep but I fought through.  Aerobically I'm strong.  Now I'm off to Ohio to cheer for the boys tomorrow.

Ran on the course in Mason.  Berens joined me for 15-20 minutes and he knew where to go, so that was nice.  There weren't any big hills, but with plenty of rolling sections and soft ground it was definitely not Oshkosh.  It was lightly raining when I started running, but that stopped well before the race started.

The guys got out in great position with all of the top 5 inside the top 50.  The lead pack remained pretty big through about 5K with La Mere, Jenkins, and Padgett all taking pulls at the front and Grant sitting right in the thick of things.  At this point Jake Campbell was hanging around 10th, Jake Brown was around 20th, and Paul and Phil were right around the All American cutoff.  NCC had had some guys fall, and my 'calculated guess' of the team score was that we were up by about 50.  Just after 6K Grant and Colin Cotton had separated from everyone else, and Paul was starting to move up quite a bit.  At 7K Grant and Cotton were still together, but it was clear from looking at them that Grant was the one holding the cards.  After the other guys came by I booked it to the finish straight just in time to see Grant come around the corner by himself.  I thought all summer and all fall that he would win, and to see him actually do it was awesome.  Jake and Paul came in next in 9th and 14th, so they were All Americans too.  Unfortunately the team score didn't turn out like we wanted (NCC 130 Olaf 143), but as Lundin said afterward, 'That's sports.'  2nd place in the nation is still pretty darn good if you ask me, and I'm glad I went out to watch this.  Another big trophy for the display case, 3 more All American awards, and the individual champ...great day to be an Ole.

I desperately needed to sleep in today, so I waited to run until after the Packer game.  This was my last ~2 hour run (besides the marathon) of 2014, which is a little strange to think about.  Fittingly I did the traditional out and back over the Stone Arch Bridge.  The 40+ degree weather felt great...it was so nice to wear half tights, light gloves, and a baseball hat rather than my heavy stuff.  My legs felt good.  For a little while on the way back I felt like I was having some trouble breathing, but that went away.

Putting in a request to the weather gods: Please give me clean paths and minimal wind for my final big workout on Wednesday morning.  I don't care if it snows a foot a day after that as I can run inside during my taper, but I would really like to get a good effort in on Wednesday.
Should have stuck to indoor morning runs.  I wiped out on some ice and went down hard.  My left shin really hurts.  I'm lucky that I didn't break anything.

From work at lunch.  I took last night off from running because my shin was swollen from my fall and walking still wasn't pain free.  Fortunately I didn't have any problems running today, so I should be good to go.

3 x 16 minutes at 'marathon effort' (3:00 recovery)

It snowed a couple of inches in the Twin Cities last night.  Since the river road paths weren't clear I decided to leave for Appleton and do the workout there.  On my warmup I found that sidewalks were shoveled, but not scraped clean.  I wanted to repeat the 3 x 3 miles workout that I did before Grandma's, but conditions weren't going to allow for hitting consistent splits so I left my GPS inside and went off of effort.  When the footing was decent I had a good pace going; when it was bad I was still working hard but definitely running slower.  After the second rep I wanted to split the last one into 2 x 8 min.  I'm glad I didn't.  I'm kind of worried about the fact that I haven't been able to get pace data on any of my last several long workouts so I don't know exactly where I'm at.  I was hitting good splits before the snow came, and I've still gotten good efforts in these past few weeks, so I just have to trust that things are going to come together next Sunday.  The hay's pretty much in the barn now.
Hampster wheel during the Lions/Bears game

Standard Xavier loop.  There was probably a half inch of snow on the sidewalks but for doing a normal run the footing was fine.  Legs felt good.  Next Sunday is now on the 10 day forecast so I can start checking that obsessively.
Hampster wheel in the basement.  That thing is a piece of junk.

Went to the Y to do this.  They were running a promotion where guests got in free when accompanied by a member, so I found a member and followed them in.  Did the warmup and cruise intervals on a treadmill, then the strides and cooldown on their 11 lap to the mile track.  Aerobically this was super easy.  The first interval was a little bit of a shock for the legs without having done any drills or strides, but after that things were good.  3 nights in a row of 8-9 hours of sleep has helped me a lot.

'I was made to slay them, ten thousand hours, I'm so damn close I can taste it.'
-Macklemore, 'The Heist'

Gotta love it during tapering when the 'long' run is barely farther than a standard distance run.  Ran to Jefferson School, did some loops through downtown, then came back via East South River.  The Patriots had all the sidewalks within a block of the Radisson closed so that their players could walk onto the bus in peace.  That's the first time I've ever seen that.  Went to the game at Lambeau...26-21 win for the Pack.  I bet we see this matchup again in two months.

Windchill of -13.  I thought about running inside but decided that the time would pass faster outside.  Out and back on Shepard.  My face was frozen by the end.  It's been awhile since I've been so glad to finish a run.  At least my legs feel good and the forecast for this weekend looks perfect.
Treadmill at lunch.  Legs felt really good.

Started from Run N Fun with a pretty big group, then I turned around after 2.5 miles and ran back to the store.  I didn't eat very much in between runs so my blood sugar was feeling off the last mile or so.  Luckily I had snacks in my car.  Legs felt good once again.  I also did strides.

Final tuneup workout.  I went to the U of M to do it since I knew I'd feel better working out on the track than on the treadmill.  Everything felt smooth.  I split 5:19, 5:17 for the 2 mile.  On the mile I was 2:29 at the half, ran 73 for the 3rd 400, then eased off to finish in 4:58.  Now it's just 3 easy runs, hopefully some good sleep, and trying not to constantly think about the race.  I'm ready to do this.
Hampster wheel at lunch.  Watched Sportscenter.  A guy came up to me and said that I must have been a cross country runner because 'he could tell based on my form.'
Early morning run on Shepard before my flight to California.  Felt ok but I didn't sleep very well last night.

Ran from the hotel in Sacramento.  I went around a park and past the capitol to a path along the river that the hotel concierge told me about.  Felt really good for about the first 10 minutes, then progressively more sluggish the rest of the time.  Did a few strides by the park afterward.  The rest of the day consisted of watching the Badgers beat Marquette in basketball, going to the expo and technical meeting, dropping off my bottles, eating spaghetti, and watching the Badgers get their ass kicked by Ohio State in football.

The bus left from downtown Sacramento at 5 AM.  I sat next to Mike, a guy originally from London who now lives in San Francisco and trains with Malcolm.  Small world.  We got out to the start and hung out in the tent until it was time to warm up.  I felt pretty good, although the three Gus that I had pinned to my shorts were weighing them down a bit so I ripped one off.  When the gun went off the 2:18 pace rabbits started off faster than planned and I think most of the elite/sub-elite men were keying off of them, so everyone got out hard.  I went through the mile in 5:14 and the main pack was probably 10 seconds up (with the Africans another ~10 seconds ahead of them).  I slowed it down for mile 2, then mile 3 was the only part of the race where I ran with someone for more than about a minute.  We ran a 5:10, which was too fast so I dropped back.  I found my rhythm pretty soon after that, but I was still running a little faster than I had planned on.  In my first marathon I felt effortless for the first 10 miles and this time I didn�t, so I was a little worried, but I decided that if I had started too fast the damage was already done so I might as well just roll with it.  I felt like the course map was a bit deceptive.  The first half of the race was pretty much constantly rolling, and several of the uphills were reasonably long.  Fortunately this was the part of the race where my legs were still fresh and the uphills were balanced out by nice gradual downhills, but through the first half I was thinking, �This is seriously where everyone comes to run fast?!�  That said, the second half of the course definitely is fast.

My official goal coming in was sub 2:22, but I really thought that I was capable of breaking 2:21 so I was targeting a low 1:10 split at the half.  Ended up going through in 1:09:32.  I ran the next 4 miles in 21:02 and when I still felt strong at 17 I realized that unless I totally died I was going to break 2:22 and that I had a real shot at breaking 2:20.  Even at 20 miles I was still on 2:19 low pace.  It started getting pretty tough after that, but I tried to just take it one mile at a time and I didn�t crash anywhere near as badly as at Grandma�s.  I had taken my first Gu at mile 10, then I kept putting off when I was going to take the second one and almost decided that I wasn�t going to, but I did it just before 21.  Despite the fact that I was slowing down I was passing people regularly.  I was 43rd at the half, 29th at 20, and 21st at the finish.  By about mile 24 my quads were pretty much shot.  It felt like I was dying but I was close enough to the end where I knew I�d make it.  I passed two guys somewhere between 25.5 and 26 and ended up putting 35 seconds on them, so they were pretty much crawling.  At the 26 mile mark there was a guy dressed like Jesus holding a sign that said �THE END (of the race) IS NEAR!�  I didn�t really have a �kick�, but I tried to run as strong as possible the last 0.2.

I definitely put out a max effort.  I was able to walk alright after I crossed the line, but my quads hurt badly and my stomach was absolutely destroyed.  I tried to eat some lunch, but my body couldn�t digest it and for the next several hours pretty much all I could do was lay around and watch football.  I�ve never felt so bad for such an extended period of time after a race.  Eventually I rallied a bit and was able to enjoy some pizza and beer in the evening.

Obviously I�m thrilled with how this went.  I thought that I was capable of a time like this on my best day, but I almost never hit those �best day� goals so I told myself I�d be happy with anything under 2:22.  Running 2:20:16 now makes sub 2:18 seem like something that I can actually think about rather than just dream about.  My training cycle (13 weeks) went just about perfectly.  If I could do it again there are only a couple of small things that I would change.  The longer workouts that I did definitely helped me, and I�ll follow a similar blueprint for the next one.  The number of texts and Facebook messages that I got afterward was almost overwhelming.  I had no idea that so many people were interested in my race, and I appreciate the support a lot.  Now I�m going to enjoy some downtime and then figure out how I want to approach 2015.
Rest.  Traveled back from Sacramento.  My quads are really sore.
Rest.  Still pretty sore.

Legs are starting to feel better.  I should be able to run this weekend.

'So, yes, I believe that 2:18 is a relative cinch given appropriate weather, a fast course, no injuries, no illness, and excellent training.  That's not asking too much, is it?'
-E-mail from Griff
Rest day #4
Rest day #5.  I think I'll start up again tomorrow but take another day or two off next week.  Went to the Wolves game and saw them get crushed by OKC, then went out with the Pod 24 crew.

Easy run to St Thomas and back.  Legs felt a bit heavy but I think at this point light running will help them more than sitting around.  I also was up until about 4:30 AM last night so that probably contributed to feeling lethargic.  Nice 47 degree temperatures, although it's gray and dreary looking outside.
Lake St to Ford.  Felt mediocre.  Jordy Nelson dropped a pass that if caught would have resulted in a 94 yard touchdown and given wins to both the Packers and my fantasy team.

Ran an out and back on Shepard in the morning.  Didn't feel very good...sluggish legs and a slight headache.  This gray and foggy weather continues.  I haven't seen the sun since I left California last Monday.
After running 3 days in a row and not feeling very good on any of those runs I took today off.  Did a power hour at Run N Fun in the evening with a couple other guys.
Pretty much the same story as Monday with a sluggish morning run.  The marathon was only 10 days ago, but it seems like my recovery is taking forever.  I guess that's fine; I've definitely got time.

Ford to Franklin.  Not much motivation this morning but I decided to just do a more normal length run and see what happened.  My legs actually felt decent.  Passed last year's mileage total.  With 13 days left I should be able to get to the 4200 range.

I intended to run today but I was too tired to get out of bed in the morning and then didn't get home from work in time to get one in before going out.  I'll get some consistency going again next week.
Ran out and back on Shepard.  Legs felt good, but I still don't have a lot of motivation right now.

The weather was gross so I ended up just waiting until the evening and running on the treadmill during the first half of the Wolves game.  Messed around with the speed and incline quite a bit in order to keep things interesting.  The Wolves are terrible.  Legs felt good again.
Ran out and back on Shepard before driving back to Appleton.  Felt good...certainly better than I expected to after going to bed at around 4 AM last night.  It was in the mid 30s and lightly raining.

Xavier loop.  I felt really good today and I was cruising.  The 41 degree temperature probably helped.  Going down College Ave a lady looked at me and said, 'Man, you're fast as hell!'  Did four hard strides at the end.
I chose a route that I thought was around 8 miles, but it turned out to be 7.  Just called it good rather than adding on.  Didn't feel as good as yesterday, but it wasn't too bad.  Lightly raining.

8 x Banta Bowl Hill

First workout since the marathon.  I ate scrambled eggs that were loaded with cheese and bacon about 2 hours before running, so for pretty much the whole warmup I felt like I was going to hurl.  The workout itself was pretty easy.  I was surprised how many people were out walking or running on Christmas.
Out and back on the CE Trail.  It was 41 degrees.  I'd really enjoy another winter like 2011-12, but I'm not betting on it.  Felt good, cruising sub 6:30s pretty easily.

Usual Appleton long run route out to Butte des Morts and around Pierce and Lutz parks before coming back through downtown.  Added a mile at the end to make it 16.  Started off running into a fairly stiff wind, then when I got the wind at my back I was getting pretty warm.  I never felt all that great today.  Legs were tired when I finished.

Ran with Marie.  We went downtown via the Oneida St bridge.  It was nice to catch up with her; the last time we ran together was over 3 years ago.  Packer game in the afternoon...Rodgers aggravated his calf injury in the 2nd quarter but returned in the 3rd to lead us to a 30-20 win and 4th consecutive NFC North title.

Back in St Paul.  Malcolm Richards is in town so we met up for a run.  We did an out and back from the roundabout by Minnehaha Park to the Franklin bridge, then I added on a bit.  Bumped into Adam Frye during the add on so I ran with him for a few minutes.  My legs felt surprisingly good after driving.  It's getting colder...today it was in the single digits with the windchill below 0.
Starting up with doubling again.  Ran inside, as I probably will do on basically every morning run for the next 2-3 months.

Ran on the treadmill at my office after work.  Watched the 2 OTs of the Maryland v Michigan State basketball game and then some football.  Legs felt good which was surprising since I was tired all day sitting at my desk.

The year doesn't end until tomorrow but I'm going to jump the gun a bit with the 'year in review'.

Positives From 2014
1. I started the year with a half marathon PR that was big for my confidence after how poorly the second half of 2013 went.
2. I stayed healthy, aside from an off and on hamstring problem that for the most part I could run through.  Didn't have any extended breaks in training.
3. I made significant strength gains from consistently doing longer long runs and tempos.
4. In this sport one great race at the right time can make a season (or a year) a success, and my run at CIM certainly qualifies.  To put so much energy and focus into one event and have it turn out as well as it did was immensely satisfying.

Negative(s)
1. Aside from Houston and CIM the rest of my racing this year was kind of lackluster.  During the spring I was consistently about 5 seconds per mile off of where I wanted to be.  I attribute this to not following a proper workout progression in February and March after Houston.  Food poisoning wiped out Victory and I think was also still affecting me at Alumni.  The TC 10K and Des Moines were good runs - nothing to jump up and down about, but everything was geared towards CIM at that point.  All that said, if you write Victory off due to the GI issues the only race this year that I really bombed was the LAX 10K.  From 2010 - 2013 I probably had 5+ terrible races each year, so I can live with one bad day.

What's Next
The first part of the year will be geared towards shorter races.  I'll probably run 2 races indoors, then hopefully something around the beginning of March depending on what I can find, and then Shamrock on 3/29.  I would like another shot at a track 10K but I doubt that it will happen this spring since unfortunately there aren't any real good ones that don't require a multiple day trip.  The big goal for the year is to run sub 2:18.  I haven't fully decided when my next marathon will be but right now I'm leaning towards Grandma's.  If I decide to wait until the fall or if I don't hit the standard there I'll run Chicago in October.

20 min tempo
5 x Ford Hill

I left work at about 2:00, then did this relatively easy workout.  Really cold out but I didn't want to do it on the treadmill.  The tempo felt kind of weird.  Not sure what my pace was...I'd say there's a very good chance I ran slower than I did for the first 4 miles at CIM.  I pushed the hills a little but it was hard to really get going in the cold.  Swung into the liquor store at the end to get some supplies for tonight.

Ran Ford to Franklin before the Badger game. I found Kampf and his dog on the other side of the Ford bridge so I ran a few minutes with them, then just before Franklin I caught up to Kotek, Emily, and Kara so we all ran together for a bit, then I ended up running a couple miles with just Kara after the other two turned off. Warmer than yesterday. I then spent the next 13 hours (11 AM - midnight) watching football.
Morning jog. I went outside since it looks like I'll be on the treadmill a bunch next week.
River road. Didn't feel that good. I didn't eat breakfast after my run this morning and I think it screwed me up for the rest of the day.

Slept in this morning, which I needed. Got out at around 1:00 for a long run over the Stone Arch. It was about 30 degrees, so that felt great. Tomorrow Old Man Winter hits us with a 4-5 day cold blast. Felt pretty good on this, and I negative split it by a shade over 2 minutes. Saw Tyler Wadsworth by the Stone Arch Apartments.
Ran on the hampster wheel during the 2nd half of the Lions/Cowboys game. The treadmill stopped 3 or 4 different times, which got kind of annoying. Legs felt decent but the run dragged on a bit.
Easy morning shakeout. Had some weird dreams last night.

First workout of 2015 at the U. It was cold as F on the warmup...the board at TCF Bank Stadium said -1 and there was a solid wind. Got in the fieldhouse and the Augsburg team was in there so before I started I talked to Ruter for a few minutes. The 800s went ok. I hit the goal times, but I felt really rusty and uncoordinated on the track. Started off with a 39 second 200 then after that my pacing was pretty good. It's going to take time to get my body in shape for 5K/8K/10K races. Next week when I do an intro VO2 workout I'll get a better idea of where I'm at.
7 AM treadmill run. Kept the pace easy and time passed reasonably quickly.

The wind chill is around -40 this morning. In my previous years of winter running the longest streak I've had of days where I need to run inside because of weather is 6. Today is day 4, and it's not looking good for getting out until at least Saturday.

More treadmill time. I realized mid afternoon that the Badgers played at 6:00, so that was nice. Legs felt great tonight. About halfway through I started getting really hungry and kind of wanted to stop, but I told myself to pretend that I was six miles out on river road and finished it. Badgers won a tight one.

5 x 6 min @ Goal MP (5:15 pace, 3 min @ 7:00 pace between)
1 x 0.5 miles @ 12 MPH (2:30 800)
Total: 8.4 miles in 47:30 (5:39 average pace)

Pretty good treadmill workout. As usual, felt like I was turning my legs over super fast. My lungs never felt all that stressed, so my aerobic system must not have fallen off too much during my break. Hopefully this weather will let up soon; I'm getting tired of the hampster wheel.

Treadmill during lunch. There was a documentary about the Ice Bowl on ESPN that started at midnight last night and I stayed up watching it, so between that and the workout I was tired today. There are two showers in the locker room and the water takes a long time to warm up, so right after I finish running I always go turn one on. As I was grabbing my soap and towel another guy jumped in and sniped my shower, then he proceeded to stay in there for about 10 minutes. There was also somebody in the other one, so I was SOL. Jerk.

Fortunately, I was able to get outside today. Unfortunately, the long run didn't go well. I was planning on going 1:50 - 2:00 in Appleton, but when I got over by Pierce Park (4 miles in) I started having some pain in my left knee. I stopped to walk for a minute and decided I'd just run back to the house. As I did this the pain went away, so I ran some extra loops to get more distance. I wanted to finish out the run, but at about 10 miles I started having bathroom issues and then feeling weak and a little light headed. My 13th and 14th miles were well over 7 minute pace and I started feeling the knee again, so I called it a day.

Dinner at Vince Lombardi's Steakhouse and sat two tables away from Jerry Jones and his entourage. Super pumped for the game tomorrow.

Early morning run to Appleton West and back. Saw the buses in front of the Radisson and ran past a bunch of Cowboys fans. My legs didn't feel very good. Stopped and did strides on a clear sidewalk with about a mile left since Brentwood Lane is covered with snow/ice.

Packers 26 Cowboys 21. GO PACK GO!
Morning run on the wheel. Felt alright.

Intro VO2 workout. The track was pretty crowded with people warming up for the Meet of Miles. It's been 4 months since I've done a workout like this so I wanted to start with something manageable. After 3 days in a row of not feeling very good this was a great turn around. I split 2:20 and 2:21 through 800 on the first two intervals. The 400s were clockwork. After cooling down a little bit I watched the first two mile heats, then I went for another cooldown with John Davis, Thies, A Town, and Merchant.

Run N Fun. We did a Summit to River Road to Highland loop (opposite way of how we usually do it), then Jake Smith and I added on at the end. Legs felt decent but I had some dull pain in my left knee off and on. Not too worried about it yet but it's something to monitor. Chipotle and a Timberwolves win (first one in a month!) afterwards.

Yesterday I said I wasn't worried about my knee; today I am. Pain was constant while running and is much more pronounced. I'm going to take the next two days off and see how it feels on the weekend. Hopefully this is just a blip on the radar screen.
Day off. Knee feels fine walking around, but it did yesterday too.
Rest

Ran on West River and the greenway. I think this is the first time I've run on the greenway from my apartment. After two days off the knee was a lot better. 35 degrees. Would've been a great day for a 2 hour run, but that would've been stupid.

I was planning on doing a similar run as yesterday but my knee wasn't feeling very good. It didn't hurt a lot but it didn't feel very stable and my stride didn't feel powerful. Turned off and just did a Lake St bridge loop. Since I won't be able to run a workout for at least a few days I then jumped on the elliptical for a simulated tempo. Knee was not an issue doing this. The Packers lost 28-22 in OT after leading the entire game and being up 12 with 5 minutes left.
30 min elliptical right after the run. 5 warmup, 20 'tempo', 5 cooldown. HR in the 160s for most of this, topped at 175.

8 miles out and back on Shepard. The temperature was in the 20s and I didn't want to watch highlights of yesterday's game so I went outside. It'll be nice when it's not dark at 7 AM. My knee wasn't 100%, but it was the best it's been in awhile and my stride felt reasonably normal. Things seem to be looking up.
Felt good doubling back this evening. The weather is so much nicer than two weeks ago.

5 x Ford Hill

I wanted to see how the knee would react to faster running so I did a few hills. Things went well. I'm thinking cross train tonight, a normal length run tomorrow, then a fartlek on Thursday. As long as I don't have any more hiccups I should still be ready to race by the St Thomas 5K.
44 minutes elliptical. Went to Bar Louie with Prez and Luke afterward.

We got a dusting of snow last night, but for a normal run the footing was fine. Hopefully the city will clear the path so I don't have to go to the track tomorrow. I went out and back to the U of M hospital, then added on a bit to make it 11. The knee was good. I saw at least 25 people out biking. Seems a little foolish to bike in 20 degrees and snow, but I'm not the one doing it.

10 min tempo
2 x 2:00, 2 x 1:30, 4 x 1:00, 4 � 0:30, 4 � 0:15 (equal time jog rest)

Started the warmup at 8:30 PM. The short tempo was basically an extension of the warmup, then the idea with the intervals was to start at around 5K pace and keep speeding up until I was pretty much sprinting at the end. I might have started a little slow, but I achieved the goal of getting the heart rate into the anaerobic zone. Legs felt like crud on the warmup but got better.

Slow run on the treadmill. I had to work late again and it took less mental effort to spin the hampster wheel while watching the Wolves and the Australian Open than it would have taken to go outside. Felt good. Tired most of the day because I couldn't fall asleep last night after finishing that workout at 10 PM.

Late morning/early afternoon long run. Absolutely beautiful day. I think the temperature hit 40. I started off heading towards the Stone Arch Bridge, as usual. Ran into Jake Campbell and some other guys, so I ran with them for a few minutes, then I bumped into Mike Mittelsteadt and ran a couple miles with him. Ended up with some extra distance because the route I took home was longer than I thought it would be. A lot of this run was around 6 minute pace. Wasn't planning on that, but I was feeling good. Mittelsteadt said that we were running 5:40 pace (according to his watch) when we were started running together but I don't really believe that. Four strides at the end.

Ran with Kieser and Roni on a loop in Mendota Heights. The route was very hilly, there was ice on most of it, and we had a steady pace going, so it wasn't as easy of a run as I was hoping for after yesterday. Still nice to get some company. I was thinking about doubling today but decided not to since I've already increased my volume quite a bit from last week and I figure some rest can't hurt.
Out and back on Shepard. Took fall #2 for the winter coming out of the tunnel by 35E. Fortunately it wasn't anywhere near as bad as fall #1 was. Felt ok.
42 min on the elliptical. Watched the Wolves, who at the moment are the worst team in the NBA. Felt pretty good. I may do one of my doubles each week on the elliptical for the rest of the winter.

No morning run - stayed up late last night and wanted to get 7 hours of sleep instead of 4-5 extra miles. On my warmup through the U of M campus some kids (probably freshmen) complimented me on my tights and told me to 'take my fucking hat off.' The workout went fairly well. Based on how I was feeling by the end of the last 600 I'm not ready for 14:40 yet, but I still think I can get there with a few more workouts over the course of the next two weeks.

Slogged a slow 8 miles from my office after work. The first half of this I probably didn't break 7:20 pace. My legs aren't too bad in general after yesterday's workout, but my knee is worse than it has been. Hopefully it'll be back near 100% tomorrow.

It was tough to get out of bed this morning since last night I worked until about midnight again, but about 3 miles into the run I started feeling really good. My knee was a non-issue. Super windy. Time for another long day.

Ended up getting home from work after 10 PM and scrapped my double since I was hungry and tired and at that point running 5-6 more miles would probably just take away from tomorrow morning's workout. That's 3 skipped doubles in 5 days. Unfortunately next week at work looks like it will be even worse than this one.

Tempo - out in 15:00, back in 14:10
5 x 30 seconds @ mile effort (1:00 jog)

Since I'm short on sleep it took a lot of effort to get out the door this morning, but thanks to my relatively low mileage the past few days my legs felt fresh and I had a good workout. Got into a good groove and gradually sped up as I went. No splits but I imagine I was running at least marathon pace, and probably faster at the end.

Drove down to St Olaf with Dan, Sathre, and Kieser for the 3K. I ran the warmup with the guys plus an extra mile by myself, took a break to socialize and watch the race, then did the cooldown. My legs felt terrible the first 5 minutes, then good the rest of the time. Really exciting race to watch - Grant 8:13, Sathre 8:14, Jake 8:20, Greeno 8:23, Easker 8:24. For a few laps in the middle I thought Ben was going to run away with it, but Grant caught him and then outkicked him the last 400. Grant and Jake are 1-2 in the nation right now. Capped off the night with dinner at Basil's.

Easy out and back on West River and the Greenway. My knee was a little sore when I first woke up this morning but by the time I ran (3:30 PM) it was feeling fine. Made sure to keep the pace easy since I probably did a little too much yesterday.

Started off planning on doing a long run but had a stabbing pain in my knee 1 mile in so I stopped and walked home. The pain was in a different spot from where it had been. Racing on the indoor track the next two weekends might have to be re-evaluated. I want to race at St Thomas, but not if I'm going to be out for a month afterward. We'll see. It felt fine later in the day. It's also a little frustrating that I'm only getting a good long run in every 3 weeks right now. Good thing I've still got almost 5 months until Grandma's.

Epic Super Bowl this evening. Probably the best one ever.

Got out there this evening and I was feeling really good so I decided that I'd do the long run that I didn't do yesterday. This means tomorrow's workout moves to Wednesday, which is better for my work schedule anyways. Knee felt totally normal. I don't get it. I threw in some sub 6s from about miles 8 to 12, then I made myself slow down.

Easy run on the wheel...didn't want to take any chances outside after it snowed all afternoon. Watched the 2nd half of the Badger game. My legs felt good but I was super hungry. My body must be in a calorie deficit right now because I've inhaled all three meals that I've eaten today and then each time I've been hungry again an hour later.
Shakeout before tonight's workout. Tired. Work is kind of destroying my life right now.

Easy run #2 for the day at 9:15 PM.

Ran at lunch. It was a nice sunny day, so I'm glad I got out. There wasn't a whole lot that was clear of snow so I ran a couple out and backs on the same stretch. Felt ok. Goals for tomorrow are a) finish without getting injured and b) don't embarrass myself.

***RACE***
Race Name: Bethel Invite
Terrain: Track (Indoor)
Warm Up: 4
Race Splits: 65, 66, 68, 66
Cool Down: 6
Overall Place: 9th

I wasn't too involved in the actual race seeing as the next guy ahead of me beat me by 4 seconds and then it was another 5 seconds to the first guy behind me, but I feel like this was a solid rust buster. 400 meters in I was already feeling the pace. 800 in I was off the back of the train, but when I looked at the clock at 1K and saw 2:45 I realized that I was still doing alright so I tried to stay engaged mentally. Not much of a gear shift for the last 200. I recovered reasonably quickly afterward; in a way it felt more like a really hard interval than an all our race. This was a post college PR and I didn't hurt myself doing it (knee felt fine both during and after), so I'll take it. I think I can run 14:4X on Friday.
I just did a medium long run this week because of the 5K coming up. Legs felt really good; not sore from yesterday. I ran the last hour with Paul, so that was fun.

Ran out and back on river road. I really wanted to go back to sleep for another hour this morning but I'll be glad tonight that I got the run in. Crossed paths with Easker and Reneau. My knee started complaining at about mile 7 and shortly after St Thomas I had to take a short walk break. For a minute I thought I was going to have to walk all the way back to my apartment, but then it mysteriously went away and I ran it in. Did strides afterward without a problem. This is the weirdest 'injury' I've ever had.

Easy morning run. Last night I went to bed with probably the worst stomach ache I've ever had. Felt better this morning, although not totally normal. Hopefully I'll be able to get to the track tonight; roads are probably going to be nasty looking at the forecast.
