Pretty slow getting out the door this morning because I was tired.  The path was covered in a combination of ice, slush, and sand.  Felt better by the second half of the run.

Easy run after a work happy hour that I didn't drink at.  It's really cold out.  My legs feel really good.  Got put in the fast heat.  Tomorrow is going to be fun.

Piggybacking on Jake Campbell's goals post
A+ race: sub 14:40
A race: sub 14:44 (would be 10 sec PR)
B race: sub 14:53 (current PR is 14:53.17)
C race: 14:53.18 - 14:59.99
Race day shakeout.  If I feel like this tonight it'll be a good one.

Ran on the hampster wheel at my office.  My calves were a little sore after last night's race, but I'm not too beat up.  I found out yesterday that I can't go to Shamrock because of work, so I'm going to have to revise my spring training and racing schedule.  I'd love to run a track 10K in early April, but I don't think there is one available.  The most likely scenario is that basically everything from this point forward will be geared towards Grandma's (18 weeks from today).

Waited until 3:30 PM to run so that it would be a little warmer, but the wind chill was still about -5.  I ran down Shepard and just about got to the turn to my office before I flipped.  Felt good for the most part.  I had the Space Jam theme song stuck in my head for a lot of the run after last night's dunk contest.  Glad to get back inside at the end.
Out and back on river road.  Not much motivation tonight, but I felt good when I got out there.  Had some discomfort in the knee.
Easy morning jog on the wheel.  An older lady got mad because I had the TV on Sportscenter instead of Good Morning America.

I brought running stuff to work, figuring I'd run on the treadmill there at the end of the day, but when 7:30 rolled around I decided I'd rather run outside despite the cold so I went home and headed out.  This was a horrible idea.  The wind chill was somewhere between -10 and -15 and gusts kept blasting me right in the face.  Usually on a cold day I'll kind of forget about it after a mile or two, but this was miserable.  It was one of those evenings where I wondered why of all the things that I could do with my time I choose to do this.  3 miles in I couldn't take it anymore so I turned around and went back.  Ended up running this segment pretty fast so I could get home sooner, then I finished the run inside.  Hopefully spring comes earlier this year than it did the past two years.

4 x 7 min @ 5:15 pace (3:00 @ ~7:00 pace in between)
1 x 2 min @ 5:00 pace
Total: 7.4 miles in 42 minutes (5:40 average pace)

Did this on the treadmill.  Watching the Badger basketball game got me through it.  At the start of the workout I thought that I would do 5 x 7:00, but this was harder than I thought it was going to be so I called it at 4.  A 5th would've required a big effort and I didn't want to dig a hole on my first long workout in awhile.  Did the final short interval because I want to be used to picking up the pace at the end of something like this.  As always on the treadmill it felt like I was running much faster than I actually was.  It's also been quite awhile since I've done 58 miles in 4 days, so that could explain having heavy legs.  It's hard to fathom running 5:15s for over 2 hours continuously when doing 4 x 7 minutes isn't a cakewalk, but a) I suck at running workouts on the treadmill and b) I've got 4 months.

Easy run on Shepard.  It's still cold (2 degrees, light winds), but not as bad as Tuesday.  My legs were tired most of the day but after about a mile of running they felt much better.  Thought back to 5 years ago today and the 2010 Snowshoe Open, which was one of the most fun evenings I've ever had at a track meet.
Morning run.  Need to get some sleep this weekend.

Ran from the U in between the mile and the 3K.  I did four miles with the guys cooling down after the mile, then another six by myself.  Legs felt pretty good.  Oles had another good night on the track.

Way too cold to run outside today (wind chill below -20), so I decided to move the long run to tomorrow.  It makes my weekly total look a little low, but my rolling 7 was over 90 yesterday and will be again after tomorrow, so it's fine.  Ran 11 on the treadmill at about noon.  The sun was pointing directly at the windows of my building's fitness center, so it was a bit of a sweat fest.  Legs felt really good.  There's a chance I'll elliptical or do a second run later.
36 min elliptical.  Got some extra aerobic work in, saved the pounding on my legs.

Monday evening long run, basically to the Science Museum.  Same route as last week, just a mile shorter.  It was warmer than yesterday but there was a decent wind.  The stretch into the wind wasn't very fun, but when I got the wind at my back I closed the last 4 miles in sub 24:00.  Legs felt great the entire run.  Could have run all day!

Easy shakeout on the treadmill at lunch.  Had to run then instead of first thing in the morning because last night the movie Rain Man came on at 10:30 and I ended up watching the entire thing.  Hill workout coming up in a few hours.

10 x Ford Hill

Had a pretty nice tailwind behind me going up the hill, which definitely made this easier.  I was tired by the time I finished but not wrecked.  Could have done a couple more if I had needed to.

Easy run at lunch.  My legs were dead when I first woke up this morning but by noon they felt better.  Wind chill was about 0, but it was nice to get outside when it was sunny out.  On my way back someone pulled up next to me in their car and talked to me for a minute.  I didn't recognize him but he said my name so he definitely knew me.  I still haven't figured it out who it was.

Wind chills are back to -20, so I was on the treadmill this morning.  Legs felt great after yesterday's easy day.  Watched the DVD of last night's Wolves game.  I was at the game so it was cool to watch it again and hear everything the announcers were saying about Garnett.  The atmosphere at the Target Center last night was absolutely electric and the Wolves looked like a really good team after the first 8 minutes.  I'm already excited for the potential that next season has if everyone stays healthy.
Lake St to Ford after work.  The wind chill was about -10.  I'm so tired of winter.  Did strides afterward and felt flat.  Felt fine on the run though.

25 min tempo
6 x 1 min hard / 1 min easy

I did NOT want to do this tonight.  Scheduling a workout for a Friday evening was probably not my greatest decision ever.  But, once I got going, things went well.  Found a real nice groove on the tempo.  I mapped it out later and I averaged 5:10s, which is cruising considering the 0 degree wind chill and all the clothes I was wearing.  The fartlek was alright.  Hard to really get rolling when it's so cold, plus towards the end I was having some GI distress.
This run sucked.  I was under dressed and tired from yesterday.

Solid long run on the usual route (past the Stone Arch Bridge).  It was in the 20s and sunny, so we're moving closer to spring at least.  I rolled sub 6s most of the way back and felt strong doing it.  First 100 mile week since before CIM, although there's an asterisk on it since it included two long runs.

I'm still undecided about racing next weekend.  I don't really have much to gain from it and would kind of like to just keep this training rhythm going, but on the other hand it might not be the best idea to go 2 months (from 2/13 to 4/11) without any races.

Didn't get out the door until late after getting bogged down in something at work.  Did 10 miles, basically to 35E and back.  Legs felt a little better than I thought they would after the long run.  Finished with 5 strides.  I'm really looking forward to next week when it will be light out after work.  The extended forecast has some 'shorts weather' in it too.

Snoozed through my morning run.  Wasn't too upset about it since I wasn't really looking forward to running on the treadmill twice in one day anyways.  It was a(nother) long day at work and I almost bagged the evening run too.  My thought process went kind of like this:

'It snowed today, it's cold out, and it's 8:00.  I could just take today off, consider this a down week, and get the miles back up next week when the weather will be nicer.'
'I don't need a down week right now and I've got one coming in two weeks anyways.'
'I guess I'll start a run.  If I'm still this unmotivated after 5 miles I'll call it a day and try again tomorrow.'

Somehow 5 minutes into the run I started feeling great and I ended up going 75 minutes.
Slept 6 hours last night.  Woke up feeling like I had slept for about 10 minutes.

Well, looks like I'll be taking somewhat of a down week after all.  I didn't want to leave work early today to go to the indoor track so I attempted a treadmill workout.  The plan was 6 x 5 minutes at 5:12 pace with 2 minutes steady in between.  On the third rep my knee started bugging me, then I stopped the workout 2 minutes into #4 because I was really altering my stride.  I don't think it will take long to get this under control, but racing this weekend is probably out.  Not worth taking any risks for this one.  Knee aside I was feeling strong.  Running fast on the treadmill doesn't seem to agree with me.  This whole issue started back in January after a treadmill workout, and before tonight I hadn't had any problems for awhile.  Stuff like this further solidifies the fact that if I qualify for the trials I will go someplace warmer for 6-8 weeks before the race in order to do all of my training outside.
Day off to let the knee calm down.  Went to the Wisconsin v Minnesota basketball game at The Barn with Mark.  Badgers dominated.  Outright Big 10 champs!

Ran from my office at 1:30 PM before leaving to drive back to Appleton.  Absolutely glorious weather - upper 30s and sunny.  Wore half tights for the first time since around Christmas.  I was so excited about the weather it would have been impossible to have a bad run.  Knee was not an issue.  This'll be a low week because of the past few days, but I think I'll be pretty much back in the saddle tomorrow.

Ran out the CE Trail to Kaukauna.  The weather was about the same as yesterday, if not a couple degrees warmer.  I had to stomp through some puddles and slush, but I didn't care.  Solid pace for pretty much the whole run.

Xavier loop.  I felt good but made a conscious effort to run slower than yesterday so that I won't be dead for tomorrow's workout.  I passed a lady who was walking her dog right as I was coming up to Xavier, then passed her again right away after I turned around and she gave me a really weird look.
Lake St to Ford in the dark after I got back to St Paul.  Really nice night outside.  Dreaming of racing a 10K under the lights, which unfortunately won't be happening this spring.

1 hour sub-tempo

5:53, 5:50, 5:49, 5:51, 5:41, 5:42, 5:46, 5:44, 5:43, 5:47 (57:46 through 10 miles)
Total: 10.40 miles in 60:00 (5:46 average)

This was the first time I've done one of these in four months, so I wanted it to be pretty easy.  It was.  Kieser ran the first 8 miles with me and we were talking the entire time.  It was great to have a workout partner.  Strangely enough our two fastest miles were the hilly section of East River.  After the St Thomas hill we dialed it back a notch since I didn't want to get any faster.  I know I've wrote about the weather the past several days, but this early spring (especially now combined with daylight savings time)  is seriously exhilarating after running in the dark and cold all winter.  It was almost 60 degrees today and I wore shorts and a t shirt.  Crazy that just last week there were a couple days where it was too cold to run outside.  Stretched outside on the lawn afterward, then a 'recovery' Spotted Cow and a steak.  Great day.

Lilydale with the Run N Fun group plus some extra at the end.  I didn't feel great so I didn't really appreciate the 6:20 pace that people were throwing down.  Oh well, it's not a big deal.  Nice to run with the team.

I was hoping to go a little further this morning but was too slow getting out the door so I only had time for 5.  Last night I put some cream on my knee and hamstring before I went to bed and then I kept waking up during the night because it burned for several hours.  Not fun.
Out and back on East River.  Felt bad.  I'm not really sure why, must be lack of sleep.
I slept better last night but still felt sluggish this morning.

Rough one this evening.  My self assigned workout was 10 x 600 at 1:45 - 1:47 (what should be about 5K pace), but my legs were as flat as the track I was running on.  I was able to get through 6.  The pace was decent but the effort was much more than it should take to run this pace.  Since I needed to do more than 6 x 600 in order to make the workout worthwhile I decided to do 2 sets of 5 x 200 with 200 jog.  Never got faster than a 32.  I'm not sure why I feel so bad.  There's no reason that Monday's run should have cashed me for the rest of the week so it's got to be something else.  Perhaps I need a Nick Ross style pizza and beer binge.  An easy day is definitely on tap for tomorrow.  Bad workout aside it was nice to be running on the outdoor track on March 12th.  That's about a month earlier than last year.

Easy six on Shepard.  I almost took the day off but decided it'd be better to move a little rather than just sit around.  I  ran REALLY slowly; basically cooldown pace the entire time.  Hoping to feel better tomorrow.
Ran with Kieser and Roni on a trail in South St Paul.  Legs felt a little less like cement today but still nowhere near 'good'.  We'll have to see about 20 tomorrow.

Short run to St Thomas and back at sunset.  I also did a few strides.  Felt alright.  Indoor nats was exciting - wouldn't believe the results if I hadn't seen the races.  Still can't believe that St Olaf has 3 individual national champs this year and got a team trophy with only 3 entrants in the meet.

I slept almost 11 hours last night.  Needed it.  My legs felt better today than they have since the beginning of the week.  I went all the way up Summit and down John Ireland to the TCM finish line, cut through downtown to the river, out nearly to the Warner bridge, then all the way back via Shepard.  Great temperature but it was windy.  Spent the rest of the day watching an awesome Badger game and looking at brackets.

I set my alarm to run this morning but immediately after it went off I passed out again for another 90 minutes.  Because of that I didn't have a chance to run until about 9:30 PM since I have a lot to get done at work before I leave on Wednesday.  I'm just going to get in whatever miles I can this week and not worry about it being a specific number.  Hopefully I won't destroy my body too badly in Vegas and when I come back I should be ready for a 13 week marathon cycle.  Things haven't gone super well the past couple weeks, but I still think I'm in better shape now than I was at the end of August so with a little over 3 months until Grandma's I'm alright with where I'm at.
A little colder this morning, but mid 20s is certainly tolerable.  Legs felt good.
Out and back on East River, again in the dark.  Felt alright for the most part.  By the time I got to St Thomas on the way back I was pretty hungry so I didn't finish the run super strong.

4 miles at marathon pace - 20:50
Jog across the Ford Bridge
5 x Ford Hill

I had thoughts about trying to do a real hard workout today since I won't be running much the next few days, but I decided to do a moderate one to stick with the rest week theme.  Didn't feel good on the warmup - flat and tired after a couple of long days.  I ran the tempo on West River.  I told myself that I'd be ok with 5:20s, but once I started I got in a good groove and just kept it consistent.  Splits were 5:14, 5:11, 5:13, 5:12, and I never felt like I was pressing.  The hills were the same as always.  Vegas time.

Got into Vegas at 11 PM last night.  People wanted to go out so I ended up getting to bed at around 3 AM (5 AM central time).  Had been awake for 22 hours minus a 30 minute nap on the plane.  Then we woke up at 7 to get bets in before the basketball games started.  No running today but according to Luke's fitbit we walked over 14 miles.

Placed my bets then went back to our hotel to run while everybody else got breakfast.  There's nowhere to run around The Strip so I ran on the treadmill.  I didn't actually feel that bad all things considered.  At least I ran once on this trip.

We played hard last night and I once again got less than 4 hours of sleep so there was no chance of a run in the morning.  I went for a short shakeout at around 11 PM in St Paul in order to shake off the flight and prime my body for a harder run in the morning.  Fun couple of days in Vegas.  I couldn't do something like this at a key point in a training cycle, so I'm glad the trip fell when it did.

50 minute sub-tempo

Before CIM I had 13 good weeks on training (including taper).  Grandma's is 13 weeks from yesterday, and I think that if I can have a similar block starting now I will be ready to do what I want to do.  Here goes.

After 3 days of minimal running and poor lifestyle choices in general I wasn't sure how I'd feel today.  I didn't exactly feel like a finely tuned machine, but this run still went well.  Averaged sub 5:40 for 50 minutes, which I did not expect.  It was about 30 degrees.  Colder than I'd like, but not bad.  Hustled afterwards to get over to watch the Irish Run.  It would have been fun to be mixing it up in that field.  I had a good time hanging out and talking with everyone but watching the race from the curb didn't feel right.  I'm excited to participate at Get In Gear.
Out and back to the U of M Hospital.  Kept it relaxed and felt fine.
Ran with a big group from Run N Fun.  Randolph to the river to Summit.  Felt decent.

Woke up this morning and was in a fog.  I suited up to run but when I got outside I turned around after a couple of minutes because it just was not happening.  Figured I'd go to work early and hopefully be able to leave in time to do the workout tonight.  As the morning went on I kept feeling worse and worse and could tell that I had a fever.  Told my boss at noon that I was going home, and I ended up taking a six hour nap.  It's not a huge mystery as to why I got sick - I've been getting poor sleep for several weeks and those days in Vegas were really hard on my body.  I cannot afford any more setbacks after this one.
Still in rough shape.  I didn't have a fever today and went to work because of deadline pressure, but after eating nothing yesterday and only a very small amount today I'm feeling pretty weak.
When I woke up this morning I planned on running today but I didn't end up actually doing it.  Worked late.  Here's hoping that today is the last day I miss for about two months.

After three days off for my stomach virus I was able to get out and run today, but that's about all that's positive that I can say about this.  Ran 10 miles on Shepard and it took me about 75 minutes.  I'm still feeling very weak after basically two days of not eating on Wednesday and Thursday.  This run felt like what I imagine the end of an ultramarathon feels like.  Just depleted.  Hopefully my appetite comes back soon so that this can turn around.  Also, apparently I slept funny last night because ever since I woke up this morning both of my shoulders have been extremely sore.

Felt much better running today than I did yesterday.  It was windy out there, and also lightly raining at times.  I spent pretty much the entire thing thinking about last night's Badger game and next week's rematch with Kentucky.  I kind of want to go to Indy for the Final Four but it would be too expensive.
Started off the week with a Lake St to Ford loop.  Felt good.

I was planning on doing this workout last Wednesday, but because of my stomach virus it got pushed back all the way to today.  I ended up running fairly well (covered ~9 miles in 49 minutes including the jogs which were pretty slow), but I felt clunky and out of sorts for most of it.  As my training gets more consistent that should get better.  Nice weather this evening, overall an enjoyable workout.  Closing the books on one of the worst training months I've ever had without being injured.

First Fort Snelling run of the year.  I love running down there.  Really strange weather today - 80 degrees and 30 mph winds.  At the start of the run I ran straight into a wind gust that just about stopped me in my tracks.  Legs were kind of tired today.

Went down to Fort Snelling again but ran on some different paths than yesterday.  I kind of zoned out and ended up turning around a little later than I was supposed to so I ended up with an extra 10 minutes.  If I run tonight I won't go more than 4.  Felt good for the most part but my left hamstring is acting up again.  Hadn't really had any issues with it since before CIM.
Shakeout and 2 strides.  Tired legs.

400s on the track at Mac.  It was a little bit chilly (40 degrees) and the wind picked up as I went along.  I started off with a 73 (I guess the first one was a warmup), then after that it was all 69s and 70s.  It wasn't a very hard workout but the weather and the fact that I was tired coming in made me not all that excited to be doing it.  If the weather is worth an extra second per rep (which seems reasonable), this is real solid.  Now time to recover for Sunday's long run.
10 mile Crosby Farms loop with Adam Dohm.  I was tired starting out but felt better as we went on.  Talked about tonight's game.  GO BADGERS!

Easter Sunday long run.  Had to wait until 3 PM to run after church and letting my lunch digest.  I started with a lap around Nokomis, ran down the creek to Harriet, took a lap around Harriet, then ran home.  I haven't really run on the creek path since last fall so it was a nice change of scenery from river road.  Felt good.  Rolled six flats for most of the second half and closed in about a 5:45.  I'm still riding high from the game last night.

Ran from work before going out to St Louis Park to watch the game.  Legs were a little tired from yesterday, but all in all weren't that bad.  Spent the whole run thinking about the Badgers.

Duke 68 Wisconsin 63.  Couple of very questionable calls in the second half and our shots at key times didn't fall.  Tough to stomach this one, as who knows when the opportunity will come again.
Tired this morning.  Didn't get a lot of sleep last night.

2 x 16 minutes tempo (3:00 rest)
5 x ~150m hard strides

Ran the tempo on West River.  I think my pace was alright, although I didn't wear my GPS watch so I don't know for sure.  Mapped it out later (the next day) and although it's hard to pinpoint exactly where I stopped I averaged somewhere around 5:08-5:10.  Didn't feel all that great.  Probably from getting used to high mileage again.
Easy run around Nokomis.  Felt good to just chill today.

Ran in Fort Snelling.  10 minutes in it started raining, and that continued for the rest of the run.  By the time I finished I was soaked and freezing.  Didn't realize how cold I was until I stopped.  Took a long hot shower afterward to warm up.  Legs felt great this morning.
I thought I was done with indoor running for the year, but I didn't have it in me to run in precipitation (it was snowing outside) twice today.  Ran inside and watched The Masters.
TIRED.  TGIF.
Ran from my office at the end of the day.  Legs felt good but my stomach was a little off.  I did strides by the river at the end, and there were a couple of sketchy looking people hanging around.

10 mile sub-tempo - 55:42
5:34, 5:28, 5:36, 5:35, 5:38, 5:34, 5:38, 5:29, 5:36, 5:33
2 x ~1K @ 3:00 (had a tailwind on these)

My original plan was to do a light fartlek on Friday and then do this on Sunday morning, but the forecast for Sunday was calling for 20+ mph winds so I wanted to get this run done when the weather would be better.  Thus I scrapped the Friday fartlek and instead made today's workout kind of a Joe Moore workout by tacking on a few Ks at the end.  Also, Prez and Kelly got engaged last night so I was out pretty late celebrating that, which led to a later start than planned this morning.  That might have workout out for the better since it was warmer.  

The sub-tempo was really smooth.  My goal pace was 5:40s and I was ahead of that the entire time.  I felt strong and relaxed.  Had to increase the effort a little the last two miles when I was going into the wind, but it still didn't feel like I was really grinding.  I did both Ks with the wind.  I'm not sure how accurate they were, but the effort was there.  That pace felt really fast.  Nice to knock out a strong workout on my birthday.  10 weeks until Grandma's.
Easy run in Fort Snelling to finish out the week.  Super windy today, glad I did the workout yesterday.  My legs didn't feel that tired, so that's encouraging.

Ran out and back to the U of M Hospital.  Yesterday afternoon I fell asleep on the couch while watching The Masters, which then led to not being able to sleep last night, so I was tired this morning.  I came around eventually.  Pretty much perfect weather this morning.

I was planning to do 600s on the track, but both Macalester and SPA had things going on, so I had to switch to the roads.  On my warmup I decided that I'd do a couple longer intervals at the beginning rather than just doing 10 x 2 Minutes.  I started from Minnehaha Park and basically made my way around the Get In Gear course.  On the second 5 minute interval I blew past two bikers who screamed because I scared them, and at the end of the fourth 2 minute interval I passed some kids on the St Thomas hill who made fun of me when I slowed way down about 5 seconds later.  Felt good overall.  I'm glad I got something like this in - it'll help for next week's 10K.
Lake St to Ford.  The mornings have been really nice this week.  Not sore from yesterday.
Out and back on Shepard.  Kind of tired this evening but got through it fine.

Thursday morning run in Fort Snelling for the third week in a row.  About five miles into the run two deer ran across the path no more than 10 feet in front of me.  I was tired when my alarm went off (these six hour nights wear me out by the end of the week), but when I got going I was fine.  My right foot is sore.  Another nice morning outside.
Another morning, another 5 miles.

Had to work late to meet what I considered an unreasonable deadline.  By the time I got home it was dark and I had a headache, so I cut my planned run in half.  It was good to get out there for a little while.

St Olaf put 5 guys under 3:53 at LAX tonight, led by Jake in 3:45.7 and Paul in 3:46.4.  That group continues to amaze.  I strongly doubt that there has ever been another D3 team whose top 6 1500m runners average sub 3:50.  A couple of hours later Sathre ran 13:54 at Mt Sac.  Especially impressive considering he just found out yesterday that he was in the meet and traveled through the night to get there.

Absolutely bombed workout.  I was planning on repeating a workout that I did last fall of 5 miles @ MP + 8 x 1K @ roughly HMP.  I could kind of tell this morning that there wasn't a lot in the tank but I thought I could still get through it.  I started off with the first two miles in 5:17 and 5:19, but by the last half of the second mile I was already pressing to stay on pace.  My 3rd mile was a 5:40 and I was getting slower every minute.  Pulled it there since it does me no good to practice dying at that pace.  Walked for a few minutes then slowly jogged home.

It's been a long, stressful, draining week, and I think things just caught up with me today.  The important thing now is to not let one bad day shake my confidence too much.  Depending on how I'm feeling I may give this another shot on Monday (or do something similar), but I also don't want to beat myself down leading into Get In Gear.
Easy Fort Snelling run.  Pike Island wasn't as full of puddles as I thought it might be after it rained most of the night.  Legs felt pretty decent.

Shakeout in the dark plus 5 strides.  Going to try another workout tomorrow, but I got some good advice to not attempt the exact same thing as yesterday so it will be something similar but with a different structure.

2 x 3.5 miles @ Marathon Effort (3:00 jog between)
5 x Ford Hill Fast

5:29, 5:21, 5:31, 2:42 - 19:03 (5:26 pace)
5:13, 5:15, 5:17, 2:37 - 18:22 (5:15 pace)

The times on this workout (especially on the first rep) don't look all that great, but it was 40 degrees and extremely windy today so I am happy with this.  The first interval was run pretty much all into the wind.  I just focused on keeping the effort where it was supposed to be rather than pressing to hit a pace.  The second one mostly had a crosswind.  On the one half mile segment where I had the wind at my back I ran a 2:34 and it felt like I was recovering.  I had a tailwind for the hills and ran them fast.  I didn't feel all that beat at the end (which is good since I need to be able to run 26.2 miles at this effort in 61 days).  This was a great turnaround from Saturday's debacle.  The rest of the week will be easy leading up to Get In Gear.  Looking forward to getting after it.
Didn't get going until late because I had to wait until the NFL schedule was released at 7:00 and then make calls to secure tickets to a few games.  Run was uneventful.

I ran a couple miles by myself on West River Road, then ran over to Nokomis with Dan after he finished his hill workout, then went around the lake and took an extended route home.  It was cold this morning - had to get the tights and turtleneck back out.  For the most part I felt good but by the end I was a little tired from doing 19 miles in 12 hours.

Lake St to Ford.  Colder again this morning.  Looks like it will be cold and windy on Saturday as well.  I almost witnessed a car accident when an idiot driver turned left onto West River when there was not a big enough break in traffic to do so, but fortunately the driver of the car coming at her was able to swerve (which involved two wheels going up onto the median for a couple seconds) and avoid it.

Short 'workout' (if you can even call it that) on the Minnehaha track this evening.  I wanted to do something that would raise my muscle tension before Saturday but not make me tired.  70 second 400s didn't feel quite as effortless as I would like, but it's not like they were hard.  On the other hand the 200 felt really easy.  I guess we'll see what we get in 36 hours.  Got some Panera afterward, then went to watch the 5Ks at Macalester.  It was a perfect night for a race.
Pre race run and strides at lunch.  Felt good.  Excited for tomorrow.

This was really disappointing.  I came in expecting a sub 31 and hoping to take a shot at my fastest 10K ever (30:44), and I wasn't even close.  I got out with the first pack (7 guys, with Sathre and a Kenyan out front) as I planned.  What wasn't planned was that I spent most of the first 2 miles leading this group, but I was feeling really good and we weren't running all that fast.  Just after the Lake St bridge someone (I think it was Austin Bauer) made a move.  I let one negative thought enter my mind and started to lose the group, then I pretty much crawled up the St Thomas hill and that totally knocked me out of contention.  I tried a few times to battle back on East River but it wasn't happening.  By 5 miles I felt terrible and just wanted to stop.  Kieser got me on the Ford bridge and went by hard enough that I couldn't latch on.  The Kenyan guy had fallen off and was jogging so I passed him to get back into 9th.  After the race I had a terrible attitude and just threw my stuff in my backpack and walked home without cooling down or talking to anyone.  I'm kind of embarrassed about my lack of sportsmanship.  

This result leaves me confused.  I felt so good for almost 3 miles, then within about 10 seconds I suddenly felt horrible.  Perhaps running at the front of that group was dumb, but leading at 5 minute pace in a 10K when it's not super windy shouldn't be that big of a deal.  It could be that the inconsistency in my training the past few months is catching up with me, or maybe it was simply a mental failure, although I thought that I was done with those.  Either way, I've got to shake this off and move on.  I keep telling myself that I'll be ok, but the way things have been going it's hard to see 2:17 happening in 8 weeks.  I guess we'll see where I am after a month of ~100 mile weeks and marathon specific workouts.

Pike Island run, then added a mile at the end.  Beautiful day.  It was nice to have a good run and remind myself that I like running since yesterday I wasn't so sure about that.  I almost continued on for another 10 miles since I was feeling good, but I decided to stick with my plan and wait until tomorrow.  As I was coming back into my building a family stopped me and asked me a bunch of questions about my running since apparently they see me coming back from runs a lot.  It was kind of an awkward conversation, but I guess it's nice when people are interested.

This wasn't the most fun run I've ever done, but it's in the books.  It's not a great feeling to be driving home from work with a 21 mile run hanging over your head.  I ran down West River, crossed the Franklin Bridge, went through the U of M, across the Stone Arch Bridge, down to the end of the path, added on a little loop, came almost all the way back on the east side of the river, then crossed the Lake St Bridge and ran the rest of the way home via West River.  Legs felt ok throughout.  By the end they were pretty tired (my left one more than my right one, which was weird).  I got side aches a couple of different times that prevented me from really opening up, but my average pace was still around 6:20, which is fine.  Probably had a little too much to eat during the day.  I'm glad this is done.
High Bridge loop from Run N Fun.  Hung out in the back with A Town.  My legs were tired today so I was glad that we were taking it easy.  Burger at Plums afterward.

Macalester loop (this is actually closer to 6.5 miles).  Longer morning run than normal but I wanted to do something different.  Beautiful morning and my legs felt decent, so good run.  Had some pain in my left hamstring at the very beginning but it went away.

Did 8 x 1K on the Minnehaha track at half marathon pace (or more accurately, what I think half marathon pace would be if I raced one soon).  My legs were tired and didn't have much pop, but this was still pretty easy.  I was thinking about doing a few faster intervals or hills at the end but decided against it since my hamstring has been a bit sore since Monday's run.  It was probably for the better to just keep this a moderate effort anyways.  Decent wind on the backstretch.  Now hopefully I can recover for a tough run on Saturday.

Ran about 8 miles (over to Fort Snelling), came inside and watched the NFL Draft for about 40 minutes, then went back out and finished the run.  None of the chaos that the 'experts' were talking about happened in the draft.  If I had known how it would play out I wouldn't have interrupted the run to watch it.  Oh well, at least I got to see Roger Goodell mispronounce Marcus Mariota's name.
Felt bad today.  My legs have been dead since Monday's 21 miler.

10.25 miles sub-tempo at 5:38 pace with Jacobs.  He had to work so we started the warmup at 7:30.  Getting up early wasn't fun but it was good that we did because this way we were done before it got hot.  We kept the pace steady in the upper 5:30s/lower 5:40s.  This was fine - after feeling bad most of the week I didn't feel like I needed to set a workout PR today.  I felt pretty good most of the way.  The St Thomas hill at 9 miles put a dent in my legs but we maintained pace.  It's also nice that I can hold a conversation at this pace.  Had a doughnut afterward at Run N Fun, then went to Hamline to watch Kieser's steeple and Dan's 1500, then went to UST to watch the Olaf guys in a 1500.  Good morning/early afternoon of running.

I assumed Jacobs would do a shakeout tonight so I decided I'd match it.  Did an easy 3 and then six strides.  Stayed in the grass for almost all of it.  It was nice to loosen up and then get in a good stretching and rolling session.  The rest of the night consisted of Clippers/Spurs Game 7 (classic) followed by Mayweather/Pacquiao (dud).

Same Fort Snelling run that I've done the past few Sundays.  I waited until just before noon in order to get some heat acclimation in.  Started very slowly but by about mile 3 I was down to a respectable pace.  I actually felt better today than I did on Thursday and Friday, which makes no sense.  Had to dodge a bunch of strollers and little kids by Minnehaha Park.
Crosby Farms loop then added a mile at the end.  Really nice weather and my legs felt good.  Only bad thing was I didn't sleep well last night.
Lake St to Ford.  Ended up having about 12 hours in between runs today.

4 x 2:00 (2:00 jog)
4 x 1:30 (1:30 jog)
4 x 1:00 (1:00 jog)
4 x 0:30 (0:30 jog)

Ran this on the river road.  Felt like I was pushing pretty well and speeding up as I went along.  Another nice morning - the weather would have been great for a marathon workout, but I've done enough strength work recently.

Got up early and banged out 18 before work.  Griff would be proud.  I had to do it in the morning because I'm busy tonight.  Getting out of bed was a chore, but once I got past that the run went well.  Went out over the Stone Arch Bridge as usual.  Seems like I can't not run the second half of a long run at six minute pace.

I started the morning with a bloody nose, then after I got that taken care of I ran a Nokomis loop.  I'm taking a short day today since I haven't had one in awhile.  Felt decent this morning though - thought I was going to be a lot more tired after a workout and long run the past two days, plus being up late last night.

5 for 5 on running in the morning this week.  Went out and back 10 on river road.  Legs felt really good after taking yesterday easy.  50 degrees with some wind out of the northeast - it would be great if the weather was exactly like this on June 20th.
Ran again after MIACs.  Felt good.

5 miles at marathon effort - 26:15
5:14, 5:13, 5:22, 5:12, 5:14

5 x mile (1:00 jog between)
5:07, 5:06, 5:06, 5:04, 5:04

I feel really good about this one.  When I ran a similar workout 6 weeks out from CIM I averaged 5:22 on the first section and 5:11 on the miles.  Outside of mile 3 (which included both a hill and a 180 degree turn around) I felt strong.  There was a bike event taking place on West River Road and I bet that there were hundreds of people out there.  Never felt like I was straining on the miles, and with a gun to my head I could have done a few more.  I'm starting to get to where I need to be - now I need to keep building off of this.

I liked the post workout shakeout last Saturday and thought that it helped me feel better the next day, so I decided to do it again.  My legs felt like I hadn't run at all today, much less done a hard workout.  I could've easily gone 10.  Watched a good MIAC meet this afternoon, and my face got nice and sunburned sitting out there.
Good run to finish out a good training week.  I didn't get out the door until about 7 PM.  Legs were a little tired from yesterday, but not bad by any means.  Raining off and on.

Macalester loop.  Felt alright, although it seems like I don't sleep very well on Sunday nights (probably because I usually sleep in on Sundays).  Dreary morning outside - low 50s and cloudy.  On river road I saw a lady 'running' while pushing a stroller, holding a dog leash, and texting.  Also saw the Team USA Minnesota crew finishing their warmups before a track workout.
Franklin to Ford, then ran up the hill to Chipotle to grab a burrito.  I felt alright.  Starting to get some accumulated fatigue setting in I think.  By the time I got home I was starving.

8 mile moderate tempo
4 x Ford Hill (ran these just shy of all out)

5:39, 5:30, 5:33, 5:32, 5:34, 5:38 (St Thomas hill), 5:20, 5:17

The goal on the tempo was to run ~5:30s for the first six and then ~5:20s for the last two.  I never really found the 5:30 pace and was consistently between 5:32 and 5:35.  Ran 5:20, 5:17 for the last two.  Aerobically this was a cakewalk.  My legs didn't feel terrible, but I was noticeably tired.  I also had no caffeine today, which could have been a contributing factor.  Hopefully I'll feel quite a bit better in a week and a half when I hope to go twice as far at roughly this same pace.  Ran the hills hard afterward.  I wasn't flat out sprinting, but I don't think I could have gone too much further at that same effort.  Cooldown was pretty short because I was hungry and just ready to be done.
Easy shakeout.  Felt fine after the first mile.  The forecast looks pretty bad for working out on both Saturday and Sunday so I may have to move some things around.

Out and back on Shepard.  My legs were dead this evening and I was cruising a hot 7:40 pace for the first few miles.  Crossed paths with the Collegeville group, including Chris Coffey who was trailing about 200 meters behind the pack (along with another guy).  Rolled my legs afterward.

Up and out early.  I almost threw my phone against the wall when the alarm rang at 6 AM.  Ran to the Stone Arch Bridge and actually felt pretty decent once I got going.  It was lightly misting almost the whole time.  I'm glad I'm not running the TC 1 Mile tonight.  Those guys are going to get soaked.

I was planning on taking a later lunch break and running about 10 miles during that, but all of the people I sit by at work decided to go out to lunch together and I didn't want to be the only person who didn't go, so I changed my plans and went with them.  Then I wasn't able to get out of the office until about 7:30.  I took a few miles off of the run since I knew I'd be starting my warmup for tomorrow's workout in less than 12 hours.  Not ideal, but it's ok.  Oles killed it in the 1500 today.  6 guys going to nationals next week in that event, plus Jake in the steeple and Phil in the 10K.

4 x 2.5 miles at marathon pace (2:30 recovery)

13:16 - 5:20, 5:19, 2:37
13:15 - 5:20, 5:17, 2:38
13:22 - 5:17, 2:45, 5:20
13:12 - 5:19, 5:16, 2:37

Tough workout this morning.  Jacobs ran the first two reps with me and then split off to do a few faster mile repeats.  It was really nice to have someone out there for part of it.  We started off on the first rep and I thought that it had this one potential to get ugly, as my legs did not feel good.  I didn't quite get down to my goal marathon pace (5:15s), but I wasn't that far off and for a day where I didn't feel great I will take it.  On the third one (my first one by myself) I dropped a 2:45 800 but told myself to get back on it and was fortunately able to do so.  Had R Kelly's 'World's Greatest' playing in my head for some reason during the last one.  We'll see about a shakeout tonight - my legs are pretty dead right now.

Easy 10 in Fort Snelling.  Kind of tired from yesterday but not too bad.  The humidity has gone up so it sort of feels like summer.  There was some sort of organized walk taking place on West River.  Also saw Adam Frye and Andrea Gelle out running (separately).

As I was crossing the Ford bridge at the start of the run I bumped into Easker and Reneau so I ran with them for about 5 miles.  After they stopped I headed towards Fort Snelling, where I found a large downed tree blocking the path after last night's storm.  Hopefully that will get taken care of soon.  Finished up with a short add-on on the river road.  Legs felt pretty good.  The 43 degree weather wasn't that bad.
